PAUL KANGAS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From rumor to reality -- one of the hottest private equity firms will be private no more. The Blackstone Group will take up residence here at the New York Stock Exchange. We`ll detail its $4 billion initial public offering.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Senate Banking Chairman Christopher Dodd scolded bank regulators today, saying they didn`t do enough to stop predatory lending in the sub-prime market. Dodd also put lenders on notice, saying they too are to blame for the sub-prime mess.

KANGAS: From sub-prime loans to sluggish sales and falling home prices, we go region by region for a look at the state of the American housing market.

PRATT: Then, Oracle is taking on one of its biggest rivals in court. We`ll tell you who the software giant is suing and why.

KANGAS: I`m Paul Kangas.

PRATT: And I`m Suzanne Pratt. Susie Gharib is off tonight. This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, May (sic) 22.

KANGAS: Good evening, everyone. One of the world`s largest private equity funds is going public. Late today, Blackstone Group announced a $4.4 or $4 billion initial public offering. The move lets investors buy into a risky business that has traditionally been the ground of wealthy individuals and large institutions. Blackstone generated more than $7.5 billion in investment gains in 2006. The company`s assets under management are worth almost $79 billion. Its portfolio includes real estate giant Equity Office Properties, Extended Stay America Hotels, publisher Houghton Mifflin and entertainment park Universal Orlando. Blackstone will trade on the New York Stock Exchange. But there`s no IPO date or ticker symbol specified in today`s filing with the SEC. But the company did say it won`t give quarterly guidance to Wall Street because its business is quote, unpredictable.

PRATT: The meltdown in the sub-prime lending market reached Capitol Hill today. The Senate Banking Committee called regulators, lenders and borrowers to learn more about the causes behind the sub-prime crisis. But as Stephanie Dhue reports, the committee quickly got down to the business of laying blame.

STEPHANIE DHUE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: With an increasing number of homeowners facing foreclosure, lawmakers, including New Jersey Senator Robert Menendez, accused the Federal Reserve of being asleep at the switch.

SEN. ROBERT MENENDEZ (D) NEW JERSEY: How could it be this big and you have done your job?

ROGER COLE, DIR., BANKING SUPERVISION & REGULATION, FEDERAL RESERVE: Given what we know now, yes, we could have done more sooner.

DHUE: Regulators say much of the sub-prime market falls outside their jurisdiction, which deals mostly with ensuring that banks are financially sound. But Senate Banking Committee Chairman Chris Dodd wasn`t buying that argument.

SEN. CHRIS DODD, CHAIRMAN, BANKING COMMITTEE: The Fed had the responsibility in my view, as a good cop, to be on the beat, particularly going back several years ago, when the information first began to surface that there were serious problems with these sub-prime loans.

DHUE: Dodd called on the regulators to quickly finalize tighter sub- prime lending standards. But lenders warn some borrowers will be shut out of the market. Countrywide Financial says it would lose 60 percent of its sub-prime business under the proposed tighter standards. Still, the company`s managing director, Sandor Samuels, says that`s not his key concern.

SANDOR SAMUELS, MANAGING DIRECTOR, COUNTRYWIDE FINANCIAL: The concern that we have is the impact on the housing market and the impact on borrowers who are in the sub-prime market. And so we hope the regulations can find a balance that will allow consumers to benefit from lower housing payments, while protecting them from unaffordable payment increases.

DHUE: The committee also heard from borrowers now at risk of losing their homes. Jennie Haliburton got an adjustable 2/28 sub-prime loan from Countrywide last year. Her payment is set to adjust in May to more than 70 percent of her income.

JENNIE HALIBURTON, BORROWER: I feel like they took advantage of me because I`m 77 and they figure, "oh, well, she`s old."

DHUE: Countrywide says it will work with Mrs. Haliburton to keep her in her home. Senator Dodd says there are thousands of sub-prime borrowers struggling with their mortgages and he wants to find ways to help them. Stephanie Dhue, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

PRATT: KB Home`s quarterly earnings plummeted 84 percent, as home prices dropped, inventories swelled and the sub-prime mortgage market began to implode. KB Home earned $0.34 a share in its fiscal first quarter. That`s down sharply from the year-ago period, but $0.09 ahead of analyst estimates. Sales fell 19 percent to $1 3/4 billion, but that was still ahead of estimates. KB Home`s CEO says housing conditions remain difficult, making it even harder to predict when the market will stabilize. The company also says 13 percent of the mortgages for KB Homes last year were financed with sub-prime loans.

KANGAS: Wall Street felt the sting of profit taking this morning after yesterday`s sharp rally. Selling was also linked to Motorola`s forecast of a first quarter loss and a rise in oil prices. By 11 a.m., the Dow was off 30 points, NASDAQ down 12. The blue chips improved this afternoon with the help of a brokerage upgrade on Procter & Gamble and some strong oil stocks, but the broader market ended lower. The Dow Industrial Average closed up 13.62 at 12,461.14. NASDAQ Composite lost 4.18, ending at 2451.74. Standard & Poor`s 500 Index fell exactly a half point to 1434.54. Over in the bond market, the 10-year note fell 12/32 to par and 10/32, lifting the yield to 4.59 percent.

PRATT: This week in our special housing series, we looked at market conditions in three U.S. cities: New York, Washington, DC and Miami. Tonight, we continue that series with a broader discussion of the national housing market. Our guest this evening is Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody`s economy.com. Mark, welcome.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY`S ECONOMY.COM: Thanks for having me.

PRATT: So what is the current state of the U.S. housing market?

ZANDI: It`s struggling. The correction which began almost two years ago is ongoing. Since the peak, we have seen sales off about 10, 15 percent. Starts are done by a third. And prices are now falling in about half to two-thirds of the nation`s market.

PRATT: So this is a correction, though, not a meltdown?

ZANDI: I would characterize it as a correction. It is a severe correction. But at this point we`re not seeing double digit price declines. And the market is still holding together reasonably well so not a crash, at least not yet.

PRATT: So tell me about the weakest areas of the country. What are some of those?

ZANDI: Well, they would include California, primarily southern California. San Diego would be a good case in point. Arizona, Phoenix, Las Vegas, most of Florida, particularly south of Florida and parts of the northeast, Washington DC, the Boston region and of course the areas around Detroit are very weak because of job losses in the auto industry.

PRATT: And what about the strongest regions of the country, what are those?

ZANDI: Well, there are fewer but Texas would be a relatively strong housing market, some of the areas around the Carolinas, the farm belt and the pas civic northwest. In fact house prices in the Pacific northwest are still rising at a double-digit pace.

PRATT: So is it typical for a correction like this to be so uneven?

ZANDI: It is. The house market is a very local market. It really depends on where you are. Although I have to say this is the broadest the housing market correction that I think we`ve experienced at least since the great depression.

PRATT: So if it is so broad though is that, or does that have ominous predictions or does that mean that we should be more concerned?

ZANDI: Well, we should be concerned. The soft part of the economy lies in the housing and now of course in the mortgage market. Housing is weighing heavily on the economy. So far the problems in housing have been largely contained to housing. They haven`t bled out to consumer spending and business investment. But given the problems and the fact that they are ongoing, we need to watch that very carefully.

PRATT: So let`s talk a little bit about the sub-prime part of the market. I mean what does that mean? What is that likely to do to the overall housing market? Could it take it into a meltdown?

ZANDI: Well, it is a significant problem. If you consider all of the very aggressive loans that have been extended in recent years, that would include sub-prime, alternative A, prime loans that are interest only or negative am loans -- these are very aggressive loans. You combine all those and these are ones at a significant risk of default. They account for 40 percent of origination volume last year and roughly one quarter of all mortgage debt outstanding. So this a significant market that is going to be significantly affected. As a result, we will see some measurable impact on housing activity and probably as a result on the broader economy.

PRATT: One thing I want to make sure that we cover is the Fed and their statement yesterday. They sort of removed the bias, depending on who you ask. You think that that was because or directly because of the housing market.

ZANDI: Yeah, I think they did -- they did get rid of their bias towards future higher interest rates. They now have a neutral policy and I think they did that to have some latitude just in case if the housing market goes south and the mortgage market weakens, that they could ease if they needed to. At this point I don`t think they want to. Inflation is above their target. They would prefer not to, but they needed a little bit of flexibility and they got that in yesterday`s statement.

PRATT: OK, great. My guest this evening, Mark Zandi, chief economist at moodyseconomy.com, thanks for joining us.

ZANDI: Thank you.

KANGAS: Business software maker Oracle sued German rival SAP today, claiming SAP committed quote, corporate theft on a grand scale end quote. Oracle says SAP illegally logged on to its password-protected customer web sites many times, stealing huge amounts of software code, documents and other confidential material. Oracle claims it knows SAP excuse me, was the culprit because Oracle traced the log-ons back to an SAP-owned subsidiary in Texas. SAP said it had no comment on the lawsuit. Oracle wants a California court to assess damages, force SAP to return the stolen items and bar SAP from logging on to Oracle`s web sites.

Crude oil surged more than 2 percent today, jumping $2.08 to $61.69 a barrel. The rally was fueled by expectations energy demand will start to surge as we head into the summer driving season. And as Erika Miller explains, experts expect oil prices to spurt even higher.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Spring is supposed to be the time of year when energy prices dip due to weak demand. Instead, the opposite is happening. Analyst Fadel Gheit blames an across- the-board rally in energy prices on strong demand for gasoline.

FADEL GHEIT, ENERGY ANALYST, OPPENHEIMER & CO.: Right now, gasoline prices are leading the energy markets in the U.S. But it doesn`t mean that oil prices are, you know, pulling back. Oil prices have shown tremendous resiliency that nobody had expected.

MILLER: Gasoline futures have surged over 20 percent since January. They`re now at a seven-month high. The rally is due in large part to fears of a supply crunch heading into the summer driving season. In the U.S., there has been an almost insatiable demand for motor fuel, despite higher prices at the pump. At the same time, supplies are dwindling. Energy trader Ira Eckstein blames that on glitches and seasonal maintenance at refineries.

IRA ECKSTEIN, OIL TRADER, AREA INTERNATIONAL TRADING: We have these outages, plus they are doing their usual spring -- they`re going from heating oil to gasoline, so they had to close down some refineries in order to switch over.

MILLER: There are also concerns about disruptions to crude supplies due to geopolitical tensions in places like Iran, Nigeria, and Saudi Arabia. Another big unknown is weather. Hurricane season starts June 1, raising the risk of damage to U.S. oil infrastructure. In the near term, many traders expect oil prices to inch higher. The question is, how much?

ECKSTEIN: Crude oil is going to test that $62.50 level -- maybe not this week, but maybe early next week and I think that we could stay above there. We`ll see how we react when we get there.

MILLER: That`s bad news for motorists. In some places, including New York City, regular unleaded is approaching $3 a gallon. But few experts think we`ll head back to record levels just yet. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York

PRATT: Transatlantic air travel took a leap into the future today, as the European Union`s transport ministers approved plans to open the skies to more competition. The so-called open skies deal lets EU carriers fly from any city in the block to any city in the U.S. and vice versa. The Bush administration welcomed the decision, saying it will spur growth and give Americans more flying freedom. The plan had been set to take effect in October, but all sides agreed on a five-month delay. The new start date is March 30, 2008, Paul.

KANGAS: Suzanne, shares of the major air carriers hit some turbulence today on concerns that pact could trigger a price war. We`ll look at how they did as we take a look at our stocks in the news tonight.

Big board volume leader on nearly 51 million shares, Motorola (MOT) down $1.24. After the close yesterday as we reported, the company predicted a $0.07 to $0.09 per share first quarter loss.

Then Pfizer (PFE) down $0.06.

General Electric (GE) moved up $0.33. The company is teaming up with News Corporation to launch an online video site to compete with youtube. The details coming up shortly.

Ford Motor Co (F) was up $0.07.

CVS Caremark (CVS), this is the first day of trading for the new merger company of CVS Caremark, down $0.36 a share, fifth in volume.

AT&T (T) rose $0.25.

Alcatel-Lucent (ALU) down a half a dollar. Goldman Sachs downgraded it from "buy" to "neutral" because it sees no sales recovery for the firm before the third quarter of this year.

ExxonMobil (XOM) up $1.13 on that sharp rise in oil.

Chesapeake Energy (CHK) down $0.15.

And Time Warner (TWX), tenth in volume, was off $0.28.

Procter Gamble (PG) moved up $0.89. Bear Stearns upgraded it from "peer perform" to "out perform" because of its attractive valuation in the price of the stock, according to Bear Stearns.

And then AMR (AMR) parent of American Airlines, down $1.54, not only today because of the sharp rise in oil, but airfares are expected to tumble next spring when the open skies package you just heard about goes into effect.

Let`s have a look at some other major carriers. Continental Air (CAL) down $1.60.

And UAL Corp (UAUA) losing $1.77.

Raytheon Co (RTN) off $1.41. The company boosted its annual dividend 6 percent from $0.96 to $1.02, but nevertheless, Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock from "neutral" to a "sell."

Conagra Foods (CAG), the big packaged foods company down $0.02 despite a turnaround. Third quarter earnings of $0.38 versus a loss last year. Those earnings $0.03 above the Street estimate.

Another packaged foods company, General Mills (GIS) moving up $0.44. Third quarter earnings there were up nearly 9 percent to $0.74, $0.04 above the Street estimate and the company boosted its 2007 earnings guidance.

Nortel Networks (NT) fell $1.53. The company launched a $1 billion offering of convertible debt, which of course has potential earnings dilution.

Then we see Barnes & Noble (BKS), the book seller, down $1.10. The company says preliminary fourth quarter earnings will be $1.84, up from $1.76 last year, but $0.04 below the Wall Street estimate.

IHS (IHS), a $3.90 gain. The aerospace defense contractor had nicely higher first quarter earnings, $0.32 versus $0.24 last year and revenues up 18 percent.

Clarcor (CLC) which is a big filtration company off $2.87. Third quarter earnings $0.32, a penny above last year, but $0.04 below the Street estimate. Sales actually fell 1.7 percent.

Google (GOOG) topped the active list on NASDAQ gaining $5.49.

Apple (AAPL) a $0.09 rise.

Microsoft (MSFT) down $0.25.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) a $0.42 loss.

Intel (INTC) dropped $0.18 a share, fifth in dollar volume.

Research in Motion (RIMM) up $1.64.

Then Oracle (ORCL) a $0.32 gain there.

Palm (PALM) closed down $1.71. Speculation appears to be cooling that it might be the target of a takeover attempt. After the close, Palm reported third quarter earnings excluding items, $0.16 a share, $0.04 above the Street estimate. In after hours trading, the stock was about $0.20 higher than this.

Broadcom (BRCM) down $1.29, hurt by Motorola`s earnings warning.

And then Qualcomm (QCOM) tenth in volume was off $0.38 a share.

Intuit (INTU) down $2.46. The company says its Turbotax software sales are off to a slow start this tax season so far.

Those are the stocks in the news tonight. Suzanne.

PRATT: The SEC and the American Stock Exchange today settled their differences over problems with the exchange`s oversight of options trading. Regulators allege, from 1999 through June 2004, the Amex didn`t adequately enforce certain order-handling rules and comply with record-keeping guidelines. The settlement creates a $3 million fund to help pay for stepped up exchange surveillance. Still in the works, though, EC action against the Amex`s former Chairman Salvatore Sodano.

KANGAS: Tomorrow, our Friday "market monitor" guest is Jeffrey Everett, chief investment officer at Templeton Global Advisors.

PRATT: A Federal judge in Mississippi has turned down a request to allow a class-action suit against State Farm insurance for denial of damage claims from hurricane Katrina. At issue so-called slab cases where houses were destroyed down to the slab. The judge said while all the homes were ruined, there are other factors that make the cases unsuitable for class action.

KANGAS: Coca-Cola is rolling out a new version of its diet Coke drink, adding vitamins and minerals to the mix. The new diet Coke plus will contain small mounts of vitamins B-3, B-6 and B-12, as well as magnesium and zinc. But the recipe for the soda itself will be unchanged. Coke says the new soft drink should hit U.S. store shelves next month.

PRATT: Here`s a look at what`s happening tomorrow. February existing home sales come out, along with earnings from Freddie Mac.

Tonight`s commentator has a few thoughts on what the Blackstone Group`s $4 billion IPO could mean to Wall Street. Here`s Chrystia Freeland, U.S. managing editor of "The Financial Times."

CHRYSTIA FREELAND, US MANAGING EDITOR, FINANCIAL TIMES: The irony of the move is irresistible. After all, the private equity business is based on the idea that a lot of companies can be run more effectively if they are liberated from the short-term targets and regulatory red tape that bedevils the public market. But there are some powerful reasons for Blackstone to be tempted to go public. The greatest may be the simplest. Blackstone`s founders are surely keen in Wall Street`s uncharacteristically coy terminology to crystallize the value of their partnership.

In plainer language, that means they want to take their billions before they retire. In contrast with those pitied Goldman Sachs senior partners who left the legendary firm before its IPO and missed out on the windfall their younger colleagues collected. For those of us not in line to receive Blackstone`s billions, the greatest significance of an IPO would be to make the private equity revolution more sustainable. Private equity has become so powerful it is easy to forget that the dominant groups are just a few decades old, are still run by the men who founded them and are dependent on Internet and fund-raising (INAUDIBLE) for most of their capital. Going public would give them access to permanent money and thus make them a more permanent fixture in world business. And that is the real irony of the story. Public capital could well give private equity groups a more enduring power to take companies private. I`m Chrystia Freeland.

KANGAS: Recapping today`s market action, a split decision on Wall Street. The Dow gained 13 points while the NASDAQ Composite lost four points. To learn more about the stories in tonight`s broadcast, go to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on pbs.org. You can also e-mail us at nbr@pbs.org

PRATT: And finally tonight, what does it take to get two bitter rivals together? And what does it take to make tax time less taxing? Scott Gurvey has those answers and more in tonight`s "tech talk."

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Tonight`s big tech news is a partnership of two very unlikely bedfellows: NBC Universal and Newscorp, parent of the Fox network. Who could get these guys together? Try youtube, the popular video-sharing web site now owned by Google. Youtube members make and post videos, often using original material, but just as often using content recorded from TV and cable, raising copyright concerns. A competing site run by NBC and Newscorp would have lots of content it could legally distribute. Yahoo!, MSN, AOL and Newscorp`s myspace will be involved. Stay tuned.

All of these sites make money by selling ads. The more popular the site, the more it can sell, and it adds up! Cisco Systems, Intel and General Motors have already signed up to advertise on the new NBC-Newscorp site. There are big bucks involved. Google paid $1.6 billion to buy youtube and recently, Viacom sued youtube for $1 billion, charging it with copyright infringement. Youtube has yet to file a response. The digital millennium copyright act of 1998 was supposed to clarify copyright law in the Internet age. It appears there is more work to be done.

It is tax time and the IRS says more than 130 million returns will be filed this year. Thirty five million will be made with tax preparation software. I`ve tried the leading products and, while they all do a good job, once again I`ve found Intuit`s Turbotax to be the most comprehensive and easiest to use. It does tend to cost $10 to $15 more than H&R Block`s tax cut. This year, Intuit added a home and business version, perfect if you file a Schedule C or need to generate W-2s for business or household employees. The tax software companies report their fastest growth is among taxpayers who enter all their data online, a process Intuit`s Bob Meighan says is simple and safe.

BOB MEIGHAN, VICE PRESIDENT, INTUIT: People don`t have to go to the store and buy the software. They don`t have to install it. They don`t have to worry about updates. I can go to the web and access tax software to do my return, so it`s convenient. All the products I know about use secure connections. If you`re transmitting your return to the IRS, it`s via secure connection, so the data is secure. All the companies that I know about guard your information very, very well, because we want to protect your privacy.

GURVEY: Even with the tax software, I haven`t sent in my return yet. How about you? Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

PRATT: That`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, March 22. I`m Suzanne Pratt. Good night everyone and good night to you, Paul.

KANGAS: Good night, Suzanne. I`m Paul Kangas, wishing all of you the best of good buys.

END

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I'm Tom Hudson. Susie is off tonight. A rescue for Knight Capital today. The trading firm stays in business thanks to a $400 million investment.

Erika Miller reports tonight on a takeover offer for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY). The founder of the struggling electronics retail chain wants to take it private.

And the Mars rover has landed on the red planet. We'll see what U.S. companies hope to gain by signing on to the mission. That and more coming up tonight here on NBR.

We begin with this, a $400 million lifeline today for Knight Capital. It's a company that makes some of the plumbing of the U.S. stock market. The market maker has been fighting to survive since a trading software update went hay-wire last week, leading to hundreds of millions of dollars in losses, its stock price cut by two-thirds and now a rescue by some of its competitors.

The deal by a half dozen Wall Street firms to invest in Knight allowed the company to, quote, resume normal operations immediately, end quote, according to Knight. Those behind the $400 million deal are investment banking firms Jefferies, Stephens and Stifel Financial (NYSE:SF), private equity giant Blackstone, trading competitor Getco and customer TD Ameritrade (NASDAQ:AMTD). Ameritrade was one of Knight's big customers that stopped doing business with it after Wednesday's trading trouble. Ameritrade has since returned as have other big customers.

As for its investment in Knight, an Ameritrade spokesperson tells NBR, quote, we have an interest in preserving choice and competition in the markets, end quote. Knight Capital matches buyers and sellers of thousands of stocks and billions of shares. It also buys and sells stocks itself, helping keep money flowing. So when it's new trading software had a problem, the firm was stuck with hundreds of millions of dollars in losing trades. That sent shareholders fleeing, driving down its stock price, leading Knight to look for help. But the assistance comes at the expense of diluting current shareholders' interest. That pressured Knight stock today, down 24 percent. Knight's rescuers get preferred stock that may be converted to common stock at $1.50 per share plus a 2 percent dividend. The deal represents a 73 percent stake in the company. The investor group also gets three new seats on the board of directors.

HUDSON: All this week at NBR, we're looking at you, the everyday investor and what problems like the one at Knight Capital are doing to investor confidence. You may remember the last time a computer system sent the stock prices spiraling. It happened back in May 2010 and was called the flash crash. It led to new rules on when firms get a do-over after a computer error. Knight asked for just such a do-over, pleading with the Securities and Exchange Commission to be released from mistaken trades. The answer back, no. Darren Gersh tonight reports on the firm line from Washington.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: This is really a story about a bailout that didn't happen. Knight Capital Group (NYSE:KCG) asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for special help. Stock exchange rules set strict limits on when trades can be reversed. In Knight's case, the rules say trades made by mistake that are more than 30 percent off of the real market price can be undone. Knight wanted more trades busted, but regulators said no. The message was clear.

JAMES ANGEL, FINANCE PROFESSOR, GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY: Once you make a trade, unless something has gone incredibly wrong, your word is your bond. You make a trade, you are expected to live up to it.

GERSH: People familiar with the matter say regulators are sending a clear message to investors: the rules on erroneous trades are meant to provide markets with certainty and they worked in this case. Another message: firms need to have incentives to be careful and what happened to Knight is a big incentive.

ANGEL: Right now I think that every IT manager is going to his boss and saying, give me a bigger budget so I make sure this isn't going to happen here.

GERSH: But that does not reassure critics who fear Wall Street firms have created computer systems they can't control.

DENNIS KELLEHER, CEO, BETTER MARKETS: It is not a glitch when in less than 30 minutes over 150 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange vary wildly in purchases and sales and prices and there's essentially haywire in the markets. That's not a glitch. That's a huge problem. It's a red flag and people better start paying attention.

GERSH: While the SEC took a tough line with Knight Capital, there are growing concerns about the ability of regulators to police the Street.

KELLEHER: Regulators and regulation generally can't keep up with what's going on in the markets. It's just that simple. Now one of the main reasons for that is that there is a fairly massive effort led by Wall Street and its allies to de-fund the agencies so they can prevent them from putting financial reform into place.

GERSH: Before the computer mistake, Knight Capital handled 20 percent of the trading in stocks like Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL). It was well-respected and innovative and all that blew up in less than half an hour. Darren Gersh, NBR, Washington.

HUDSON: (INAUDIBLE) Just the latest reminder of how technology continues to reshape the investment market. As part of our coverage this week, join the discussion online on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and Twitter, bizrpt. How confident are you in the technology that powers the market? Will it change how you trade and invest because of the technology? Join us online.

On Wall Street today meantime, investors helped the major averages to finish a fresh three-month highs tonight, despite some selling in Knight Capital shares as we mentioned. The Dow Industrials rising 21 points, the NASDAQ up 22, the S&P 500 gained three points. One other quick note here about policing the markets. A major British bank was accused today of hiding over 60,000 illegal transactions with Iran over the past decade. Those transactions made by Standard Charter PLC were valued at over $250 billion. New York State's department of financial services threatened to revoke the bank's U.S. license today and called it a quote, rogue institution. Standard Charter meantime said it's reviewing its compliance with U.S. banking sanctions.

A billion dollar plus bet could be paying off much sooner than Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) had hoped. One week into the media company's NBC Olympics coverage and it may actually turn a profit. NBC has been hit by the usual number of criticisms, too much focus on the Americans, not enough live coverage, hasn't hurt the television audience numbers here in the U.S. though. Through the first 10 days of coverage - look at this - Comcast's Olympic ratings averaged 33.6 million viewers. That's up 12 percent from Beijing, 28 percent higher than the Athens games in 2004.

Porter Bibb is back with us, managing partner at Mediatech Capital Partners at the NASDAQ. Porter, is it something that Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) is doing with its coverage of the games or is it the games themselves?

PORTER BIBB, MANAGING PARTNER, MEDIATECH CAPITAL PARTNERS: I think it's mostly the games themselves and it's the fact that there's not a lot else going on right now in the dog days of the summer of 2012. Basically it's the fact that this Olympics has drawn a tremendous amount of attention from the public and it's reflected in these numbers which are historic. They've never ever had such great ratings any television broadcast since 1960 when CBS (NYSE:CBS) first broadcast the Rome Olympics.

HUDSON: Talk to us about the opportunities here then. This opportunity comes at a significant cost, more than a billion dollars invested. Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) sold a billion dollars worth of advertising. Can it go back to its advertisers and ask for more money now that the ratings are in?

BIBB: They did get a little bit of a premium when they exceed the ratings, yes. But the biggest advertiser, interestingly enough on this Olympic tenure is NBC. Every third or fourth commercial is promoting an NBC series that's going to be breaking this fall and they're hoping to shore up their ratings throughout the year because NBC has been wallowing in the cellar behind all of the other major networks for the last seven years.

HUDSON: I want to talk about the investor in the Olympics here before we get to the broader NBC picture. Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) has estimated a $200 million profit. It spent about $1.2 billion for the rights it has to pay to produce the programs. Is this a good return on investment for shareholders?

BIBB: It's never been a good return in terms of bottom line, but it's considered by the TV executives in the suites to be the best promotion for their networks that money can buy. It rivals the Super Bowl and the way the Oscars used to command this kind of an audience but don't anymore.

HUDSON: Certainly, shareholders are being attracted to this stock, Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) shares at a 52-week high even with this billion dollar plus investment.

BIBB: You have to realize that NBC television is a very small part of the Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) empire. They're the largest cable systems operators in the country, in the world in fact and they're also the largest Internet service providers. They reap huge profits from NBC Universal (NYSE:UVV) cable channels, not just television networks.

HUDSON: Is that the way you leverage then the next Olympic games? Is that the lesson here?

BIBB: They have bought this Olympics and the summer and winter Olympics in 2020 and they expect that they will have to change the model because the next Rio in 2016 is going to be an online digital Internet, not like this one. These decisions that NBC made were two and a half years ago when they acquired the rights and they didn't anticipate the iPad and the profusion of smart phones that are out there. And their Internet delivery is really patchy. It's not very good, but it will be by the time they get to Rio for sure.

HUDSON: That's going to be the big change for the next summer games in four years. Do you have any position in Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) by the way, Porter?

BIBB: None.

HUDSON: Porter Bibb along with us here watching the Olympics and commenting on the coverage, Mediatech Capital Partners.

Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) founder and former chairman wants his stores back. Richard Schulze has offered to take the struggling electronics retail chain private. The offer is $24 to $26 per share. Now the higher price, it values the company at just over $8.8 billion. Erika Miller tonight in Manhattan joining us with what could be one of the biggest buyouts in recent years of an American retailer.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: That's right. Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) founder has made a generous offer for the stores but he still faces an uphill battle getting the board to approve it. In a public letter addressed to Best Buy's board, Richard Schulze says quote, bold and extensive changes are needed for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) to return to market leadership. He is proposing to buy out the company, using his own money, private equity funds and some debt. So would going public (sic) be the right strategy for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY)?

RJ HOTTOVY, SR. RETAIL ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: It may make sense for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) to be a privately held company, especially if you have the backing of a private equity company with retail and turnaround experience. Frankly, this company has got a lot of work ahead of them to stay competitive and stay relevant in the eyes of consumers.

MILLER: It's a moment of truth for the retail electronics chain Schulze founded in 1966. Part of Best Buy's problem is so-called showrooming. That's when customers browse the store, but actually place their orders elsewhere, often at online sites like Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN). An even bigger issue is the enormous size of most stores, a relic of a bygone era.

HOTTOVY: In the early part of the 90's through the early part of the 2000s, really consumers had no problem. They were shopping in stores for TVs, video games, CDs were all a big part of their consumer electronics budget. But as that shifted to a digital distribution format over the last several years, it has left a gaping hole in Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) stores.

MILLER: Schulze will clearly face big challenges turning the offer into a deal. First, he needs to get the approval of all Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) board members before signing a deal with private equity partners. He will likely have trouble getting the support of interim CEO Mike Mikan, who is gunning for a permanent position at the helm. Second, Schulze will have to detail his turnaround plans, which are vague at this point. The third issue is money. The board will likely try to get a higher offer, if it supports a deal at all and that could make it harder for Schulze to secure financing. And don't forget Schulze was elbowed out as chairman in the spring, after an internal audit found he knew former CEO Brian Dunn was having an inappropriate relationship with a female employee. That alone is unlikely to be a deal breaker. But it may mean some board member resistance to putting him back in charge.

HUDSON: Erika is in New York tonight as we mentioned. So, why does Schulze make this offer in public? Why not negotiate privately with the board?

MILLER: In his letter, Schulze said he would have preferred to have private negotiations, but the board was dragging its feet, so he felt he had no choice but to take his campaign public and hope that Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) shareholders would support him.

HUDSON: It certainly caused a bit of a ruckus in the stock as we'll mention in a moment. But what happens now? What's the next step? What can we expect to hear, when can we hear from the board?

MILLER: It's unclear at this point. All that we know is that Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) will confirm its made the offer, but don't know when it will respond.

HUDSON: We are coming into a key time for retailers like Best Buys, holidays right around the corner, turnarounds are easier said than done this time of year. What does is need to do to discourage the showrooming, the shopping and actually and turn the shopping into buying?

MILLER: Best Buy's biggest problem is its format, 50,000 square feet on average of retail space just doesn't make sense any more. It needs to go to a smaller format store. That's its biggest challenge. But it also needs to emphasize its most profitable product lines. We're talking about things like mobile phones.

HUDSON: Erika Miller tonight in New York on Best Buy (NYSE:BBY). Thanks, Erika. From electronic retailing to auto sales, July was a disappointing month of sales for General Motors (NYSE:GM) at home. Not so in China though. The U.S. auto maker set a sales record there last month. But the road ahead in China could be dicey for GM and other auto companies. Diane Eastabrook has details.

DIANE EASTABROOK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: GM bucked fears of a slowing economy in China last month by selling 15 percent more vehicles there than it did during the same month last year. Among the biggest sellers for GM were Buick Excel models. While auto sales in China have been strong compared to last year, they've actually been declining month over month this year, a possible sign of a cooling Chinese economy. June sales slid nearly 2.5 percent from May and sales were also down the two months before that. Still U.S. auto manufacturers are betting big on China. GM is the market leader, selling more than 2.5 million vehicles there last year primarily through joint ventures. Ford is increasing its exposure there as well, planning to add six new plants in China that will produce more than a million vehicles by 2015. Diane Eastabrook, NBR, Chicago.

HUDSON: In our "Market Focus," Some modest gains driving the U.S. major stock indices up to three-month highs tonight. We begin with the intraday S&P 500 starting out with the index jumping on the heels of some decent gains we saw overnight in European and Asian markets. No headline economic data today as the buying cooled somewhat into the closing bell. The index finished up a fraction. But it was enough for it to continue the trend since June of higher highs and higher lows. This is the S&P 500's highest close since May 2nd. Trading volume meantime backing off from Friday's pace, 645 million shares on the big board, just over one and a half billion on the NASDAQ.

It was a mixed market, six of the 10 major stock sectors were higher. Material stocks leading the gainers, up 1.1 percent. Technology added 0.7 of a percent and it was steel stocks behind today's gain in the materials sector. Many of these manufacturers have struggled under weaker building demand and lower pricing. But we have seen some buying lately after a string of better than expected earnings and some of the stocks also hitting recent lows.

U.S. Steel up today 5.6 percent, Titanium Metals (NYSE:TIE) rallying 4.5 percent. Both of these tonight are at their highest prices since mid- May. Cliff's Natural Resources added 2.7 percent. Today was the first Monday since May that the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted a gain. Two of the top 3 percentage gainers in fact for the Dow in the tech industry. HPQ, Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ) up 2.4 percent. This buying comes after HP sank to a seven and a half year low late last week. Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) the other big tech stock on the Dow that's been under pressure and shares gained 2.1 percent, although volume was lighter than usual during today's buying of CSCO.

The biggest meat processor in the U.S., Tyson Foods (NYSE:TSN), may have to turn to Brazil for corn. The company put that option on the table today thanks to the continued drought throughout the Midwestern U.S. It comes after Tyson reported weaker than expected earnings, coming in $0.04 below estimates. Its beef business saw lower demand thanks to the controversy over a ground beef additive called pink slime by critics. Falling pork prices hurt that business in Tyson as well. The company went on to lower its revenue outlook for the year. That hit shares, falling eight percent. Volume was more than three times normal for TSN. This in fact tonight is a new 52-week low for Tyson.

Shares of semi-truck maker Navistar hit the gas, after Federal regulators, environmental regulators submitted a final rule allowing, that may allow the company to continue to pay fines and still sell engines that do not meet EPA guidelines. The stock has been under pressure as it has been threatened with losing the ability to sell these new engines that don't meet current emissions standards. The details of today's final ruling were not disclosed. Shares jumped 10 percent though. An interim rule allowed Navistart to continue with its sales if it paid a fine.

All five of the most actively traded ETF's seeing some modest gains. The biggest for the Russell 2000 and NASDAQ 100 track funds. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

The virtual world of the Internet has changed businesses from newspapers to retailing. But the real world of video games continues to favor established names and not new-comers. That is tonight's "Word on the Street" -- gaming. Debra Borchardt, markets analyst at thestreet.com with us at the NASDAQ. Deborah, first of all explain the business model differences between the new digital gaming versus more traditional video games?

DEBRA BORCHARDT, MARKETS ANALYST, THESTREET.COM: Well, a lot of the digital gamers, the way that they earn money is putting advertising within the games or trying to get you to pay for different additional items like points and that type of model. But they're finding that people really just want to play their games on their phones for free. They're called snacking games. You just play them for a little bit of a time when you're standing in line, you're waiting in a restaurant, something like that. So you really don't want to pay any additional money, whereas your traditional game company like an Activision or an EA, they make their money off one upfront buying the game which is pretty expensive. But they've now determined ways to upsell you so that you can go and charge more for additional accessories to the game.

HUDSON: You can have a multitude of revenue sources in the language of an MBA student here. So the new generation is perhaps best illustrated by Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA), ZNGA, big business through facebook, and this stock has just been a disaster since its IPO, new lows last week here. Farmville is not working out for it. Is the new model broken?

BORCHARDT: Well it really is for Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) because they've got all their playing time on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) has started to push the old titles down in prominence and Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) hasn't got a new title to get in new revenue. So as Farmville loses its attraction, it has to come up with a new name to attract new players. So it's getting hurt with this relationship with Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and also by not having a new hit name.

HUDSON: But it's not alone in that. Even traditional video game companies like Activision also are looked at as what's new, what's next? Activision for instance had a pretty decent quarter earnings-wise, a third of its sales coming through its digital channel to cut out the retail space, nice bigger margins there. But yet the stock sold off significantly last week and rebounded a bit today.

BORCHARDT: Right. They were beat up because they said that their second quarter net income fell. Some user were - some investors were concerned that the users for "World of Warcraft" had dropped. But here's the thing. They have new titles coming up this fall. They're going to making it to the holidays and this is what's interesting. Here you've got Farmville with Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) and you can't really update it. They haven't really figured out how to built a franchise. The established companies were beat up for having franchises, but that's then the big payoff. "Call of Duty," "Black Ops" is coming out, (INAUDIBLE) Giant." These titles just keep paying off. Electronic Arts (NASDAQ:ERTS) has "Madden."

HUDSON: Debra, do you own any positions in these stocks?

BORCHARDT: No, I don't.

HUDSON: But we're going to guess you're a gamer nonetheless. Debra Borchardt along with us. She's with the street.com.

Congress has fled Washington, DC for a five-week summer recess, despite little progress on a host of bills covering everything from extending the Bush-era tax cuts to interim drought relief and Internet security. Tonight's commentary says don't blame the G-word for all that interaction or rather inaction. She's Veronique de Rugy, senior research fellow at the Mercatus Center at George Mason University.

VERONIQUE DE RUGY, SR. RSCH. FELLOW, MERCATUS CENTER, GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY: What's really the problem in Washington? Well, if you ask Washington, they'll tell you it's gridlock and blame inaction on some new and hyper-partisan or ideological era. But while gridlock might be blamed for slowing things down, it can't be blamed for failing to address serious issues. Welfare reform and balanced budgets in the 1990s were the product of gridlock that slowly gave way to consensus. And today's Washington is more than happy to come together when it suits its own interests.

For instance, just last week, Congress managed bipartisan support for another continuing resolution, an agreement that allows the legislators to, once again, put off doing any real fiscal planning. In fact, Congress hasn't managed to produce a Federal budget in more than three years. Washington's problem is not gridlock. It is an increasingly irresponsible government that has for far too long been let off the hook for performing the most basic responsibilities. So, whatever happens in November, this much is certain: unless taxpayers demand their president and Congress act responsibly and do the work they were elected to do, so-called Washington gridlock will be the least of our problems. I'm Veronique de Rugy.

HUDSON: You can find some progress in outer space. NASA's rover "Curiosity" tonight on the surface of the red planet. "Curiosity" pierced Mars' atmosphere traveling at 13,000 miles per hour, safely touched down after slowing to a mere two miles per hour. It began transmitting photos right away. Ruben Ramirez tonight reports on the partnership between government and business that made "Curiosity" possible.

RUBEN RAMIREZ, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The big question of course, is there, or, has there ever been life on Mars? Well, this week starts a two-year, $2.5 billion mission on the red planet to try and find the answer. Nearly three years behind schedule and almost a billion dollars over budget, NASA's "Curiosity" rover landed safely on Mars. It's the largest and most advanced spacecraft ever sent to outer space. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC), Lockheed Martin (NYSE:LMT), General Dynamics (NYSE:GD) and Siemens were just some of the companies that participated in the project. Siemens licensed its 3D modeling technology to NASA's jet propulsion lab to help cut prototype costs.

TONY AFFUSO, CHAIRMAN, SIEMENS PLM SOFTWARE: These techniques between public and private and the way that they can share costs, share risks and collaborate around technology is a great way to bring all the resources to bear.

RAMIREZ: According to NASA, the public private partnership created about 7,000 jobs at various times during the eight years it took to develop the rover. And, unlike in past decades of space exploration, in true social media fashion, you can follow the rover on Twitter at Marscuriosity. Ruben Ramirez, NBR, Washington.

HUDSON: The red planet to Wall Street and Main Street. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Monday, August 6. Thanks for joining us. We'll see you online at nbr.com and then back here tomorrow night.

END

urn:contentItem:518K-60N1-JBKP-N2VS-00000-00Nightly Business Report2010-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTSusan Wachter, Richard BernerBUSINESS101801cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib, Suzanne Pratt, Stephanie Dhue

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: The foreclosure paperwork nightmare -- is it a big deal for the nation`s banks?

ROBERT ALBERTSON, CHIEF STRATEGIST, SANDLER O`NEILL: I do not think this is an issue. I think it`s a creation, quite frankly, of the media to some extent and listening to people who don`t understand securitization.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: But other banking experts say it could be a $120 billion headache for the financial sector. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, October 18.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone. The financial sector was under the microscope today because of big earnings news and more worries about the foreclosure crisis. Tom, Bank of America came out saying it`s planning to end its moratorium on foreclosures in 23 states. But it`s still studying foreclosure paperwork in 27 other states.

HUDSON: Meantime Susie on the earnings front, it was Citi that reported better than expected quarterly results. Take a look at the results here with the bank earning $0.07 per share, a penny more than analyst estimates in the third quarter. This is Citi`s third straight quarterly profit.

GHARIB: Now bank stocks rallied on those results from Citi. Still, there are continuing concerns about the impact of the foreclosure crisis on banks and Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae. We have two reports tonight. We begin with Suzanne Pratt in New York.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Bank of America, Citi, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo. These are the banks with the biggest potential exposure to what`s now being called foreclosuregate. But just how much could faulty mortgage foreclosures cost the U.S. financial sector? On Wall Street, the range of estimates is staggering. JPMorgan`s own research staff says, worst case scenario, the price tag could reach a hefty $120 billion. That would cover the expense of buying back mortgages. Most banking experts however, are projecting losses closer to half that number, over a period of several years. S&P analyst Erik Oja puts the cost somewhere in between financial fiasco and minor blip.

ERIK OJA, EQUITY ANALYST, STANDARD & POOR`S: At this point I`m not sure if it`s a minor blip. I`m sure that as these banks go through their foreclosure pipeline, they will find instances of paperwork that needs to be redone.

PRATT: And Robert Albertson of Sandler O`Neill says speculating about the size of the losses is silly because the banks can handle it.

ROBERT ALBERTSON, CHIEF STRATEGIST, SANDLER O`NEILL: People fail to understand how much the banks have reserved in case things drag out. It is massive. It is something beyond what they got to even in the great depression. So, I do not think there`s a number we should worry about.

PRATT: But worry is exactly what bank stock investors have been doing. In the last month, as mortgage foreclosure practices have come under increased scrutiny, the KBW bank stock index has fallen about 6 percent. Still, some bank analysts say selling the shares now is probably a big mistake.

ALBERTSON: In my judgment, all other things being equal, it`s probably a reason to buy. People are overreaching for negatives and they`re imagining things that make no common sense at all.

PRATT: Analysts say one thing about this foreclosure mess is that it`s overshadowing an improving earnings picture. Not only are banks posting profits, but credit quality is getting better. Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

STEPHANIE DHUE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: This is Stephanie Dhue in Washington. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac own or guarantee nearly $200 billion worth of past due mortgages that could be foreclosed. Uncle Sam took control of the mortgage siblings in September 2008. Since then, taxpayers have given the companies $150 billion just to stay afloat. James Lockhart spent three years as the chief regulator of Fannie and Freddie, beginning at the height of the housing bubble. He thinks the foreclosure paperwork mess will cost taxpayers more.

JAMES LOCKHART, FORMER DIR., FEDERAL HOUSING FINANCE AGENCY: There is a foreclosure process. Different states have a different process. In many states it takes a very long time and in the meantime, Fannie and Freddie are not making any money, not getting any principal payment on the mortgage and as a result, effectively the taxpayer is giving a free loan to the homeowner.

DHUE: The average homeowner in default hasn`t made a payment in over a year. But it`s not just homeowners who may get a free ride. Investors in mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by Fannie and Freddie keep getting paid until a home is foreclosed and taken off the books. Karen Shaw Petrou says foreclosure delays put a further squeeze on the government-controlled firms.

KAREN SHAW PETROU, FEDERAL FINANCIAL ANALYTICS: In this Never Never land, Fannie and Freddie are paying the mortgage backed security investor, but they`re not getting any money in their hands with which to do it, so they`re in a real cash flow squeeze.

DHUE: That squeeze may not fall completely on taxpayers. Federal regulators are working to recoup $11 billion in losses by forcing banks to buy back mortgages that didn`t meet Fannie and Freddie underwriting standards. Known as putbacks in the industry, those sums could multiply as more shoddy paperwork is revealed. Lockhart says the issue may complicate the government`s ability to unwind Fannie and Freddie.

LOCKHART: To the extent we`re still fighting through this mortgage mess, it will be harder to get the will to fix Fannie and Freddie. There will be, unfortunately, a desire just to keep them sort of moving along without what we really need to do, is a resolution of their future and, more importantly, a resolution of the future in the mortgage market in this country.

DHUE: Many blame politics for helping get Fannie and Freddie into the mortgage mess in the first place and many think politics will make it just as difficult to get out. Stephanie Dhue, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: Here are the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. Those strong results from Citigroup helped Wall Street start the week with some modest gains. By the time the closing bell was heard, the Dow jumped 80 points, the NASDAQ added 11, the S&P 500 gained 8.5. Trading volume was light at the start of this week, with less than a billion shares changing hands on the big board, under two billion on the NASDAQ. Now stocks moved higher despite a pullback at the nation`s factories last month. The Federal Reserve reports industrial production fell 0.2 of a percent in September. Economists had expected a gain in output. And European Union finance ministers agreed in theory today to penalize member countries that overspend. They`re hoping to nip debt problems in the bud before they become full-blown crises. EU leaders are expected to adopt the new rules next week.

GHARIB: Still ahead on the program, with the housing industry still struggling and the jobs picture still bleak, we talk with Morgan Stanley`s chief economist Richard Berner about the outlook for the U.S. economy.

HUDSON: From ninja loans, those so-called no income, no job needed home mortgages written at the height of housing bubble, to today`s robo signing foreclosure document mess is something broke with the way the home mortgage system works in America? Susan Wachter is a professor of real estate at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and she joins us tonight from Philadelphia. Professor, welcome to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. Nice to see you.

SUSAN WACHTER, REAL ESTATE PROFESSOR, WHARTON: Pleasure to be here.

HUDSON: So is the U.S. home mortgage system broken today?

WACHTER: Yes, Tom it is broken. The foreclosure documentation crisis is just one more example of a system that is, in fact, broken.

HUDSON: One of the reasons why you say it`s broken and what exactly is broken is the loss of control that has happened in the mortgage market. Control by whom? Who lost control?

WACHTER: Underwriters, lenders, securitizers across the board. There is a lack of control and a partial lack of control reflects a lack of oversight as well by regulators.

HUDSON: Talk about that second point in terms of the lack of oversight, because it is usually seen as mortgages are regulated at the state level, that there is not a lot of Federal oversight. Ought there be?

WACHTER: Absolutely there needs to be. The systemic risk that is generated is not a state-by-state, although I`m not saying there shouldn`t be state oversight as well. It is clearly in this case and very well can be going forward nationwide, so there needs to be oversight by regulators that are able to see the entire markets, Federal regulators.

HUDSON: I want to ask you about how to rebuild confidence but do you think it ought to be part of the new consumer financial products commission where that kind of oversight lies?

WACHTER: That could very well be there, absolutely.

HUDSON: Let`s take a look at some of your ideas to rebuild the mortgage system. You first say keep securitization. This is the idea that banks can tell mortgages into the secondary market and allow them to be securitized with mortgage-backed securities. Why do you think it is important to keep this system in place?

WACHTER: Securitization is necessary and worked for decades. Without securitization we won`t have a long-term fixed-rate mortgage. Now is not the time to rely only on short-term adjust (ph) rate mortgages because that puts the homeowner, the borrower facing interest rate risks that they can`t really deal with. Interest rates eventually are likely to go up and we will have another crisis. So we need securitization, but we need a securitization system that is transparent and where there are controls and oversight.

HUDSON: You talk about more transparency as well as an idea to rebuild confidence in the mortgage system. Transparency how and provided by whom by the home buyer, by the lender?

WACHTER: By the lender and by the securitizer. Information needs to be available, provided for mortgages and for mortgage-backed securities by both lenders, originators and securitizers in ways that can be analyzed by investors and overseen by regulators.

HUDSON: What exactly would you like to see, more FICA scores or credit scores and the ability of a homeowner to pay the mortgage, talking about appraisals? What types of transparencies do you think would help?

WACHTER: That information, absolutely. But more actually, the key point is that the information needs to be standardized, so that the information can be compared across mortgages and can be tracked over time. And the transparency that would then allow, that would allow transparency for investors and regulators to monitor what is happening to the mortgage system -- monitoring which we completely failed in this crisis.

HUDSON: Do you think that more uniform standards, more transparency would ultimately increase the cost of securitization thus increase the cost of a mortgage?

WACHTER: Not necessarily. In fact, quite the reverse. With more transparency, the more information, the risks should be less.

HUDSON: Our guest this evening taking a look at the mortgage system in the United States as it has been in trouble here, Susan Wachter along with us. She`s a professor of real estate at the Wharton School.

Not exactly a jump higher, instead stocks really kind of drifting higher throughout the day with a full schedule of corporate earnings this week led by a couple of tech giants after the close tonight. Get you updated here. The first one of course, the big Apple (AAPL) turning in results for its first full quarter to include sales of its new iPad. This quarter also saw the release of its latest iPhone, each of those really driving results and here they are. Earnings easily beating estimates, they were up almost 70 percent from just one year ago. Iphone was one of the biggest contributors, with sales up 91 percent compared to a year ago. IPad sales totaling 4.2 million units. Of course, the iPad did not even exist last year at this time. IPod sales though, continued slowing-- down 11 percent year over year. Some analysts point to the iPad and iPod sales in the past quarter as a bit disappointing. Now Apple stock came into this report hitting new all-time highs, but sold off a brief trading halt in after hours. Apple stock in fact was down as much as 6.5 percent after hours, dropping below $300 per share, clearly one to watch tomorrow.

Big blue the other big tech out after the close, IBM (IBM) beating the Street. A fifth of its revenue came from emerging markets such as Brazil, Russia, India and China, the BRIC countries. Shares were at all- time highs for this report. They sold off 4 percent after the close. That came despite the company`s hiking guidance for the third time since July.

Taking the lead during the trading session were the big banks, repairing some of the losses last week from the foreclosure documentation problem. Here`s a trio led by Citigroup (C) leading the sector gainers, up more than 5 percent on huge volume. As we mentioned, its earnings were better than expected. Bank of America (BAC), the biggest gainer in the Dow Industrials, up 3 percent. B. of A. earnings one to watch, due out tomorrow morning. JPMorgan (JPM) the second best Dow component of the day, up almost 3 percent.

The energy sector also higher, but quarterly results from a couple of players really sapped their stocks. Halliburton (HAL) and McMoran Exploration (MMR) each fell after their earnings. Here`s Halliburton first of all. The stock falling from a six-month high despite beating the Street with a pick-up in drilling. Some analysts voiced concerns about high expectations for future earnings at Halliburton. McMoran Exploration meantime also fell from a six-month high after reporting a loss that was worse than expected. Energy production dropped and revenues fell at the company too, the stock off 13 percent.

While we`re talking about energy, in the utility space a multi- billion-dollar Monday buyout. The Massachusetts-based Northeast Utilities (NU) wants to buy Nstar (NST), based in Boston, for $4.3 billion in stock. This deal did not create many sparks for investors as you can see. Both Northeast and Nstar dropping about 1 percent. The purchase values Nstar at $40.28 a share. That is $1 above tonight`s closing price tonight. One other possible deal in energy, natural gas producer Quicksilver (KWK) jumped 17 percent. The firm`s ruling shareholder family is looking at alternatives, including taking it private possibly.

In medical devices meantime, St. Jude (STJ) looking to beef up its product pipeline, making a $1 billion play for AGA Medical (AGAM). It was a big volume gainer (ph), huge volume for AGA Medical on this 41 percent pop. The deal values AGA at $20.80 per share, clearly just a dime above tonight`s closing price. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Just two more weeks until the next meeting of the Federal Reserve and investors expect policymakers will announce a plan to pump more money into the financial system. Will that strategy give a boost to the economy? Joining us now, Morgan Stanley`s chief economist, Richard Berner. Hi Dick. Nice to you have back.

RICHARD BERNER, CHIEF U.S. ECONOMIST, MORGAN STANLEY: Nice to be with you.

GHARIB: So it looks like the Fed is going to go ahead to add more money into the financial system come November. Six to nine months after that, will we be saying that the strategy paid off?

BERNER: Well, I think we will, Susie, although the benefits to quantitative easing are probably going to be pretty limited. And that`s because the transmission mechanism and monetary policy is not functioning as well as it should be. In your earlier piece you heard Susan Wachter talk about our housing finance system that`s not functioning well. And that`s one of the key reasons that the benefits are likely to be limited. There is one channel, there is one channel through which policy could have a boost though and that is the global or international channel. As the dollar weakens in foreign exchange markets and perhaps as other central banks decide also to adopt a more accommodative policy, that could be a boost forth U.S. economy.

GHARIB: But going back to the Fed, are you saying that this strategy then will accomplish little and if so, what are the alternatives, to get the economy, U.S. economy growing again?

BERNER: Well, let`s look at what the Fed is facing. The Fed as you know has a dual mandate. They`re missing on both sides of that dual mandate. The unemployment rate is too high and inflation is a little too low. And from what we`ve seen in the marketplace, the Fed I think has accomplished a lot without really doing anything, just talking about quantitative easing. Because long-term rates have come down and in particular, rates adjusted for inflation or real rates have come down very significantly. And that should be a boost to the economy.

Second, the Fed has already also accomplished another of its goals which is to boost inflation expectations. And that is part of the process of raising inflation back to where they think it should be. So at least from those two points of view, they have already accomplished something. But I think that the headwinds that are out there in the economy mean that the benefits to the economy itself are probably going to be somewhat limited.

GHARIB: The key thing for most people the proof that they want to see is what happens to the unemployment rate and even the Fed is saying that that is priority number one to get people working again. Where do you see the unemployment rate in 2011?

BERNER: Well, by the end of 2011 Susie it is probably going to be half a point lower than where it is today and it could go up in the meantime.

GHARIB: That`s not much of a change. What about in terms of growth? Right now the economy is growing at less than 2 percent. Do you see any pickup there?

BERNER: We think that next year we`ll see about a 3 percent growth rate compared to two to two and a half percent in the second half of this year.

GHARIB: All right, so just for most of Americans and people who are watching this program, they`ve put through a lot of pain with this economic crisis over the last couple of years and they want to know when are things going to get back to normal if at all? When do you see that happening, if ever?

BERNER: Well, if ever is a long time. I think it will happen in the next few years. But it`s pretty clear that we have some longer-term issues out there to solve in our economy, some problems and monetary policy is only part of the solution. We have structural problems. They require structural solutions and monetary policy can only be a partial help.

GHARIB: All right. We`re going to have to leave it there. Unfortunately we`ve run out of time. Thank you so much for coming on the program this evening.

BERNER: Thanks, Susie.

GHARIB: We`ve been speaking with Richard Berner, chief economist at Morgan Stanley.

HUDSON: Here`s what we are watching for tomorrow. We will see September`s housing starts and building permits along with quarterly results due in from Bank of America as we mentioned, also Coca-Cola, Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson. Also tomorrow, our "Word on the Street" oil. It`s about 300 million years old, but the energy stocks you may want in your portfolio depend on how old you are.

GHARIB: If you can`t sell it, make it better. General Electric today said it will spend $432 million to update its appliance division. The focus on designing and building new energy-efficient refrigerators will add 500 jobs at new plants in Kentucky, Indiana, Alabama and Tennessee. GE spent much of 2008 trying to sell its appliance unit and since has invested nearly $1 billion on upgrades.

HUDSON: Cablevision subscribers in the New York City area and Philadelphia still cannot watch Fox programs. Cablevision and Fox parent News Corp are back at the negotiating table. Fox programming has been blocked out on Cablevision for three days so far. Cablevision says it pays $70 million a year for Fox programming and News Corp now wants $150 million. Cablevision customers have already missed playoff baseball and yesterday`s New York Giants game.

GHARIB: With the mid-term elections over two weeks away, tonight`s commentator believes there are really just two issues facing voters. Here`s Glenn Hubbard, dean of Columbia`s graduate school of business and former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President George W. Bush.

GLENN HUBBARD, DEAN, COLUMBIA GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: To listen to the tax debate in Washington, the nation is having a tug of war over whose taxes should rise to cover the Federal government`s large budget deficits. President Obama argues that raising taxes only on individuals earning over $250,000 per year will return us to fiscal health. That is simply not true, given the large current and future deficits. Many Republicans argue against raising taxes on anyone. But what spending reductions would they recommend to stop the spiraling public debt burden?

Memo to Washington: we`re actually all in this together. The real questions are how big do we want government to be? And how can we pay for it with the least cost to economic growth and job creation? Keeping the government we now have will require major tax increases on all Americans. The budget holes of 5 percent of GDP in the near term, growing to twice that in the long term, cannot be fixed by raising taxes only on high-income families. Alternatively, we can reduce the growth of entitlement spending, while keeping a strong safety net. So what do we do now? We should extend the current tax code through 2012. Such a move will provide support to the struggling recovery and reduce uncertainty holding back business and household decisions. And the 2012 elections permit the tough conversation about those real questions. We all have a stake in the outcome. I`m Glenn Hubbard.

HUDSON: That`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Monday evening, October 18. Thanks for joining us. I`m Tom Hudson. Have a great night, you too, Susie.

GHARIB: Tom you have a great night too. I`m Susie Gharib. Good night everyone and we hope to see all of you again tomorrow night.
