PAUL KANGAS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From rumor to reality -- one of the hottest private equity firms will be private no more. The Blackstone Group will take up residence here at the New York Stock Exchange. We`ll detail its $4 billion initial public offering.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Senate Banking Chairman Christopher Dodd scolded bank regulators today, saying they didn`t do enough to stop predatory lending in the sub-prime market. Dodd also put lenders on notice, saying they too are to blame for the sub-prime mess.

KANGAS: From sub-prime loans to sluggish sales and falling home prices, we go region by region for a look at the state of the American housing market.

PRATT: Then, Oracle is taking on one of its biggest rivals in court. We`ll tell you who the software giant is suing and why.

KANGAS: I`m Paul Kangas.

PRATT: And I`m Suzanne Pratt. Susie Gharib is off tonight. This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, May (sic) 22.

KANGAS: Good evening, everyone. One of the world`s largest private equity funds is going public. Late today, Blackstone Group announced a $4.4 or $4 billion initial public offering. The move lets investors buy into a risky business that has traditionally been the ground of wealthy individuals and large institutions. Blackstone generated more than $7.5 billion in investment gains in 2006. The company`s assets under management are worth almost $79 billion. Its portfolio includes real estate giant Equity Office Properties, Extended Stay America Hotels, publisher Houghton Mifflin and entertainment park Universal Orlando. Blackstone will trade on the New York Stock Exchange. But there`s no IPO date or ticker symbol specified in today`s filing with the SEC. But the company did say it won`t give quarterly guidance to Wall Street because its business is quote, unpredictable.

PRATT: The meltdown in the sub-prime lending market reached Capitol Hill today. The Senate Banking Committee called regulators, lenders and borrowers to learn more about the causes behind the sub-prime crisis. But as Stephanie Dhue reports, the committee quickly got down to the business of laying blame.

STEPHANIE DHUE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: With an increasing number of homeowners facing foreclosure, lawmakers, including New Jersey Senator Robert Menendez, accused the Federal Reserve of being asleep at the switch.

SEN. ROBERT MENENDEZ (D) NEW JERSEY: How could it be this big and you have done your job?

ROGER COLE, DIR., BANKING SUPERVISION & REGULATION, FEDERAL RESERVE: Given what we know now, yes, we could have done more sooner.

DHUE: Regulators say much of the sub-prime market falls outside their jurisdiction, which deals mostly with ensuring that banks are financially sound. But Senate Banking Committee Chairman Chris Dodd wasn`t buying that argument.

SEN. CHRIS DODD, CHAIRMAN, BANKING COMMITTEE: The Fed had the responsibility in my view, as a good cop, to be on the beat, particularly going back several years ago, when the information first began to surface that there were serious problems with these sub-prime loans.

DHUE: Dodd called on the regulators to quickly finalize tighter sub- prime lending standards. But lenders warn some borrowers will be shut out of the market. Countrywide Financial says it would lose 60 percent of its sub-prime business under the proposed tighter standards. Still, the company`s managing director, Sandor Samuels, says that`s not his key concern.

SANDOR SAMUELS, MANAGING DIRECTOR, COUNTRYWIDE FINANCIAL: The concern that we have is the impact on the housing market and the impact on borrowers who are in the sub-prime market. And so we hope the regulations can find a balance that will allow consumers to benefit from lower housing payments, while protecting them from unaffordable payment increases.

DHUE: The committee also heard from borrowers now at risk of losing their homes. Jennie Haliburton got an adjustable 2/28 sub-prime loan from Countrywide last year. Her payment is set to adjust in May to more than 70 percent of her income.

JENNIE HALIBURTON, BORROWER: I feel like they took advantage of me because I`m 77 and they figure, "oh, well, she`s old."

DHUE: Countrywide says it will work with Mrs. Haliburton to keep her in her home. Senator Dodd says there are thousands of sub-prime borrowers struggling with their mortgages and he wants to find ways to help them. Stephanie Dhue, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

PRATT: KB Home`s quarterly earnings plummeted 84 percent, as home prices dropped, inventories swelled and the sub-prime mortgage market began to implode. KB Home earned $0.34 a share in its fiscal first quarter. That`s down sharply from the year-ago period, but $0.09 ahead of analyst estimates. Sales fell 19 percent to $1 3/4 billion, but that was still ahead of estimates. KB Home`s CEO says housing conditions remain difficult, making it even harder to predict when the market will stabilize. The company also says 13 percent of the mortgages for KB Homes last year were financed with sub-prime loans.

KANGAS: Wall Street felt the sting of profit taking this morning after yesterday`s sharp rally. Selling was also linked to Motorola`s forecast of a first quarter loss and a rise in oil prices. By 11 a.m., the Dow was off 30 points, NASDAQ down 12. The blue chips improved this afternoon with the help of a brokerage upgrade on Procter & Gamble and some strong oil stocks, but the broader market ended lower. The Dow Industrial Average closed up 13.62 at 12,461.14. NASDAQ Composite lost 4.18, ending at 2451.74. Standard & Poor`s 500 Index fell exactly a half point to 1434.54. Over in the bond market, the 10-year note fell 12/32 to par and 10/32, lifting the yield to 4.59 percent.

PRATT: This week in our special housing series, we looked at market conditions in three U.S. cities: New York, Washington, DC and Miami. Tonight, we continue that series with a broader discussion of the national housing market. Our guest this evening is Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody`s economy.com. Mark, welcome.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY`S ECONOMY.COM: Thanks for having me.

PRATT: So what is the current state of the U.S. housing market?

ZANDI: It`s struggling. The correction which began almost two years ago is ongoing. Since the peak, we have seen sales off about 10, 15 percent. Starts are done by a third. And prices are now falling in about half to two-thirds of the nation`s market.

PRATT: So this is a correction, though, not a meltdown?

ZANDI: I would characterize it as a correction. It is a severe correction. But at this point we`re not seeing double digit price declines. And the market is still holding together reasonably well so not a crash, at least not yet.

PRATT: So tell me about the weakest areas of the country. What are some of those?

ZANDI: Well, they would include California, primarily southern California. San Diego would be a good case in point. Arizona, Phoenix, Las Vegas, most of Florida, particularly south of Florida and parts of the northeast, Washington DC, the Boston region and of course the areas around Detroit are very weak because of job losses in the auto industry.

PRATT: And what about the strongest regions of the country, what are those?

ZANDI: Well, there are fewer but Texas would be a relatively strong housing market, some of the areas around the Carolinas, the farm belt and the pas civic northwest. In fact house prices in the Pacific northwest are still rising at a double-digit pace.

PRATT: So is it typical for a correction like this to be so uneven?

ZANDI: It is. The house market is a very local market. It really depends on where you are. Although I have to say this is the broadest the housing market correction that I think we`ve experienced at least since the great depression.

PRATT: So if it is so broad though is that, or does that have ominous predictions or does that mean that we should be more concerned?

ZANDI: Well, we should be concerned. The soft part of the economy lies in the housing and now of course in the mortgage market. Housing is weighing heavily on the economy. So far the problems in housing have been largely contained to housing. They haven`t bled out to consumer spending and business investment. But given the problems and the fact that they are ongoing, we need to watch that very carefully.

PRATT: So let`s talk a little bit about the sub-prime part of the market. I mean what does that mean? What is that likely to do to the overall housing market? Could it take it into a meltdown?

ZANDI: Well, it is a significant problem. If you consider all of the very aggressive loans that have been extended in recent years, that would include sub-prime, alternative A, prime loans that are interest only or negative am loans -- these are very aggressive loans. You combine all those and these are ones at a significant risk of default. They account for 40 percent of origination volume last year and roughly one quarter of all mortgage debt outstanding. So this a significant market that is going to be significantly affected. As a result, we will see some measurable impact on housing activity and probably as a result on the broader economy.

PRATT: One thing I want to make sure that we cover is the Fed and their statement yesterday. They sort of removed the bias, depending on who you ask. You think that that was because or directly because of the housing market.

ZANDI: Yeah, I think they did -- they did get rid of their bias towards future higher interest rates. They now have a neutral policy and I think they did that to have some latitude just in case if the housing market goes south and the mortgage market weakens, that they could ease if they needed to. At this point I don`t think they want to. Inflation is above their target. They would prefer not to, but they needed a little bit of flexibility and they got that in yesterday`s statement.

PRATT: OK, great. My guest this evening, Mark Zandi, chief economist at moodyseconomy.com, thanks for joining us.

ZANDI: Thank you.

KANGAS: Business software maker Oracle sued German rival SAP today, claiming SAP committed quote, corporate theft on a grand scale end quote. Oracle says SAP illegally logged on to its password-protected customer web sites many times, stealing huge amounts of software code, documents and other confidential material. Oracle claims it knows SAP excuse me, was the culprit because Oracle traced the log-ons back to an SAP-owned subsidiary in Texas. SAP said it had no comment on the lawsuit. Oracle wants a California court to assess damages, force SAP to return the stolen items and bar SAP from logging on to Oracle`s web sites.

Crude oil surged more than 2 percent today, jumping $2.08 to $61.69 a barrel. The rally was fueled by expectations energy demand will start to surge as we head into the summer driving season. And as Erika Miller explains, experts expect oil prices to spurt even higher.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Spring is supposed to be the time of year when energy prices dip due to weak demand. Instead, the opposite is happening. Analyst Fadel Gheit blames an across- the-board rally in energy prices on strong demand for gasoline.

FADEL GHEIT, ENERGY ANALYST, OPPENHEIMER & CO.: Right now, gasoline prices are leading the energy markets in the U.S. But it doesn`t mean that oil prices are, you know, pulling back. Oil prices have shown tremendous resiliency that nobody had expected.

MILLER: Gasoline futures have surged over 20 percent since January. They`re now at a seven-month high. The rally is due in large part to fears of a supply crunch heading into the summer driving season. In the U.S., there has been an almost insatiable demand for motor fuel, despite higher prices at the pump. At the same time, supplies are dwindling. Energy trader Ira Eckstein blames that on glitches and seasonal maintenance at refineries.

IRA ECKSTEIN, OIL TRADER, AREA INTERNATIONAL TRADING: We have these outages, plus they are doing their usual spring -- they`re going from heating oil to gasoline, so they had to close down some refineries in order to switch over.

MILLER: There are also concerns about disruptions to crude supplies due to geopolitical tensions in places like Iran, Nigeria, and Saudi Arabia. Another big unknown is weather. Hurricane season starts June 1, raising the risk of damage to U.S. oil infrastructure. In the near term, many traders expect oil prices to inch higher. The question is, how much?

ECKSTEIN: Crude oil is going to test that $62.50 level -- maybe not this week, but maybe early next week and I think that we could stay above there. We`ll see how we react when we get there.

MILLER: That`s bad news for motorists. In some places, including New York City, regular unleaded is approaching $3 a gallon. But few experts think we`ll head back to record levels just yet. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York

PRATT: Transatlantic air travel took a leap into the future today, as the European Union`s transport ministers approved plans to open the skies to more competition. The so-called open skies deal lets EU carriers fly from any city in the block to any city in the U.S. and vice versa. The Bush administration welcomed the decision, saying it will spur growth and give Americans more flying freedom. The plan had been set to take effect in October, but all sides agreed on a five-month delay. The new start date is March 30, 2008, Paul.

KANGAS: Suzanne, shares of the major air carriers hit some turbulence today on concerns that pact could trigger a price war. We`ll look at how they did as we take a look at our stocks in the news tonight.

Big board volume leader on nearly 51 million shares, Motorola (MOT) down $1.24. After the close yesterday as we reported, the company predicted a $0.07 to $0.09 per share first quarter loss.

Then Pfizer (PFE) down $0.06.

General Electric (GE) moved up $0.33. The company is teaming up with News Corporation to launch an online video site to compete with youtube. The details coming up shortly.

Ford Motor Co (F) was up $0.07.

CVS Caremark (CVS), this is the first day of trading for the new merger company of CVS Caremark, down $0.36 a share, fifth in volume.

AT&T (T) rose $0.25.

Alcatel-Lucent (ALU) down a half a dollar. Goldman Sachs downgraded it from "buy" to "neutral" because it sees no sales recovery for the firm before the third quarter of this year.

ExxonMobil (XOM) up $1.13 on that sharp rise in oil.

Chesapeake Energy (CHK) down $0.15.

And Time Warner (TWX), tenth in volume, was off $0.28.

Procter Gamble (PG) moved up $0.89. Bear Stearns upgraded it from "peer perform" to "out perform" because of its attractive valuation in the price of the stock, according to Bear Stearns.

And then AMR (AMR) parent of American Airlines, down $1.54, not only today because of the sharp rise in oil, but airfares are expected to tumble next spring when the open skies package you just heard about goes into effect.

Let`s have a look at some other major carriers. Continental Air (CAL) down $1.60.

And UAL Corp (UAUA) losing $1.77.

Raytheon Co (RTN) off $1.41. The company boosted its annual dividend 6 percent from $0.96 to $1.02, but nevertheless, Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock from "neutral" to a "sell."

Conagra Foods (CAG), the big packaged foods company down $0.02 despite a turnaround. Third quarter earnings of $0.38 versus a loss last year. Those earnings $0.03 above the Street estimate.

Another packaged foods company, General Mills (GIS) moving up $0.44. Third quarter earnings there were up nearly 9 percent to $0.74, $0.04 above the Street estimate and the company boosted its 2007 earnings guidance.

Nortel Networks (NT) fell $1.53. The company launched a $1 billion offering of convertible debt, which of course has potential earnings dilution.

Then we see Barnes & Noble (BKS), the book seller, down $1.10. The company says preliminary fourth quarter earnings will be $1.84, up from $1.76 last year, but $0.04 below the Wall Street estimate.

IHS (IHS), a $3.90 gain. The aerospace defense contractor had nicely higher first quarter earnings, $0.32 versus $0.24 last year and revenues up 18 percent.

Clarcor (CLC) which is a big filtration company off $2.87. Third quarter earnings $0.32, a penny above last year, but $0.04 below the Street estimate. Sales actually fell 1.7 percent.

Google (GOOG) topped the active list on NASDAQ gaining $5.49.

Apple (AAPL) a $0.09 rise.

Microsoft (MSFT) down $0.25.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) a $0.42 loss.

Intel (INTC) dropped $0.18 a share, fifth in dollar volume.

Research in Motion (RIMM) up $1.64.

Then Oracle (ORCL) a $0.32 gain there.

Palm (PALM) closed down $1.71. Speculation appears to be cooling that it might be the target of a takeover attempt. After the close, Palm reported third quarter earnings excluding items, $0.16 a share, $0.04 above the Street estimate. In after hours trading, the stock was about $0.20 higher than this.

Broadcom (BRCM) down $1.29, hurt by Motorola`s earnings warning.

And then Qualcomm (QCOM) tenth in volume was off $0.38 a share.

Intuit (INTU) down $2.46. The company says its Turbotax software sales are off to a slow start this tax season so far.

Those are the stocks in the news tonight. Suzanne.

PRATT: The SEC and the American Stock Exchange today settled their differences over problems with the exchange`s oversight of options trading. Regulators allege, from 1999 through June 2004, the Amex didn`t adequately enforce certain order-handling rules and comply with record-keeping guidelines. The settlement creates a $3 million fund to help pay for stepped up exchange surveillance. Still in the works, though, EC action against the Amex`s former Chairman Salvatore Sodano.

KANGAS: Tomorrow, our Friday "market monitor" guest is Jeffrey Everett, chief investment officer at Templeton Global Advisors.

PRATT: A Federal judge in Mississippi has turned down a request to allow a class-action suit against State Farm insurance for denial of damage claims from hurricane Katrina. At issue so-called slab cases where houses were destroyed down to the slab. The judge said while all the homes were ruined, there are other factors that make the cases unsuitable for class action.

KANGAS: Coca-Cola is rolling out a new version of its diet Coke drink, adding vitamins and minerals to the mix. The new diet Coke plus will contain small mounts of vitamins B-3, B-6 and B-12, as well as magnesium and zinc. But the recipe for the soda itself will be unchanged. Coke says the new soft drink should hit U.S. store shelves next month.

PRATT: Here`s a look at what`s happening tomorrow. February existing home sales come out, along with earnings from Freddie Mac.

Tonight`s commentator has a few thoughts on what the Blackstone Group`s $4 billion IPO could mean to Wall Street. Here`s Chrystia Freeland, U.S. managing editor of "The Financial Times."

CHRYSTIA FREELAND, US MANAGING EDITOR, FINANCIAL TIMES: The irony of the move is irresistible. After all, the private equity business is based on the idea that a lot of companies can be run more effectively if they are liberated from the short-term targets and regulatory red tape that bedevils the public market. But there are some powerful reasons for Blackstone to be tempted to go public. The greatest may be the simplest. Blackstone`s founders are surely keen in Wall Street`s uncharacteristically coy terminology to crystallize the value of their partnership.

In plainer language, that means they want to take their billions before they retire. In contrast with those pitied Goldman Sachs senior partners who left the legendary firm before its IPO and missed out on the windfall their younger colleagues collected. For those of us not in line to receive Blackstone`s billions, the greatest significance of an IPO would be to make the private equity revolution more sustainable. Private equity has become so powerful it is easy to forget that the dominant groups are just a few decades old, are still run by the men who founded them and are dependent on Internet and fund-raising (INAUDIBLE) for most of their capital. Going public would give them access to permanent money and thus make them a more permanent fixture in world business. And that is the real irony of the story. Public capital could well give private equity groups a more enduring power to take companies private. I`m Chrystia Freeland.

KANGAS: Recapping today`s market action, a split decision on Wall Street. The Dow gained 13 points while the NASDAQ Composite lost four points. To learn more about the stories in tonight`s broadcast, go to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on pbs.org. You can also e-mail us at nbr@pbs.org

PRATT: And finally tonight, what does it take to get two bitter rivals together? And what does it take to make tax time less taxing? Scott Gurvey has those answers and more in tonight`s "tech talk."

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Tonight`s big tech news is a partnership of two very unlikely bedfellows: NBC Universal and Newscorp, parent of the Fox network. Who could get these guys together? Try youtube, the popular video-sharing web site now owned by Google. Youtube members make and post videos, often using original material, but just as often using content recorded from TV and cable, raising copyright concerns. A competing site run by NBC and Newscorp would have lots of content it could legally distribute. Yahoo!, MSN, AOL and Newscorp`s myspace will be involved. Stay tuned.

All of these sites make money by selling ads. The more popular the site, the more it can sell, and it adds up! Cisco Systems, Intel and General Motors have already signed up to advertise on the new NBC-Newscorp site. There are big bucks involved. Google paid $1.6 billion to buy youtube and recently, Viacom sued youtube for $1 billion, charging it with copyright infringement. Youtube has yet to file a response. The digital millennium copyright act of 1998 was supposed to clarify copyright law in the Internet age. It appears there is more work to be done.

It is tax time and the IRS says more than 130 million returns will be filed this year. Thirty five million will be made with tax preparation software. I`ve tried the leading products and, while they all do a good job, once again I`ve found Intuit`s Turbotax to be the most comprehensive and easiest to use. It does tend to cost $10 to $15 more than H&R Block`s tax cut. This year, Intuit added a home and business version, perfect if you file a Schedule C or need to generate W-2s for business or household employees. The tax software companies report their fastest growth is among taxpayers who enter all their data online, a process Intuit`s Bob Meighan says is simple and safe.

BOB MEIGHAN, VICE PRESIDENT, INTUIT: People don`t have to go to the store and buy the software. They don`t have to install it. They don`t have to worry about updates. I can go to the web and access tax software to do my return, so it`s convenient. All the products I know about use secure connections. If you`re transmitting your return to the IRS, it`s via secure connection, so the data is secure. All the companies that I know about guard your information very, very well, because we want to protect your privacy.

GURVEY: Even with the tax software, I haven`t sent in my return yet. How about you? Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

PRATT: That`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, March 22. I`m Suzanne Pratt. Good night everyone and good night to you, Paul.

KANGAS: Good night, Suzanne. I`m Paul Kangas, wishing all of you the best of good buys.

END

urn:contentItem:5KR6-6GF1-JBHT-D351-00000-00Nightly Business Report2007-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportLanhamFULL TEXT

PAUL KANGAS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From rumor to reality -- one of the hottest private equity firms will be private no more. The Blackstone Group will take up residence here at the New York Stock Exchange. We`ll detail its $4 billion initial public offering.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Senate Banking Chairman Christopher Dodd scolded bank regulators today, saying they didn`t do enough to stop predatory lending in the sub-prime market. Dodd also put lenders on notice, saying they too are to blame for the sub-prime mess.

KANGAS: From sub-prime loans to sluggish sales and falling home prices, we go region by region for a look at the state of the American housing market.

PRATT: Then, Oracle is taking on one of its biggest rivals in court. We`ll tell you who the software giant is suing and why.

KANGAS: I`m Paul Kangas.

PRATT: And I`m Suzanne Pratt. Susie Gharib is off tonight. This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, May (sic) 22.

KANGAS: Good evening, everyone. One of the world`s largest private equity funds is going public. Late today, Blackstone Group announced a $4.4 or $4 billion initial public offering. The move lets investors buy into a risky business that has traditionally been the ground of wealthy individuals and large institutions. Blackstone generated more than $7.5 billion in investment gains in 2006. The company`s assets under management are worth almost $79 billion. Its portfolio includes real estate giant Equity Office Properties, Extended Stay America Hotels, publisher Houghton Mifflin and entertainment park Universal Orlando. Blackstone will trade on the New York Stock Exchange. But there`s no IPO date or ticker symbol specified in today`s filing with the SEC. But the company did say it won`t give quarterly guidance to Wall Street because its business is quote, unpredictable.

PRATT: The meltdown in the sub-prime lending market reached Capitol Hill today. The Senate Banking Committee called regulators, lenders and borrowers to learn more about the causes behind the sub-prime crisis. But as Stephanie Dhue reports, the committee quickly got down to the business of laying blame.

STEPHANIE DHUE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: With an increasing number of homeowners facing foreclosure, lawmakers, including New Jersey Senator Robert Menendez, accused the Federal Reserve of being asleep at the switch.

SEN. ROBERT MENENDEZ (D) NEW JERSEY: How could it be this big and you have done your job?

ROGER COLE, DIR., BANKING SUPERVISION & REGULATION, FEDERAL RESERVE: Given what we know now, yes, we could have done more sooner.

DHUE: Regulators say much of the sub-prime market falls outside their jurisdiction, which deals mostly with ensuring that banks are financially sound. But Senate Banking Committee Chairman Chris Dodd wasn`t buying that argument.

SEN. CHRIS DODD, CHAIRMAN, BANKING COMMITTEE: The Fed had the responsibility in my view, as a good cop, to be on the beat, particularly going back several years ago, when the information first began to surface that there were serious problems with these sub-prime loans.

DHUE: Dodd called on the regulators to quickly finalize tighter sub- prime lending standards. But lenders warn some borrowers will be shut out of the market. Countrywide Financial says it would lose 60 percent of its sub-prime business under the proposed tighter standards. Still, the company`s managing director, Sandor Samuels, says that`s not his key concern.

SANDOR SAMUELS, MANAGING DIRECTOR, COUNTRYWIDE FINANCIAL: The concern that we have is the impact on the housing market and the impact on borrowers who are in the sub-prime market. And so we hope the regulations can find a balance that will allow consumers to benefit from lower housing payments, while protecting them from unaffordable payment increases.

DHUE: The committee also heard from borrowers now at risk of losing their homes. Jennie Haliburton got an adjustable 2/28 sub-prime loan from Countrywide last year. Her payment is set to adjust in May to more than 70 percent of her income.

JENNIE HALIBURTON, BORROWER: I feel like they took advantage of me because I`m 77 and they figure, "oh, well, she`s old."

DHUE: Countrywide says it will work with Mrs. Haliburton to keep her in her home. Senator Dodd says there are thousands of sub-prime borrowers struggling with their mortgages and he wants to find ways to help them. Stephanie Dhue, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

PRATT: KB Home`s quarterly earnings plummeted 84 percent, as home prices dropped, inventories swelled and the sub-prime mortgage market began to implode. KB Home earned $0.34 a share in its fiscal first quarter. That`s down sharply from the year-ago period, but $0.09 ahead of analyst estimates. Sales fell 19 percent to $1 3/4 billion, but that was still ahead of estimates. KB Home`s CEO says housing conditions remain difficult, making it even harder to predict when the market will stabilize. The company also says 13 percent of the mortgages for KB Homes last year were financed with sub-prime loans.

KANGAS: Wall Street felt the sting of profit taking this morning after yesterday`s sharp rally. Selling was also linked to Motorola`s forecast of a first quarter loss and a rise in oil prices. By 11 a.m., the Dow was off 30 points, NASDAQ down 12. The blue chips improved this afternoon with the help of a brokerage upgrade on Procter & Gamble and some strong oil stocks, but the broader market ended lower. The Dow Industrial Average closed up 13.62 at 12,461.14. NASDAQ Composite lost 4.18, ending at 2451.74. Standard & Poor`s 500 Index fell exactly a half point to 1434.54. Over in the bond market, the 10-year note fell 12/32 to par and 10/32, lifting the yield to 4.59 percent.

PRATT: This week in our special housing series, we looked at market conditions in three U.S. cities: New York, Washington, DC and Miami. Tonight, we continue that series with a broader discussion of the national housing market. Our guest this evening is Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody`s economy.com. Mark, welcome.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY`S ECONOMY.COM: Thanks for having me.

PRATT: So what is the current state of the U.S. housing market?

ZANDI: It`s struggling. The correction which began almost two years ago is ongoing. Since the peak, we have seen sales off about 10, 15 percent. Starts are done by a third. And prices are now falling in about half to two-thirds of the nation`s market.

PRATT: So this is a correction, though, not a meltdown?

ZANDI: I would characterize it as a correction. It is a severe correction. But at this point we`re not seeing double digit price declines. And the market is still holding together reasonably well so not a crash, at least not yet.

PRATT: So tell me about the weakest areas of the country. What are some of those?

ZANDI: Well, they would include California, primarily southern California. San Diego would be a good case in point. Arizona, Phoenix, Las Vegas, most of Florida, particularly south of Florida and parts of the northeast, Washington DC, the Boston region and of course the areas around Detroit are very weak because of job losses in the auto industry.

PRATT: And what about the strongest regions of the country, what are those?

ZANDI: Well, there are fewer but Texas would be a relatively strong housing market, some of the areas around the Carolinas, the farm belt and the pas civic northwest. In fact house prices in the Pacific northwest are still rising at a double-digit pace.

PRATT: So is it typical for a correction like this to be so uneven?

ZANDI: It is. The house market is a very local market. It really depends on where you are. Although I have to say this is the broadest the housing market correction that I think we`ve experienced at least since the great depression.

PRATT: So if it is so broad though is that, or does that have ominous predictions or does that mean that we should be more concerned?

ZANDI: Well, we should be concerned. The soft part of the economy lies in the housing and now of course in the mortgage market. Housing is weighing heavily on the economy. So far the problems in housing have been largely contained to housing. They haven`t bled out to consumer spending and business investment. But given the problems and the fact that they are ongoing, we need to watch that very carefully.

PRATT: So let`s talk a little bit about the sub-prime part of the market. I mean what does that mean? What is that likely to do to the overall housing market? Could it take it into a meltdown?

ZANDI: Well, it is a significant problem. If you consider all of the very aggressive loans that have been extended in recent years, that would include sub-prime, alternative A, prime loans that are interest only or negative am loans -- these are very aggressive loans. You combine all those and these are ones at a significant risk of default. They account for 40 percent of origination volume last year and roughly one quarter of all mortgage debt outstanding. So this a significant market that is going to be significantly affected. As a result, we will see some measurable impact on housing activity and probably as a result on the broader economy.

PRATT: One thing I want to make sure that we cover is the Fed and their statement yesterday. They sort of removed the bias, depending on who you ask. You think that that was because or directly because of the housing market.

ZANDI: Yeah, I think they did -- they did get rid of their bias towards future higher interest rates. They now have a neutral policy and I think they did that to have some latitude just in case if the housing market goes south and the mortgage market weakens, that they could ease if they needed to. At this point I don`t think they want to. Inflation is above their target. They would prefer not to, but they needed a little bit of flexibility and they got that in yesterday`s statement.

PRATT: OK, great. My guest this evening, Mark Zandi, chief economist at moodyseconomy.com, thanks for joining us.

ZANDI: Thank you.

KANGAS: Business software maker Oracle sued German rival SAP today, claiming SAP committed quote, corporate theft on a grand scale end quote. Oracle says SAP illegally logged on to its password-protected customer web sites many times, stealing huge amounts of software code, documents and other confidential material. Oracle claims it knows SAP excuse me, was the culprit because Oracle traced the log-ons back to an SAP-owned subsidiary in Texas. SAP said it had no comment on the lawsuit. Oracle wants a California court to assess damages, force SAP to return the stolen items and bar SAP from logging on to Oracle`s web sites.

Crude oil surged more than 2 percent today, jumping $2.08 to $61.69 a barrel. The rally was fueled by expectations energy demand will start to surge as we head into the summer driving season. And as Erika Miller explains, experts expect oil prices to spurt even higher.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Spring is supposed to be the time of year when energy prices dip due to weak demand. Instead, the opposite is happening. Analyst Fadel Gheit blames an across- the-board rally in energy prices on strong demand for gasoline.

FADEL GHEIT, ENERGY ANALYST, OPPENHEIMER & CO.: Right now, gasoline prices are leading the energy markets in the U.S. But it doesn`t mean that oil prices are, you know, pulling back. Oil prices have shown tremendous resiliency that nobody had expected.

MILLER: Gasoline futures have surged over 20 percent since January. They`re now at a seven-month high. The rally is due in large part to fears of a supply crunch heading into the summer driving season. In the U.S., there has been an almost insatiable demand for motor fuel, despite higher prices at the pump. At the same time, supplies are dwindling. Energy trader Ira Eckstein blames that on glitches and seasonal maintenance at refineries.

IRA ECKSTEIN, OIL TRADER, AREA INTERNATIONAL TRADING: We have these outages, plus they are doing their usual spring -- they`re going from heating oil to gasoline, so they had to close down some refineries in order to switch over.

MILLER: There are also concerns about disruptions to crude supplies due to geopolitical tensions in places like Iran, Nigeria, and Saudi Arabia. Another big unknown is weather. Hurricane season starts June 1, raising the risk of damage to U.S. oil infrastructure. In the near term, many traders expect oil prices to inch higher. The question is, how much?

ECKSTEIN: Crude oil is going to test that $62.50 level -- maybe not this week, but maybe early next week and I think that we could stay above there. We`ll see how we react when we get there.

MILLER: That`s bad news for motorists. In some places, including New York City, regular unleaded is approaching $3 a gallon. But few experts think we`ll head back to record levels just yet. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York

PRATT: Transatlantic air travel took a leap into the future today, as the European Union`s transport ministers approved plans to open the skies to more competition. The so-called open skies deal lets EU carriers fly from any city in the block to any city in the U.S. and vice versa. The Bush administration welcomed the decision, saying it will spur growth and give Americans more flying freedom. The plan had been set to take effect in October, but all sides agreed on a five-month delay. The new start date is March 30, 2008, Paul.

KANGAS: Suzanne, shares of the major air carriers hit some turbulence today on concerns that pact could trigger a price war. We`ll look at how they did as we take a look at our stocks in the news tonight.

Big board volume leader on nearly 51 million shares, Motorola (MOT) down $1.24. After the close yesterday as we reported, the company predicted a $0.07 to $0.09 per share first quarter loss.

Then Pfizer (PFE) down $0.06.

General Electric (GE) moved up $0.33. The company is teaming up with News Corporation to launch an online video site to compete with youtube. The details coming up shortly.

Ford Motor Co (F) was up $0.07.

CVS Caremark (CVS), this is the first day of trading for the new merger company of CVS Caremark, down $0.36 a share, fifth in volume.

AT&T (T) rose $0.25.

Alcatel-Lucent (ALU) down a half a dollar. Goldman Sachs downgraded it from "buy" to "neutral" because it sees no sales recovery for the firm before the third quarter of this year.

ExxonMobil (XOM) up $1.13 on that sharp rise in oil.

Chesapeake Energy (CHK) down $0.15.

And Time Warner (TWX), tenth in volume, was off $0.28.

Procter Gamble (PG) moved up $0.89. Bear Stearns upgraded it from "peer perform" to "out perform" because of its attractive valuation in the price of the stock, according to Bear Stearns.

And then AMR (AMR) parent of American Airlines, down $1.54, not only today because of the sharp rise in oil, but airfares are expected to tumble next spring when the open skies package you just heard about goes into effect.

Let`s have a look at some other major carriers. Continental Air (CAL) down $1.60.

And UAL Corp (UAUA) losing $1.77.

Raytheon Co (RTN) off $1.41. The company boosted its annual dividend 6 percent from $0.96 to $1.02, but nevertheless, Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock from "neutral" to a "sell."

Conagra Foods (CAG), the big packaged foods company down $0.02 despite a turnaround. Third quarter earnings of $0.38 versus a loss last year. Those earnings $0.03 above the Street estimate.

Another packaged foods company, General Mills (GIS) moving up $0.44. Third quarter earnings there were up nearly 9 percent to $0.74, $0.04 above the Street estimate and the company boosted its 2007 earnings guidance.

Nortel Networks (NT) fell $1.53. The company launched a $1 billion offering of convertible debt, which of course has potential earnings dilution.

Then we see Barnes & Noble (BKS), the book seller, down $1.10. The company says preliminary fourth quarter earnings will be $1.84, up from $1.76 last year, but $0.04 below the Wall Street estimate.

IHS (IHS), a $3.90 gain. The aerospace defense contractor had nicely higher first quarter earnings, $0.32 versus $0.24 last year and revenues up 18 percent.

Clarcor (CLC) which is a big filtration company off $2.87. Third quarter earnings $0.32, a penny above last year, but $0.04 below the Street estimate. Sales actually fell 1.7 percent.

Google (GOOG) topped the active list on NASDAQ gaining $5.49.

Apple (AAPL) a $0.09 rise.

Microsoft (MSFT) down $0.25.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) a $0.42 loss.

Intel (INTC) dropped $0.18 a share, fifth in dollar volume.

Research in Motion (RIMM) up $1.64.

Then Oracle (ORCL) a $0.32 gain there.

Palm (PALM) closed down $1.71. Speculation appears to be cooling that it might be the target of a takeover attempt. After the close, Palm reported third quarter earnings excluding items, $0.16 a share, $0.04 above the Street estimate. In after hours trading, the stock was about $0.20 higher than this.

Broadcom (BRCM) down $1.29, hurt by Motorola`s earnings warning.

And then Qualcomm (QCOM) tenth in volume was off $0.38 a share.

Intuit (INTU) down $2.46. The company says its Turbotax software sales are off to a slow start this tax season so far.

Those are the stocks in the news tonight. Suzanne.

PRATT: The SEC and the American Stock Exchange today settled their differences over problems with the exchange`s oversight of options trading. Regulators allege, from 1999 through June 2004, the Amex didn`t adequately enforce certain order-handling rules and comply with record-keeping guidelines. The settlement creates a $3 million fund to help pay for stepped up exchange surveillance. Still in the works, though, EC action against the Amex`s former Chairman Salvatore Sodano.

KANGAS: Tomorrow, our Friday "market monitor" guest is Jeffrey Everett, chief investment officer at Templeton Global Advisors.

PRATT: A Federal judge in Mississippi has turned down a request to allow a class-action suit against State Farm insurance for denial of damage claims from hurricane Katrina. At issue so-called slab cases where houses were destroyed down to the slab. The judge said while all the homes were ruined, there are other factors that make the cases unsuitable for class action.

KANGAS: Coca-Cola is rolling out a new version of its diet Coke drink, adding vitamins and minerals to the mix. The new diet Coke plus will contain small mounts of vitamins B-3, B-6 and B-12, as well as magnesium and zinc. But the recipe for the soda itself will be unchanged. Coke says the new soft drink should hit U.S. store shelves next month.

PRATT: Here`s a look at what`s happening tomorrow. February existing home sales come out, along with earnings from Freddie Mac.

Tonight`s commentator has a few thoughts on what the Blackstone Group`s $4 billion IPO could mean to Wall Street. Here`s Chrystia Freeland, U.S. managing editor of "The Financial Times."

CHRYSTIA FREELAND, US MANAGING EDITOR, FINANCIAL TIMES: The irony of the move is irresistible. After all, the private equity business is based on the idea that a lot of companies can be run more effectively if they are liberated from the short-term targets and regulatory red tape that bedevils the public market. But there are some powerful reasons for Blackstone to be tempted to go public. The greatest may be the simplest. Blackstone`s founders are surely keen in Wall Street`s uncharacteristically coy terminology to crystallize the value of their partnership.

In plainer language, that means they want to take their billions before they retire. In contrast with those pitied Goldman Sachs senior partners who left the legendary firm before its IPO and missed out on the windfall their younger colleagues collected. For those of us not in line to receive Blackstone`s billions, the greatest significance of an IPO would be to make the private equity revolution more sustainable. Private equity has become so powerful it is easy to forget that the dominant groups are just a few decades old, are still run by the men who founded them and are dependent on Internet and fund-raising (INAUDIBLE) for most of their capital. Going public would give them access to permanent money and thus make them a more permanent fixture in world business. And that is the real irony of the story. Public capital could well give private equity groups a more enduring power to take companies private. I`m Chrystia Freeland.

KANGAS: Recapping today`s market action, a split decision on Wall Street. The Dow gained 13 points while the NASDAQ Composite lost four points. To learn more about the stories in tonight`s broadcast, go to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on pbs.org. You can also e-mail us at nbr@pbs.org

PRATT: And finally tonight, what does it take to get two bitter rivals together? And what does it take to make tax time less taxing? Scott Gurvey has those answers and more in tonight`s "tech talk."

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Tonight`s big tech news is a partnership of two very unlikely bedfellows: NBC Universal and Newscorp, parent of the Fox network. Who could get these guys together? Try youtube, the popular video-sharing web site now owned by Google. Youtube members make and post videos, often using original material, but just as often using content recorded from TV and cable, raising copyright concerns. A competing site run by NBC and Newscorp would have lots of content it could legally distribute. Yahoo!, MSN, AOL and Newscorp`s myspace will be involved. Stay tuned.

All of these sites make money by selling ads. The more popular the site, the more it can sell, and it adds up! Cisco Systems, Intel and General Motors have already signed up to advertise on the new NBC-Newscorp site. There are big bucks involved. Google paid $1.6 billion to buy youtube and recently, Viacom sued youtube for $1 billion, charging it with copyright infringement. Youtube has yet to file a response. The digital millennium copyright act of 1998 was supposed to clarify copyright law in the Internet age. It appears there is more work to be done.

It is tax time and the IRS says more than 130 million returns will be filed this year. Thirty five million will be made with tax preparation software. I`ve tried the leading products and, while they all do a good job, once again I`ve found Intuit`s Turbotax to be the most comprehensive and easiest to use. It does tend to cost $10 to $15 more than H&R Block`s tax cut. This year, Intuit added a home and business version, perfect if you file a Schedule C or need to generate W-2s for business or household employees. The tax software companies report their fastest growth is among taxpayers who enter all their data online, a process Intuit`s Bob Meighan says is simple and safe.

BOB MEIGHAN, VICE PRESIDENT, INTUIT: People don`t have to go to the store and buy the software. They don`t have to install it. They don`t have to worry about updates. I can go to the web and access tax software to do my return, so it`s convenient. All the products I know about use secure connections. If you`re transmitting your return to the IRS, it`s via secure connection, so the data is secure. All the companies that I know about guard your information very, very well, because we want to protect your privacy.

GURVEY: Even with the tax software, I haven`t sent in my return yet. How about you? Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

PRATT: That`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, March 22. I`m Suzanne Pratt. Good night everyone and good night to you, Paul.

KANGAS: Good night, Suzanne. I`m Paul Kangas, wishing all of you the best of good buys.

END

urn:contentItem:4PB8-X680-TXW3-40TH-00000-00Nightly Business Report2007-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNightly Business Report

PAUL KANGAS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From rumor to reality -- one of the hottest private equity firms will be private no more. The Blackstone Group will take up residence here at the New York Stock Exchange. We`ll detail its $4 billion initial public offering.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Senate Banking Chairman Christopher Dodd scolded bank regulators today, saying they didn`t do enough to stop predatory lending in the sub-prime market. Dodd also put lenders on notice, saying they too are to blame for the sub-prime mess.

KANGAS: From sub-prime loans to sluggish sales and falling home prices, we go region by region for a look at the state of the American housing market.

PRATT: Then, Oracle is taking on one of its biggest rivals in court. We`ll tell you who the software giant is suing and why.

KANGAS: I`m Paul Kangas.

PRATT: And I`m Suzanne Pratt. Susie Gharib is off tonight. This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, May (sic) 22.

KANGAS: Good evening, everyone. One of the world`s largest private equity funds is going public. Late today, Blackstone Group announced a $4.4 or $4 billion initial public offering. The move lets investors buy into a risky business that has traditionally been the ground of wealthy individuals and large institutions. Blackstone generated more than $7.5 billion in investment gains in 2006. The company`s assets under management are worth almost $79 billion. Its portfolio includes real estate giant Equity Office Properties, Extended Stay America Hotels, publisher Houghton Mifflin and entertainment park Universal Orlando. Blackstone will trade on the New York Stock Exchange. But there`s no IPO date or ticker symbol specified in today`s filing with the SEC. But the company did say it won`t give quarterly guidance to Wall Street because its business is quote, unpredictable.

PRATT: The meltdown in the sub-prime lending market reached Capitol Hill today. The Senate Banking Committee called regulators, lenders and borrowers to learn more about the causes behind the sub-prime crisis. But as Stephanie Dhue reports, the committee quickly got down to the business of laying blame.

STEPHANIE DHUE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: With an increasing number of homeowners facing foreclosure, lawmakers, including New Jersey Senator Robert Menendez, accused the Federal Reserve of being asleep at the switch.

SEN. ROBERT MENENDEZ (D) NEW JERSEY: How could it be this big and you have done your job?

ROGER COLE, DIR., BANKING SUPERVISION & REGULATION, FEDERAL RESERVE: Given what we know now, yes, we could have done more sooner.

DHUE: Regulators say much of the sub-prime market falls outside their jurisdiction, which deals mostly with ensuring that banks are financially sound. But Senate Banking Committee Chairman Chris Dodd wasn`t buying that argument.

SEN. CHRIS DODD, CHAIRMAN, BANKING COMMITTEE: The Fed had the responsibility in my view, as a good cop, to be on the beat, particularly going back several years ago, when the information first began to surface that there were serious problems with these sub-prime loans.

DHUE: Dodd called on the regulators to quickly finalize tighter sub- prime lending standards. But lenders warn some borrowers will be shut out of the market. Countrywide Financial says it would lose 60 percent of its sub-prime business under the proposed tighter standards. Still, the company`s managing director, Sandor Samuels, says that`s not his key concern.

SANDOR SAMUELS, MANAGING DIRECTOR, COUNTRYWIDE FINANCIAL: The concern that we have is the impact on the housing market and the impact on borrowers who are in the sub-prime market. And so we hope the regulations can find a balance that will allow consumers to benefit from lower housing payments, while protecting them from unaffordable payment increases.

DHUE: The committee also heard from borrowers now at risk of losing their homes. Jennie Haliburton got an adjustable 2/28 sub-prime loan from Countrywide last year. Her payment is set to adjust in May to more than 70 percent of her income.

JENNIE HALIBURTON, BORROWER: I feel like they took advantage of me because I`m 77 and they figure, "oh, well, she`s old."

DHUE: Countrywide says it will work with Mrs. Haliburton to keep her in her home. Senator Dodd says there are thousands of sub-prime borrowers struggling with their mortgages and he wants to find ways to help them. Stephanie Dhue, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

PRATT: KB Home`s quarterly earnings plummeted 84 percent, as home prices dropped, inventories swelled and the sub-prime mortgage market began to implode. KB Home earned $0.34 a share in its fiscal first quarter. That`s down sharply from the year-ago period, but $0.09 ahead of analyst estimates. Sales fell 19 percent to $1 3/4 billion, but that was still ahead of estimates. KB Home`s CEO says housing conditions remain difficult, making it even harder to predict when the market will stabilize. The company also says 13 percent of the mortgages for KB Homes last year were financed with sub-prime loans.

KANGAS: Wall Street felt the sting of profit taking this morning after yesterday`s sharp rally. Selling was also linked to Motorola`s forecast of a first quarter loss and a rise in oil prices. By 11 a.m., the Dow was off 30 points, NASDAQ down 12. The blue chips improved this afternoon with the help of a brokerage upgrade on Procter & Gamble and some strong oil stocks, but the broader market ended lower. The Dow Industrial Average closed up 13.62 at 12,461.14. NASDAQ Composite lost 4.18, ending at 2451.74. Standard & Poor`s 500 Index fell exactly a half point to 1434.54. Over in the bond market, the 10-year note fell 12/32 to par and 10/32, lifting the yield to 4.59 percent.

PRATT: This week in our special housing series, we looked at market conditions in three U.S. cities: New York, Washington, DC and Miami. Tonight, we continue that series with a broader discussion of the national housing market. Our guest this evening is Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody`s economy.com. Mark, welcome.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY`S ECONOMY.COM: Thanks for having me.

PRATT: So what is the current state of the U.S. housing market?

ZANDI: It`s struggling. The correction which began almost two years ago is ongoing. Since the peak, we have seen sales off about 10, 15 percent. Starts are done by a third. And prices are now falling in about half to two-thirds of the nation`s market.

PRATT: So this is a correction, though, not a meltdown?

ZANDI: I would characterize it as a correction. It is a severe correction. But at this point we`re not seeing double digit price declines. And the market is still holding together reasonably well so not a crash, at least not yet.

PRATT: So tell me about the weakest areas of the country. What are some of those?

ZANDI: Well, they would include California, primarily southern California. San Diego would be a good case in point. Arizona, Phoenix, Las Vegas, most of Florida, particularly south of Florida and parts of the northeast, Washington DC, the Boston region and of course the areas around Detroit are very weak because of job losses in the auto industry.

PRATT: And what about the strongest regions of the country, what are those?

ZANDI: Well, there are fewer but Texas would be a relatively strong housing market, some of the areas around the Carolinas, the farm belt and the pas civic northwest. In fact house prices in the Pacific northwest are still rising at a double-digit pace.

PRATT: So is it typical for a correction like this to be so uneven?

ZANDI: It is. The house market is a very local market. It really depends on where you are. Although I have to say this is the broadest the housing market correction that I think we`ve experienced at least since the great depression.

PRATT: So if it is so broad though is that, or does that have ominous predictions or does that mean that we should be more concerned?

ZANDI: Well, we should be concerned. The soft part of the economy lies in the housing and now of course in the mortgage market. Housing is weighing heavily on the economy. So far the problems in housing have been largely contained to housing. They haven`t bled out to consumer spending and business investment. But given the problems and the fact that they are ongoing, we need to watch that very carefully.

PRATT: So let`s talk a little bit about the sub-prime part of the market. I mean what does that mean? What is that likely to do to the overall housing market? Could it take it into a meltdown?

ZANDI: Well, it is a significant problem. If you consider all of the very aggressive loans that have been extended in recent years, that would include sub-prime, alternative A, prime loans that are interest only or negative am loans -- these are very aggressive loans. You combine all those and these are ones at a significant risk of default. They account for 40 percent of origination volume last year and roughly one quarter of all mortgage debt outstanding. So this a significant market that is going to be significantly affected. As a result, we will see some measurable impact on housing activity and probably as a result on the broader economy.

PRATT: One thing I want to make sure that we cover is the Fed and their statement yesterday. They sort of removed the bias, depending on who you ask. You think that that was because or directly because of the housing market.

ZANDI: Yeah, I think they did -- they did get rid of their bias towards future higher interest rates. They now have a neutral policy and I think they did that to have some latitude just in case if the housing market goes south and the mortgage market weakens, that they could ease if they needed to. At this point I don`t think they want to. Inflation is above their target. They would prefer not to, but they needed a little bit of flexibility and they got that in yesterday`s statement.

PRATT: OK, great. My guest this evening, Mark Zandi, chief economist at moodyseconomy.com, thanks for joining us.

ZANDI: Thank you.

KANGAS: Business software maker Oracle sued German rival SAP today, claiming SAP committed quote, corporate theft on a grand scale end quote. Oracle says SAP illegally logged on to its password-protected customer web sites many times, stealing huge amounts of software code, documents and other confidential material. Oracle claims it knows SAP excuse me, was the culprit because Oracle traced the log-ons back to an SAP-owned subsidiary in Texas. SAP said it had no comment on the lawsuit. Oracle wants a California court to assess damages, force SAP to return the stolen items and bar SAP from logging on to Oracle`s web sites.

Crude oil surged more than 2 percent today, jumping $2.08 to $61.69 a barrel. The rally was fueled by expectations energy demand will start to surge as we head into the summer driving season. And as Erika Miller explains, experts expect oil prices to spurt even higher.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Spring is supposed to be the time of year when energy prices dip due to weak demand. Instead, the opposite is happening. Analyst Fadel Gheit blames an across- the-board rally in energy prices on strong demand for gasoline.

FADEL GHEIT, ENERGY ANALYST, OPPENHEIMER & CO.: Right now, gasoline prices are leading the energy markets in the U.S. But it doesn`t mean that oil prices are, you know, pulling back. Oil prices have shown tremendous resiliency that nobody had expected.

MILLER: Gasoline futures have surged over 20 percent since January. They`re now at a seven-month high. The rally is due in large part to fears of a supply crunch heading into the summer driving season. In the U.S., there has been an almost insatiable demand for motor fuel, despite higher prices at the pump. At the same time, supplies are dwindling. Energy trader Ira Eckstein blames that on glitches and seasonal maintenance at refineries.

IRA ECKSTEIN, OIL TRADER, AREA INTERNATIONAL TRADING: We have these outages, plus they are doing their usual spring -- they`re going from heating oil to gasoline, so they had to close down some refineries in order to switch over.

MILLER: There are also concerns about disruptions to crude supplies due to geopolitical tensions in places like Iran, Nigeria, and Saudi Arabia. Another big unknown is weather. Hurricane season starts June 1, raising the risk of damage to U.S. oil infrastructure. In the near term, many traders expect oil prices to inch higher. The question is, how much?

ECKSTEIN: Crude oil is going to test that $62.50 level -- maybe not this week, but maybe early next week and I think that we could stay above there. We`ll see how we react when we get there.

MILLER: That`s bad news for motorists. In some places, including New York City, regular unleaded is approaching $3 a gallon. But few experts think we`ll head back to record levels just yet. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York

PRATT: Transatlantic air travel took a leap into the future today, as the European Union`s transport ministers approved plans to open the skies to more competition. The so-called open skies deal lets EU carriers fly from any city in the block to any city in the U.S. and vice versa. The Bush administration welcomed the decision, saying it will spur growth and give Americans more flying freedom. The plan had been set to take effect in October, but all sides agreed on a five-month delay. The new start date is March 30, 2008, Paul.

KANGAS: Suzanne, shares of the major air carriers hit some turbulence today on concerns that pact could trigger a price war. We`ll look at how they did as we take a look at our stocks in the news tonight.

Big board volume leader on nearly 51 million shares, Motorola (MOT) down $1.24. After the close yesterday as we reported, the company predicted a $0.07 to $0.09 per share first quarter loss.

Then Pfizer (PFE) down $0.06.

General Electric (GE) moved up $0.33. The company is teaming up with News Corporation to launch an online video site to compete with youtube. The details coming up shortly.

Ford Motor Co (F) was up $0.07.

CVS Caremark (CVS), this is the first day of trading for the new merger company of CVS Caremark, down $0.36 a share, fifth in volume.

AT&T (T) rose $0.25.

Alcatel-Lucent (ALU) down a half a dollar. Goldman Sachs downgraded it from "buy" to "neutral" because it sees no sales recovery for the firm before the third quarter of this year.

ExxonMobil (XOM) up $1.13 on that sharp rise in oil.

Chesapeake Energy (CHK) down $0.15.

And Time Warner (TWX), tenth in volume, was off $0.28.

Procter Gamble (PG) moved up $0.89. Bear Stearns upgraded it from "peer perform" to "out perform" because of its attractive valuation in the price of the stock, according to Bear Stearns.

And then AMR (AMR) parent of American Airlines, down $1.54, not only today because of the sharp rise in oil, but airfares are expected to tumble next spring when the open skies package you just heard about goes into effect.

Let`s have a look at some other major carriers. Continental Air (CAL) down $1.60.

And UAL Corp (UAUA) losing $1.77.

Raytheon Co (RTN) off $1.41. The company boosted its annual dividend 6 percent from $0.96 to $1.02, but nevertheless, Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock from "neutral" to a "sell."

Conagra Foods (CAG), the big packaged foods company down $0.02 despite a turnaround. Third quarter earnings of $0.38 versus a loss last year. Those earnings $0.03 above the Street estimate.

Another packaged foods company, General Mills (GIS) moving up $0.44. Third quarter earnings there were up nearly 9 percent to $0.74, $0.04 above the Street estimate and the company boosted its 2007 earnings guidance.

Nortel Networks (NT) fell $1.53. The company launched a $1 billion offering of convertible debt, which of course has potential earnings dilution.

Then we see Barnes & Noble (BKS), the book seller, down $1.10. The company says preliminary fourth quarter earnings will be $1.84, up from $1.76 last year, but $0.04 below the Wall Street estimate.

IHS (IHS), a $3.90 gain. The aerospace defense contractor had nicely higher first quarter earnings, $0.32 versus $0.24 last year and revenues up 18 percent.

Clarcor (CLC) which is a big filtration company off $2.87. Third quarter earnings $0.32, a penny above last year, but $0.04 below the Street estimate. Sales actually fell 1.7 percent.

Google (GOOG) topped the active list on NASDAQ gaining $5.49.

Apple (AAPL) a $0.09 rise.

Microsoft (MSFT) down $0.25.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) a $0.42 loss.

Intel (INTC) dropped $0.18 a share, fifth in dollar volume.

Research in Motion (RIMM) up $1.64.

Then Oracle (ORCL) a $0.32 gain there.

Palm (PALM) closed down $1.71. Speculation appears to be cooling that it might be the target of a takeover attempt. After the close, Palm reported third quarter earnings excluding items, $0.16 a share, $0.04 above the Street estimate. In after hours trading, the stock was about $0.20 higher than this.

Broadcom (BRCM) down $1.29, hurt by Motorola`s earnings warning.

And then Qualcomm (QCOM) tenth in volume was off $0.38 a share.

Intuit (INTU) down $2.46. The company says its Turbotax software sales are off to a slow start this tax season so far.

Those are the stocks in the news tonight. Suzanne.

PRATT: The SEC and the American Stock Exchange today settled their differences over problems with the exchange`s oversight of options trading. Regulators allege, from 1999 through June 2004, the Amex didn`t adequately enforce certain order-handling rules and comply with record-keeping guidelines. The settlement creates a $3 million fund to help pay for stepped up exchange surveillance. Still in the works, though, EC action against the Amex`s former Chairman Salvatore Sodano.

KANGAS: Tomorrow, our Friday "market monitor" guest is Jeffrey Everett, chief investment officer at Templeton Global Advisors.

PRATT: A Federal judge in Mississippi has turned down a request to allow a class-action suit against State Farm insurance for denial of damage claims from hurricane Katrina. At issue so-called slab cases where houses were destroyed down to the slab. The judge said while all the homes were ruined, there are other factors that make the cases unsuitable for class action.

KANGAS: Coca-Cola is rolling out a new version of its diet Coke drink, adding vitamins and minerals to the mix. The new diet Coke plus will contain small mounts of vitamins B-3, B-6 and B-12, as well as magnesium and zinc. But the recipe for the soda itself will be unchanged. Coke says the new soft drink should hit U.S. store shelves next month.

PRATT: Here`s a look at what`s happening tomorrow. February existing home sales come out, along with earnings from Freddie Mac.

Tonight`s commentator has a few thoughts on what the Blackstone Group`s $4 billion IPO could mean to Wall Street. Here`s Chrystia Freeland, U.S. managing editor of "The Financial Times."

CHRYSTIA FREELAND, US MANAGING EDITOR, FINANCIAL TIMES: The irony of the move is irresistible. After all, the private equity business is based on the idea that a lot of companies can be run more effectively if they are liberated from the short-term targets and regulatory red tape that bedevils the public market. But there are some powerful reasons for Blackstone to be tempted to go public. The greatest may be the simplest. Blackstone`s founders are surely keen in Wall Street`s uncharacteristically coy terminology to crystallize the value of their partnership.

In plainer language, that means they want to take their billions before they retire. In contrast with those pitied Goldman Sachs senior partners who left the legendary firm before its IPO and missed out on the windfall their younger colleagues collected. For those of us not in line to receive Blackstone`s billions, the greatest significance of an IPO would be to make the private equity revolution more sustainable. Private equity has become so powerful it is easy to forget that the dominant groups are just a few decades old, are still run by the men who founded them and are dependent on Internet and fund-raising (INAUDIBLE) for most of their capital. Going public would give them access to permanent money and thus make them a more permanent fixture in world business. And that is the real irony of the story. Public capital could well give private equity groups a more enduring power to take companies private. I`m Chrystia Freeland.

KANGAS: Recapping today`s market action, a split decision on Wall Street. The Dow gained 13 points while the NASDAQ Composite lost four points. To learn more about the stories in tonight`s broadcast, go to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on pbs.org. You can also e-mail us at nbr@pbs.org

PRATT: And finally tonight, what does it take to get two bitter rivals together? And what does it take to make tax time less taxing? Scott Gurvey has those answers and more in tonight`s "tech talk."

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Tonight`s big tech news is a partnership of two very unlikely bedfellows: NBC Universal and Newscorp, parent of the Fox network. Who could get these guys together? Try youtube, the popular video-sharing web site now owned by Google. Youtube members make and post videos, often using original material, but just as often using content recorded from TV and cable, raising copyright concerns. A competing site run by NBC and Newscorp would have lots of content it could legally distribute. Yahoo!, MSN, AOL and Newscorp`s myspace will be involved. Stay tuned.

All of these sites make money by selling ads. The more popular the site, the more it can sell, and it adds up! Cisco Systems, Intel and General Motors have already signed up to advertise on the new NBC-Newscorp site. There are big bucks involved. Google paid $1.6 billion to buy youtube and recently, Viacom sued youtube for $1 billion, charging it with copyright infringement. Youtube has yet to file a response. The digital millennium copyright act of 1998 was supposed to clarify copyright law in the Internet age. It appears there is more work to be done.

It is tax time and the IRS says more than 130 million returns will be filed this year. Thirty five million will be made with tax preparation software. I`ve tried the leading products and, while they all do a good job, once again I`ve found Intuit`s Turbotax to be the most comprehensive and easiest to use. It does tend to cost $10 to $15 more than H&R Block`s tax cut. This year, Intuit added a home and business version, perfect if you file a Schedule C or need to generate W-2s for business or household employees. The tax software companies report their fastest growth is among taxpayers who enter all their data online, a process Intuit`s Bob Meighan says is simple and safe.

BOB MEIGHAN, VICE PRESIDENT, INTUIT: People don`t have to go to the store and buy the software. They don`t have to install it. They don`t have to worry about updates. I can go to the web and access tax software to do my return, so it`s convenient. All the products I know about use secure connections. If you`re transmitting your return to the IRS, it`s via secure connection, so the data is secure. All the companies that I know about guard your information very, very well, because we want to protect your privacy.

GURVEY: Even with the tax software, I haven`t sent in my return yet. How about you? Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

PRATT: That`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, March 22. I`m Suzanne Pratt. Good night everyone and good night to you, Paul.

KANGAS: Good night, Suzanne. I`m Paul Kangas, wishing all of you the best of good buys.

END
