urn:contentItem:568X-0VK1-DYG3-12N4-00000-00Nightly Business Report2012-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTBUSINESS080601cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I`m Tom Hudson. Susie is off tonight. A rescue for Knight Capital today. The trading firm stays in business thanks to a $400 million investment.

Erika Miller reports tonight on a takeover offer for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY). The founder of the struggling electronics retail chain wants to take it private.

And the Mars rover has landed on the red planet. We`ll see what U.S. companies hope to gain by signing on to the mission. That and more coming up tonight here on NBR.

We begin with this, a $400 million lifeline today for Knight Capital. It`s a company that makes some of the plumbing of the U.S. stock market. The market maker has been fighting to survive since a trading software update went hay-wire last week, leading to hundreds of millions of dollars in losses, its stock price cut by two-thirds and now a rescue by some of its competitors.

The deal by a half dozen Wall Street firms to invest in Knight allowed the company to, quote, resume normal operations immediately, end quote, according to Knight. Those behind the $400 million deal are investment banking firms Jefferies, Stephens and Stifel Financial (NYSE:SF), private equity giant Blackstone, trading competitor Getco and customer TD Ameritrade (NASDAQ:AMTD). Ameritrade was one of Knight`s big customers that stopped doing business with it after Wednesday`s trading trouble. Ameritrade has since returned as have other big customers.

As for its investment in Knight, an Ameritrade spokesperson tells NBR, quote, we have an interest in preserving choice and competition in the markets, end quote. Knight Capital matches buyers and sellers of thousands of stocks and billions of shares. It also buys and sells stocks itself, helping keep money flowing. So when it`s new trading software had a problem, the firm was stuck with hundreds of millions of dollars in losing trades. That sent shareholders fleeing, driving down its stock price, leading Knight to look for help. But the assistance comes at the expense of diluting current shareholders` interest. That pressured Knight stock today, down 24 percent. Knight`s rescuers get preferred stock that may be converted to common stock at $1.50 per share plus a 2 percent dividend. The deal represents a 73 percent stake in the company. The investor group also gets three new seats on the board of directors.

HUDSON: All this week at NBR, we`re looking at you, the everyday investor and what problems like the one at Knight Capital are doing to investor confidence. You may remember the last time a computer system sent the stock prices spiraling. It happened back in May 2010 and was called the flash crash. It led to new rules on when firms get a do-over after a computer error. Knight asked for just such a do-over, pleading with the Securities and Exchange Commission to be released from mistaken trades. The answer back, no. Darren Gersh tonight reports on the firm line from Washington.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: This is really a story about a bailout that didn`t happen. Knight Capital Group (NYSE:KCG) asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for special help. Stock exchange rules set strict limits on when trades can be reversed. In Knight`s case, the rules say trades made by mistake that are more than 30 percent off of the real market price can be undone. Knight wanted more trades busted, but regulators said no. The message was clear.

JAMES ANGEL, FINANCE PROFESSOR, GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY: Once you make a trade, unless something has gone incredibly wrong, your word is your bond. You make a trade, you are expected to live up to it.

GERSH: People familiar with the matter say regulators are sending a clear message to investors: the rules on erroneous trades are meant to provide markets with certainty and they worked in this case. Another message: firms need to have incentives to be careful and what happened to Knight is a big incentive.

ANGEL: Right now I think that every IT manager is going to his boss and saying, give me a bigger budget so I make sure this isn`t going to happen here.

GERSH: But that does not reassure critics who fear Wall Street firms have created computer systems they can`t control.

DENNIS KELLEHER, CEO, BETTER MARKETS: It is not a glitch when in less than 30 minutes over 150 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange vary wildly in purchases and sales and prices and there`s essentially haywire in the markets. That`s not a glitch. That`s a huge problem. It`s a red flag and people better start paying attention.

GERSH: While the SEC took a tough line with Knight Capital, there are growing concerns about the ability of regulators to police the Street.

KELLEHER: Regulators and regulation generally can`t keep up with what`s going on in the markets. It`s just that simple. Now one of the main reasons for that is that there is a fairly massive effort led by Wall Street and its allies to de-fund the agencies so they can prevent them from putting financial reform into place.

GERSH: Before the computer mistake, Knight Capital handled 20 percent of the trading in stocks like Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL). It was well-respected and innovative and all that blew up in less than half an hour. Darren Gersh, NBR, Washington.

HUDSON: (INAUDIBLE) Just the latest reminder of how technology continues to reshape the investment market. As part of our coverage this week, join the discussion online on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and Twitter, bizrpt. How confident are you in the technology that powers the market? Will it change how you trade and invest because of the technology? Join us online.

On Wall Street today meantime, investors helped the major averages to finish a fresh three-month highs tonight, despite some selling in Knight Capital shares as we mentioned. The Dow Industrials rising 21 points, the NASDAQ up 22, the S&P 500 gained three points. One other quick note here about policing the markets. A major British bank was accused today of hiding over 60,000 illegal transactions with Iran over the past decade. Those transactions made by Standard Charter PLC were valued at over $250 billion. New York State`s department of financial services threatened to revoke the bank`s U.S. license today and called it a quote, rogue institution. Standard Charter meantime said it`s reviewing its compliance with U.S. banking sanctions.

A billion dollar plus bet could be paying off much sooner than Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) had hoped. One week into the media company`s NBC Olympics coverage and it may actually turn a profit. NBC has been hit by the usual number of criticisms, too much focus on the Americans, not enough live coverage, hasn`t hurt the television audience numbers here in the U.S. though. Through the first 10 days of coverage - look at this - Comcast`s Olympic ratings averaged 33.6 million viewers. That`s up 12 percent from Beijing, 28 percent higher than the Athens games in 2004.

Porter Bibb is back with us, managing partner at Mediatech Capital Partners at the NASDAQ. Porter, is it something that Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) is doing with its coverage of the games or is it the games themselves?

PORTER BIBB, MANAGING PARTNER, MEDIATECH CAPITAL PARTNERS: I think it`s mostly the games themselves and it`s the fact that there`s not a lot else going on right now in the dog days of the summer of 2012. Basically it`s the fact that this Olympics has drawn a tremendous amount of attention from the public and it`s reflected in these numbers which are historic. They`ve never ever had such great ratings any television broadcast since 1960 when CBS (NYSE:CBS) first broadcast the Rome Olympics.

HUDSON: Talk to us about the opportunities here then. This opportunity comes at a significant cost, more than a billion dollars invested. Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) sold a billion dollars worth of advertising. Can it go back to its advertisers and ask for more money now that the ratings are in?

BIBB: They did get a little bit of a premium when they exceed the ratings, yes. But the biggest advertiser, interestingly enough on this Olympic tenure is NBC. Every third or fourth commercial is promoting an NBC series that`s going to be breaking this fall and they`re hoping to shore up their ratings throughout the year because NBC has been wallowing in the cellar behind all of the other major networks for the last seven years.

HUDSON: I want to talk about the investor in the Olympics here before we get to the broader NBC picture. Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) has estimated a $200 million profit. It spent about $1.2 billion for the rights it has to pay to produce the programs. Is this a good return on investment for shareholders?

BIBB: It`s never been a good return in terms of bottom line, but it`s considered by the TV executives in the suites to be the best promotion for their networks that money can buy. It rivals the Super Bowl and the way the Oscars used to command this kind of an audience but don`t anymore.

HUDSON: Certainly, shareholders are being attracted to this stock, Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) shares at a 52-week high even with this billion dollar plus investment.

BIBB: You have to realize that NBC television is a very small part of the Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) empire. They`re the largest cable systems operators in the country, in the world in fact and they`re also the largest Internet service providers. They reap huge profits from NBC Universal (NYSE:UVV) cable channels, not just television networks.

HUDSON: Is that the way you leverage then the next Olympic games? Is that the lesson here?

BIBB: They have bought this Olympics and the summer and winter Olympics in 2020 and they expect that they will have to change the model because the next Rio in 2016 is going to be an online digital Internet, not like this one. These decisions that NBC made were two and a half years ago when they acquired the rights and they didn`t anticipate the iPad and the profusion of smart phones that are out there. And their Internet delivery is really patchy. It`s not very good, but it will be by the time they get to Rio for sure.

HUDSON: That`s going to be the big change for the next summer games in four years. Do you have any position in Comcast (NASDAQ:CMCSA) (NYSE:CCS) by the way, Porter?

BIBB: None.

HUDSON: Porter Bibb along with us here watching the Olympics and commenting on the coverage, Mediatech Capital Partners.

Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) founder and former chairman wants his stores back. Richard Schulze has offered to take the struggling electronics retail chain private. The offer is $24 to $26 per share. Now the higher price, it values the company at just over $8.8 billion. Erika Miller tonight in Manhattan joining us with what could be one of the biggest buyouts in recent years of an American retailer.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: That`s right. Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) founder has made a generous offer for the stores but he still faces an uphill battle getting the board to approve it. In a public letter addressed to Best Buy`s board, Richard Schulze says quote, bold and extensive changes are needed for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) to return to market leadership. He is proposing to buy out the company, using his own money, private equity funds and some debt. So would going public (sic) be the right strategy for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY)?

RJ HOTTOVY, SR. RETAIL ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: It may make sense for Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) to be a privately held company, especially if you have the backing of a private equity company with retail and turnaround experience. Frankly, this company has got a lot of work ahead of them to stay competitive and stay relevant in the eyes of consumers.

MILLER: It`s a moment of truth for the retail electronics chain Schulze founded in 1966. Part of Best Buy`s problem is so-called showrooming. That`s when customers browse the store, but actually place their orders elsewhere, often at online sites like Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN). An even bigger issue is the enormous size of most stores, a relic of a bygone era.

HOTTOVY: In the early part of the 90`s through the early part of the 2000s, really consumers had no problem. They were shopping in stores for TVs, video games, CDs were all a big part of their consumer electronics budget. But as that shifted to a digital distribution format over the last several years, it has left a gaping hole in Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) stores.

MILLER: Schulze will clearly face big challenges turning the offer into a deal. First, he needs to get the approval of all Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) board members before signing a deal with private equity partners. He will likely have trouble getting the support of interim CEO Mike Mikan, who is gunning for a permanent position at the helm. Second, Schulze will have to detail his turnaround plans, which are vague at this point. The third issue is money. The board will likely try to get a higher offer, if it supports a deal at all and that could make it harder for Schulze to secure financing. And don`t forget Schulze was elbowed out as chairman in the spring, after an internal audit found he knew former CEO Brian Dunn was having an inappropriate relationship with a female employee. That alone is unlikely to be a deal breaker. But it may mean some board member resistance to putting him back in charge.

HUDSON: Erika is in New York tonight as we mentioned. So, why does Schulze make this offer in public? Why not negotiate privately with the board?

MILLER: In his letter, Schulze said he would have preferred to have private negotiations, but the board was dragging its feet, so he felt he had no choice but to take his campaign public and hope that Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) shareholders would support him.

HUDSON: It certainly caused a bit of a ruckus in the stock as we`ll mention in a moment. But what happens now? What`s the next step? What can we expect to hear, when can we hear from the board?

MILLER: It`s unclear at this point. All that we know is that Best Buy (NYSE:BBY) will confirm its made the offer, but don`t know when it will respond.

HUDSON: We are coming into a key time for retailers like Best Buys, holidays right around the corner, turnarounds are easier said than done this time of year. What does is need to do to discourage the showrooming, the shopping and actually and turn the shopping into buying?

MILLER: Best Buy`s biggest problem is its format, 50,000 square feet on average of retail space just doesn`t make sense any more. It needs to go to a smaller format store. That`s its biggest challenge. But it also needs to emphasize its most profitable product lines. We`re talking about things like mobile phones.

HUDSON: Erika Miller tonight in New York on Best Buy (NYSE:BBY). Thanks, Erika. From electronic retailing to auto sales, July was a disappointing month of sales for General Motors (NYSE:GM) at home. Not so in China though. The U.S. auto maker set a sales record there last month. But the road ahead in China could be dicey for GM and other auto companies. Diane Eastabrook has details.

DIANE EASTABROOK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: GM bucked fears of a slowing economy in China last month by selling 15 percent more vehicles there than it did during the same month last year. Among the biggest sellers for GM were Buick Excel models. While auto sales in China have been strong compared to last year, they`ve actually been declining month over month this year, a possible sign of a cooling Chinese economy. June sales slid nearly 2.5 percent from May and sales were also down the two months before that. Still U.S. auto manufacturers are betting big on China. GM is the market leader, selling more than 2.5 million vehicles there last year primarily through joint ventures. Ford is increasing its exposure there as well, planning to add six new plants in China that will produce more than a million vehicles by 2015. Diane Eastabrook, NBR, Chicago.

HUDSON: In our "Market Focus," Some modest gains driving the U.S. major stock indices up to three-month highs tonight. We begin with the intraday S&P 500 starting out with the index jumping on the heels of some decent gains we saw overnight in European and Asian markets. No headline economic data today as the buying cooled somewhat into the closing bell. The index finished up a fraction. But it was enough for it to continue the trend since June of higher highs and higher lows. This is the S&P 500`s highest close since May 2nd. Trading volume meantime backing off from Friday`s pace, 645 million shares on the big board, just over one and a half billion on the NASDAQ.

It was a mixed market, six of the 10 major stock sectors were higher. Material stocks leading the gainers, up 1.1 percent. Technology added 0.7 of a percent and it was steel stocks behind today`s gain in the materials sector. Many of these manufacturers have struggled under weaker building demand and lower pricing. But we have seen some buying lately after a string of better than expected earnings and some of the stocks also hitting recent lows.

U.S. Steel up today 5.6 percent, Titanium Metals (NYSE:TIE) rallying 4.5 percent. Both of these tonight are at their highest prices since mid- May. Cliff`s Natural Resources added 2.7 percent. Today was the first Monday since May that the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted a gain. Two of the top 3 percentage gainers in fact for the Dow in the tech industry. HPQ, Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ) up 2.4 percent. This buying comes after HP sank to a seven and a half year low late last week. Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) the other big tech stock on the Dow that`s been under pressure and shares gained 2.1 percent, although volume was lighter than usual during today`s buying of CSCO.

The biggest meat processor in the U.S., Tyson Foods (NYSE:TSN), may have to turn to Brazil for corn. The company put that option on the table today thanks to the continued drought throughout the Midwestern U.S. It comes after Tyson reported weaker than expected earnings, coming in $0.04 below estimates. Its beef business saw lower demand thanks to the controversy over a ground beef additive called pink slime by critics. Falling pork prices hurt that business in Tyson as well. The company went on to lower its revenue outlook for the year. That hit shares, falling eight percent. Volume was more than three times normal for TSN. This in fact tonight is a new 52-week low for Tyson.

Shares of semi-truck maker Navistar hit the gas, after Federal regulators, environmental regulators submitted a final rule allowing, that may allow the company to continue to pay fines and still sell engines that do not meet EPA guidelines. The stock has been under pressure as it has been threatened with losing the ability to sell these new engines that don`t meet current emissions standards. The details of today`s final ruling were not disclosed. Shares jumped 10 percent though. An interim rule allowed Navistart to continue with its sales if it paid a fine.

All five of the most actively traded ETF`s seeing some modest gains. The biggest for the Russell 2000 and NASDAQ 100 track funds. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

The virtual world of the Internet has changed businesses from newspapers to retailing. But the real world of video games continues to favor established names and not new-comers. That is tonight`s "Word on the Street" -- gaming. Debra Borchardt, markets analyst at thestreet.com with us at the NASDAQ. Deborah, first of all explain the business model differences between the new digital gaming versus more traditional video games?

DEBRA BORCHARDT, MARKETS ANALYST, THESTREET.COM: Well, a lot of the digital gamers, the way that they earn money is putting advertising within the games or trying to get you to pay for different additional items like points and that type of model. But they`re finding that people really just want to play their games on their phones for free. They`re called snacking games. You just play them for a little bit of a time when you`re standing in line, you`re waiting in a restaurant, something like that. So you really don`t want to pay any additional money, whereas your traditional game company like an Activision or an EA, they make their money off one upfront buying the game which is pretty expensive. But they`ve now determined ways to upsell you so that you can go and charge more for additional accessories to the game.

HUDSON: You can have a multitude of revenue sources in the language of an MBA student here. So the new generation is perhaps best illustrated by Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA), ZNGA, big business through facebook, and this stock has just been a disaster since its IPO, new lows last week here. Farmville is not working out for it. Is the new model broken?

BORCHARDT: Well it really is for Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) because they`ve got all their playing time on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) has started to push the old titles down in prominence and Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) hasn`t got a new title to get in new revenue. So as Farmville loses its attraction, it has to come up with a new name to attract new players. So it`s getting hurt with this relationship with Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and also by not having a new hit name.

HUDSON: But it`s not alone in that. Even traditional video game companies like Activision also are looked at as what`s new, what`s next? Activision for instance had a pretty decent quarter earnings-wise, a third of its sales coming through its digital channel to cut out the retail space, nice bigger margins there. But yet the stock sold off significantly last week and rebounded a bit today.

BORCHARDT: Right. They were beat up because they said that their second quarter net income fell. Some user were - some investors were concerned that the users for "World of Warcraft" had dropped. But here`s the thing. They have new titles coming up this fall. They`re going to making it to the holidays and this is what`s interesting. Here you`ve got Farmville with Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) and you can`t really update it. They haven`t really figured out how to built a franchise. The established companies were beat up for having franchises, but that`s then the big payoff. "Call of Duty," "Black Ops" is coming out, (INAUDIBLE) Giant." These titles just keep paying off. Electronic Arts (NASDAQ:ERTS) has "Madden."

HUDSON: Debra, do you own any positions in these stocks?

BORCHARDT: No, I don`t.

HUDSON: But we`re going to guess you`re a gamer nonetheless. Debra Borchardt along with us. She`s with the street.com.

Congress has fled Washington, DC for a five-week summer recess, despite little progress on a host of bills covering everything from extending the Bush-era tax cuts to interim drought relief and Internet security. Tonight`s commentary says don`t blame the G-word for all that interaction or rather inaction. She`s Veronique de Rugy, senior research fellow at the Mercatus Center at George Mason University.

VERONIQUE DE RUGY, SR. RSCH. FELLOW, MERCATUS CENTER, GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY: What`s really the problem in Washington? Well, if you ask Washington, they`ll tell you it`s gridlock and blame inaction on some new and hyper-partisan or ideological era. But while gridlock might be blamed for slowing things down, it can`t be blamed for failing to address serious issues. Welfare reform and balanced budgets in the 1990s were the product of gridlock that slowly gave way to consensus. And today`s Washington is more than happy to come together when it suits its own interests.

For instance, just last week, Congress managed bipartisan support for another continuing resolution, an agreement that allows the legislators to, once again, put off doing any real fiscal planning. In fact, Congress hasn`t managed to produce a Federal budget in more than three years. Washington`s problem is not gridlock. It is an increasingly irresponsible government that has for far too long been let off the hook for performing the most basic responsibilities. So, whatever happens in November, this much is certain: unless taxpayers demand their president and Congress act responsibly and do the work they were elected to do, so-called Washington gridlock will be the least of our problems. I`m Veronique de Rugy.

HUDSON: You can find some progress in outer space. NASA`s rover "Curiosity" tonight on the surface of the red planet. "Curiosity" pierced Mars` atmosphere traveling at 13,000 miles per hour, safely touched down after slowing to a mere two miles per hour. It began transmitting photos right away. Ruben Ramirez tonight reports on the partnership between government and business that made "Curiosity" possible.

RUBEN RAMIREZ, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The big question of course, is there, or, has there ever been life on Mars? Well, this week starts a two-year, $2.5 billion mission on the red planet to try and find the answer. Nearly three years behind schedule and almost a billion dollars over budget, NASA`s "Curiosity" rover landed safely on Mars. It`s the largest and most advanced spacecraft ever sent to outer space. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC), Lockheed Martin (NYSE:LMT), General Dynamics (NYSE:GD) and Siemens were just some of the companies that participated in the project. Siemens licensed its 3D modeling technology to NASA`s jet propulsion lab to help cut prototype costs.

TONY AFFUSO, CHAIRMAN, SIEMENS PLM SOFTWARE: These techniques between public and private and the way that they can share costs, share risks and collaborate around technology is a great way to bring all the resources to bear.

RAMIREZ: According to NASA, the public private partnership created about 7,000 jobs at various times during the eight years it took to develop the rover. And, unlike in past decades of space exploration, in true social media fashion, you can follow the rover on Twitter at Marscuriosity. Ruben Ramirez, NBR, Washington.

HUDSON: The red planet to Wall Street and Main Street. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Monday, August 6. Thanks for joining us. We`ll see you online at nbr.com and then back here tomorrow night.

urn:contentItem:5KR6-6FW1-JBHT-D2MM-00000-00Nightly Business Report2010-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportWalthamFULL TEXT

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Extending unemployment benefits. It`s a hot topic on Capitol Hill, but this man says there`s nothing political about needing a job.

BILL BOTELER: You`re going to have a lot of people out there who aren`t going to have jobs. They are not going to have anywhere to turn.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From compassion to the cost, we look at the pros and cons of extending jobless benefits for millions of Americans. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 19.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone, a plea today from President Obama for Congress to pass the unemployment bill. The president urged lawmakers, Tom, to put aside politics and to approve an extension of benefits to millions of Americans out of work.

HUDSON: Susie, this unemployment insurance bill is expected back on the Senate floor tomorrow. Republicans say they`ll only support an extension if the bill does not add to the national debt.

GHARIB: Still the president said lawmakers need to help Americans who have been laid off during this recession.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We`ve got a responsibility to help them make ends meet and support their families, even as they`re looking for another job. That`s why it`s so essential to pass the unemployment insurance extension that comes up for a vote tomorrow.

GHARIB: Millions of Americans will be watching that vote tomorrow to find out what`s ahead for their weekly unemployment insurance check and one of them will be Bill Boteler. We first introduced you to Bill almost a year ago when he had already been unemployed for several months. Today he still is looking for work. Now as we revisit him, Bill tells us how he`s keeping his spirits up and planning for an uncertain future. Darren Gersh reports.

BILL BOTELER: It`s the top one. Open it up. They gave me $290.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: For almost two years Bill Boteler has relied on a weekly unemployment insurance check. Not to make ends meet but to get them a little closer.

BOTELER: This to me is like a cushion. To try to live off this is challenging.

GERSH: When we first met Boteler almost a year ago, he hadn`t had a permanent job for 10 months. Since then he`s tried to keep his credit up which he says is important when you`re searching for work. He`s now looking for a cheaper apartment and Boteler says his weekly benefit check helps him focus on finding a job.

BOTELER: If you put the two together-- that you don`t have enough money to pay for anything and you are having to face a lot of rejection and a lot of disappointment in trying to find a job -- then I think that`s a little bit too much of a burden to put on people.

GERSH: In the last year, Boteler figures he`s applied for hundreds of jobs. He even set a daily production quota. His day begins with a trip to the new office of the great recession --

BOTELER: Hi, my name is Bill Boteler. I have experience as a writer and an editor.

GERSH: . the local cafe.

BOTELER: I mean, I`m here. I`m doing this. I`m dressed up. I have a goal. I`m not sitting in my room thinking about whether I should do the dishes or whether I should look for a job or something like that. I`m not aimless.

GERSH: Boteler has taken temp jobs including a stint as a census worker. Now he`s focused on the quality of his networking, not the quantity of resumes he sends out.

BOTELER: It`s unbelievable how much time it takes for people to find jobs. People who have not had to do that, who have been fortunate who have let`s say a job that`s been secure for many years, will be shocked when they discover just how difficult it is.

GERSH: We`ve talked to many people who are looking for work and they say there`s an unstated bias against the unemployed. Bill Boteler worries about that too. He wants people to know he`s a hard worker and he can`t understand why Congress is having such a tough time extending benefits.

BOTELER: If they cut the budget back, then you`re going to have a lot of people out there who aren`t going to have jobs. They`re not going to have anywhere to turn. And it`s... it will have an economic impact on people who consider themselves more fortunate.

GERSH: He has just nine weeks of unemployment insurance left. But the last few days, he says, have been good ones.

BOTELER: I`m not feeling really down right now because I`ve been doing a lot. I think something will pan out this time.

GERSH: Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: We`ll have more on the debate over extending jobless benefits a little bit later on in this program. But first let`s get you updated in the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. Stocks shook off some new worries about the housing sector at the closing bell, the Dow rising 56 points, the NASDAQ adding 19, the S&P 500 up six. NYSE exchange volume fell below a billion down from Friday`s pace. NASDAQ fell below two billion also down from Friday. Stocks moved higher despite home builders singing the blues. This month the National Association of Home Builders confidence index fell to its lowest level in 15 months on a slump in economic growth and persistent high unemployment.

BP can keep testing the cap fitted over its broken well head. Now the tests have shown a methane gas leak on the sea floor near the well is not related Retired Coast Guard Admiral Thad Allen has OKd BP to continue testing for another 24 hours. Meanwhile costs tied to the spill are nearing $4 billion, including over $200 million to settle individual claims. And Ken Feinberg, the man overseeing BP`s huge compensation fund, says fishermen and others with claims would be, in his words, crazy to bypass the fund and sue. Feinberg says he`ll be more generous than any court and claimants won`t face court delays.

GHARIB: And coming up on the program, stocks too volatile? Treasury yields got you down? How about lending money to your favorite company instead? We look at why corporate debt offerings are jumping.

HUDSON: More now on the debate over extending unemployment benefits. If Congress OKs this this week, it would be the sixth time since the recession began that unemployment payments have been extended. Over the past two years, looking at everyone without a job, the percent of people who have been jobless for six months or more has jumped from under 20 percent to almost half. Jeff Miron is a senior fellow at the Cato Institute. Christian Weller is a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress. Gentlemen, welcome to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT.

JEFF MIRON, SENIOR FELLOW, CATO INSTITUTE: Thank you very much for having me.

CHRISTIAN WELLER, SR. FELLOW, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS: Nice to be here.

HUDSON: Let`s begin with what the Department of Labor says about the purpose of these unemployment checks. The benefits, quote, are intended to provide temporary financial assistance to unemployed workers. Jeff, let`s begin with you. Should there be a limit to unemployment benefits?

MIRON: I think there should be a limit. We need to have a balance between compassion which is the temporary word in the Department of Labor`s language suggests and productivity in giving people an incentive to go out and find jobs and particular to be willing to lower their wage demands, to accept jobs that are not exactly what they had before. They`re not necessarily as good as they had before. But have to take some responsibility themselves for the fact that economic conditions are worse and therefore take a broader set of jobs and have some limit to how long people can collect unemployment insurance.

HUDSON: That presumes there are jobs out there and that job demand is not being fulfilled. Christian, how about you? How do you define temporary in that definition from the Department of Labor?

WELLER: We need to have a new definition of temporary. We have to be mindful of the fact that this is the worst recession since the great depression. We have over 14 million people looking for jobs who cannot find jobs. We have about five people looking for each opening. We have millions of people who have given up looking for a job. And as you already mentioned, those who are looking are looking longer than at any point since World War II. Still clearly temporary now means something else given the severity of the labor market recession. And I think extending unemployment benefits is compassionate, but it also makes economic sense.

HUDSON: Talk to us Christian, talk to us just about that idea. We saw earlier in Darren`s piece from Bill Boteler, $290 a week. That doesn`t go very far. What do we know about the economic impact of these checks?

WELLER: We know that these checks make a real difference obviously in peoples` lives, those who are hurt the most by the current crisis. But in the aggregate, we`re talking about $30 billion. The money will be spent very quickly because these are people who have been struggling for quite some time. You`re extending the unemployment benefits. The money won`t be saved. It will go very quickly to consumption. It will boost retail sales which is the big worry of businesses at this point that they may fall off. Forty percent of businesses worry about sales not being high enough. That`s the biggest worry for them. So it will help the private sector and will protect the private sector momentum that we`ve seen that since the end of 2009. It`s strengthened the recovery to help us continue building jobs in the private sector.

HUDSON: Jeff, how about that? In order to stimulate job growth, you need folks spending money. At least this gets people to have some dollars in their pocket to spend.

MIRON: I think it`s a very unpersuasive position. First of all, the check that we`re sending the unemployed came from somewhere. They came from the taxes of other people who are for the most part employed. So if transferring money to these people who are unemployed helps stimulate the economy, then taking it away from the people who are paying the taxes to pay for it de-stimulates the economy. Overall it`s hard the see how that is on net a beneficial thing. More broadly, the fact that we`re consistently trying to promote sort of redistribution in helping people rather than trying to create rules and a system which is productive gives the private sector pause. It makes the private sector think we`re not getting the deficit and the debt under control. It makes them think we`re not worry about productivity. That`s in the long term much worse for people having jobs and being employed than the temporary aspect related to the recession.

HUDSON: Jeff, it`s estimated that since the extended unemployment benefits expired back in early June, about $3 billion has not been spent. Over that same month interest on the U.S. debt in June was $107 billion. We seem to be, you know, talking about spending pennies or saving pennies when we`re spending dollars.

MIRON: I totally agree. It`s a very small amount of money. The fact that it`s a very small amount of money also means that any possible effect in stimulating the economy is also very trivial because we`re talking about a very small amount of money. The broader thing is it creates the wrong incentive. There`s clear evidence that people who are unemployed tend to leave unemployment just before their unemployment benefits run out. It`s not just a question -- it`s not the right way to think about it -- are there jobs? The right way is are there jobs at what wages? If people lower their wage demands, if they offer to take say their old job for 50 percent of what they were getting, there would be a lot more jobs out there. That`s the adjustment that needs to happen in many cases. But unemployment insurance and especially very, very long-term unemployment insurance impedes that kind of adjustment.

HUDSON: Guys less than a minute left. Christian, I want to address that job demand issue.

WELLER: That`s just simply robbing Peter to pay Paul. If we lower our wages to create more jobs, ultimately the overall consumption won`t change and sales won`t change. The important point is that unemployment benefits are incredibly targeted, very good. Benefits for the economy, every dollar spent on unemployment increases economic activity, $1.6 (ph). So it makes economic sense. It helps the most vulnerable and ultimately boosts economic growth. I think this is the time is right at this point to extend the unemployment benefit.

HUDSON: It will be in front of the Senate tomorrow, Christian. Does it get approved?

WELLER: It will get approved but probably with a very slim margin.

HUDSON: Jeff, how about it?

MIRON: Unfortunately I think it will get approved too.

HUDSON: Our guests this evening on extending unemployment benefits, Christian Weller, senior fellow at the Center for American Progress. We`ve also got Jeff Miron. He is with the Cato Institute.

WELLER: Thank you very much.

GHARIB: And moving along now to financial regulatory reform. On Wednesday President Obama will sign the biggest overhaul of financial rules since the great depression. The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission says she`ll need helps enforcing those rules -- a lot of help. Mary Shapiro says her agency will need 800 new workers for what she calls a logistical and labor intensive challenge. Her comments came in prepared testimony that`s expected before a House committee tomorrow. The Dodd Frank Reform Act gives sweeping new powers to the SEC, including supervising hedge funds and the huge derivatives market.

GHARIB: A big step forward in the break-up of Motorola. It is selling most of its wireless network equipment business to Nokia Siemens. The price tag $1.2 billion. The all-cash sale boosts the standing of Nokia Siemens joint venture in the U.S. and Japan. Those companies say it brings layoffs. As for Motorola, by the first quarter of next year, it will have two business units, one selling equipment for the business market and another making mobile phones and other consumer products.

And speaking of technology, Tom, IBM came out with those earnings and disappointing revenues after the bell. Looks like that could set the tone for the markets tomorrow.

HUDSON: Kind of a similar refrain we`re hearing from IBM which was a pretty good bottom line but some concerns on the top line. We talked about it late last week. It is back in tonight`s "Market Focus."

Before we get there throughout the day, investors bought both the defensive-minded utility sector as well as the growth-focused technology stocks. We`ll talk about big blue and tech in a moment. Utility stocks as measured by this exchange-traded fund XLU clearly was a pretty good winner today, traded up throughout the day almost making up what they lost during last Friday`s sell- off. A move over $31 for this ETF would take this fund up to a six-month high.

As we mentioned the focus after the close settled on a couple of big tech giants including IBM (IBM). Bottom line at big blue came in better than expected, but the top line revenues were lighter than anticipated. Also despite rising its full-year guidance, it still remains below Street estimates. Shares of IBM were up in advance of these earnings as you can see but after the report the stock was down as much as 4 percent after hours.

Chip maker Texas Instruments (TXN) was the other tech reporting after the close. Profits here coming in right as expected, no surprises. Operating profits did set a record. Gross margins also on the increase and positive news there for shareholders. Now TXN stock jumped 3 percent during the regular session. But after hours the stock gave up that and then some, falling by better than 6 percent. Apple (AAPL) is the big tech firm tomorrow with earnings as questions continue swirling about its iPhone-4. For a moment today intra-day, Apple stock fell below $240 per share, closing at $245 and change. That is the lowest price since mid May. Research in Motion, Motorola and others arguing today that Apple`s claim that all smart phones have reception problems is wrong. Apple`s earnings tomorrow by the way will be the first full quarter to include iPad sales. We`ll have a report tomorrow evening.

Energy stocks got a boost with some strong results from services company Halliburton (HAL). We`ll get you updated here. Growth across all of its markets helped Halliburton easily beat estimates. It`s the first major oil services firm to report earnings for the quarter that includes the BP disaster and the deep water drilling moratorium. Halliburton jumped 6 percent to a two-month high on the trade (ph). Schlumberger (SLB) will be next up with earnings in the group on Friday. Baker Hughes (BHI) is due out in two weeks.

More seats in the air may be good news for air travelers, but it could put pressure on airline profits. Delta (DAL) plans to increase capacity at the tail end of this year and into next year. That announcement came after earnings in the second quarter were much better than estimates. But echoing what we`ve seen from several others, revenues were less than anticipated. Delta stock dropped on three times the usual volume. Also caught up in the sell-off and concerns about more capacity leading to lower ticket prices, U.S. Airways (LCC) and even budget carrier Southwest (LUV), each falling on heavier volume.

Now we did see some biotech buying today in Gilead Sciences (GILD). It may be one to watch tomorrow. The "Wall Street Journal" tonight reports that a gel containing an HIV treatment made by Gilead cuts the chances of getting AIDS if used by women before and after sex. This study was led by South African researchers. Shares bounced off a 52-week low which was hit just on Friday. The drug is used to treat the AIDS virus, but this experiment looked at using it to help prevent HIV.

Catching you up on one of those biotechs working on an experimental weight loss drug, Vivus (VVUS) continued falling adding to Friday`s losses after an FDA advisory panel decided against recommending its treatment for approval, selling 8 percent to the downside.

Finally merger talk, today that centered around H&R Block (HRB). Shareholders have had a tough go of it this year, since January the stock down by a third hitting a new 52-week low on Friday. Today though, shares bouncing on word that another tax giant wants to talk. John Hewitt (ph) put together (ph) Jackson Hewitt and another Liberty Tax services. He`s interested in H&R Block. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: With worries about the economy and the stock market heating up, investors have been seeking the safety of bonds. For many that means Treasuries despite the puny returns. But if you can stomach more risk as some investment advisors believe corporate bonds are a better bet. Erika Miller looks at why you may want to consider jumping on the corporate bond boat.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: When sailing in choppy waters, boaters have life vests for safety. When it comes to market volatility, investors have their own form of protection: bonds. So far this year, investors have yanked nearly $11 trillion out of domestic stock funds. They`ve poured more than 10 times that amount into U.S. bond funds. The money is not just going into Treasury. Top quality corporate bonds are also benefiting from the flight to safety. But credit strategist Brad Rogoff believes high yield corporates, otherwise known as junk bonds, are a much better option.

BRADLEY ROGOFF, CO-HEAD, US CREDIT STRATEGY, BARCLAY`S CAPITAL: High yield bonds are paying on average, you know, 9 plus percent right now. Fundamentals are still improving for a lot of these companies. We`re seeing that come through as we get into earnings season right now.

MILLER: An easy way to get broad exposure to the corporate bond sector is to buy an exchange-traded fund. The Ishares high-yield corporate bond index is currently yielding 9 percent. The investment grade version is yielding 5 percent. Both are paying out a lot more than 10-year Treasuries which yield less than 3 percent. One of the biggest risks to corporate bonds is the possibility the Fed might start raising interest rates. Even if that happens, Rogoff thinks junk bonds will hold up fairly well.

ROGOFF: From a price standpoint, you will not see much of a move with respect to high-yield bonds. Obviously with a sizable coupon that they have on them that makes for an attractive investment in the current environment. Investment grade bonds will be much more sensitive to rates.

MILLER: Still financial planner Cliff Michaels believes investment grade bonds are the better bet these days because they have less likelihood of default.

CLIFFORD MICHAELS, CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER: If in fact we are double dipping -- I`m not in that camp necessarily -- but if we are slowing down, that would affect the corporate high-yield bond market, the junk bond market. So we are going much more for investment grade corporate bonds now.

MILLER: So you might think of investment grade then as more of a tanker than a sailboat, not terribly exciting but the safer option if seas get rough. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

GHARIB: And here`s what we`re watching for you for tomorrow. Housing starts for June come out. Analysts are expecting a second straight monthly fall. That`s due to the end of the home buyer tax credit. A big day for earnings -- results for Apple, Goldman Sachs, Johnson & Johnson and Pepsico. Also gold, our "Word on the Street" segment looks at lifelong strategies when it comes to investing in the precious metals.

A setback today for Ireland`s recovery. Moody`s downgraded the country`s credit rating. Moody`s lowered Ireland one notch. It still remains above junk level though. The ratings agency cited a weak banking system and rising debt. But Moody`s still boosted its outlook from Ireland from negative to stable, saying another downgrade is unlikely. Ireland was the first Eurozone nation to enter recession. It was out in the first quarter of this year.

HUDSON: Meanwhile major banks in Greece are expected to pass a series of stress tests. The country`s finance minister said today he`s certain they will. Six Greek banks are among the 91 undergoing stress tests by the European Union. The results are due Friday. The Greek government is considering a $911 million offer by a private bank to take control of two state lenders. Greece is said to be closely examining that proposal.

GHARIB: From tax cuts to curbing spending, tonight`s commentator is thinking about controlling our budget deficit. He`s Glen Hubbard, dean of Columbia University`s graduate school of business and former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors under President George W. Bush.

GLENN HUBBARD, GRADUATE SCHL. OF BUSINESS, COLUMBIA UNIV.: Many congressional leaders have suggested that tax revenues are too low and will remain low without a tax increase. This year`s Federal revenues will be about 15 percent of GDP, less than the 40-year average of about 18 percent. But revenues are already on track to exceed 23 percent of GDP in just 25 years, greater than in World War II. How would this happen?

First a recovery will boost revenues. And over time rising incomes will lift taxpayers into higher brackets, real bracket creep. And tax cuts from 2001 and 2003 and the 2009 stimulus will expire. New taxes are helping to pay for health care reform while the AMT not indexed for inflation will hike taxes for millions.

About a third of the revenue growth comes from expiring tax provisions, a third from real bracket creep and a third from remaining tax increases. Now the Congress is unlikely to let all tax cuts expire. So won`t we have a revenue gap exactly as congressional leaders argue? Not necessarily. We can extend the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts and limit the growth of the AMT and still have tax revenues more than 19 percent of GDP by the end of this decade, well over the 40-year average. The real question is whether we can keep Federal spending in check. If not, we will need to raise taxes and to levels well beyond the heights of World War II. I`m Glenn Hubbard.

HUDSON: And that is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on this Monday evening, July 19. That`s for joining us. I`m Tom Hudson. Good night. Have a great evening Susie.

GHARIB: Take care, Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Good night everyone. Hope to see all of you again tomorrow night.

END

urn:contentItem:516W-59B1-JBKP-N2MW-00000-00Nightly Business Report2010-10-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTBUSINESS100801cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The only piece of economic news that folks still looking for work want to hear is "you`re hired!"

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: But while thousands of Americans were hired, many more were fired, as the economy lost jobs for a fourth straight month in September.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: All told, nearly 15 million people in the country are out of work. We`ll look at how that`s playing out in the economy and the upcoming election. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, October 8.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone, 95,000 American workers lost jobs in September. And you know Tom, when you look at the numbers, there was some hiring by U.S. businesses, but just not enough to offset those huge cuts in government jobs.

HUDSON: No there wasn`t Susie, the Labor Department in fact said the unemployment rate did hold steady at 9.6 percent. But add in people who`ve stopped looking or who cannot find full-time work and the so-called underemployment rate is much higher: 17.1 percent.

GHARIB: That`s right and those dreary numbers could be the trigger for Federal Reserve policymakers to pump more money into the financial system, hoping to spur economic activity and hiring. Scott Gurvey reports.

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The employment report for September looks a lot like the report for August -- more government layoffs than new hires in the private sector. There are also signs cautious employers are making due with part-time and temporary workers, adding to the number of so-called underemployed. And with consumers still cutting spending to pay down debt, economist Chris Low sees the sluggish pattern continuing.

CHRISTOPHER LOW, CHIEF ECONOMIST, FTN FINANCIAL: The obvious bad news is that we`ve got an unacceptably high level of unemployment in the U.S. And we will continue to have an unacceptably high level of unemployment. The good news is that at least the economy is growing.

GURVEY: Growing yes, but job growth remains slow. So slow in fact it is not keeping up with population growth. The president`s top economist today admitted his disappointment with the data.

AUSTAN GOOLSBEE, WHITE HOUSE ECONOMIC ADVISER: It`s clearly the right trajectory, but it`s got to be much higher because this is the deepest hole since 1929.

GURVEY: Even with short-term interest rates near zero, JPMorgan`s Bruce Kasman says today`s employment report should prompt the central bank to take additional steps to stimulate growth by injecting more money into the economy.

BRUCE KASMAN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, JP MORGAN CHASE: This is a report which feeds that concern on the part of the Fed that they`re not hitting their mandate. And I think they made it clear that unless they feel that something has changed, they`re going to move towards asset purchases.

GURVEY: The Fed could announce plans to buy additional assets as early as next month. It meets in three weeks to review policy. Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Here are the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. That weak jobs market did not stop stocks from moving higher. At the closing bell, the Dow had gained 58 points, closing above 11,000 for the first time since May. The NASDAQ added 18, the S&P 500 up seven. Volume grew slightly from yesterday`s pace but still under one billion shares on the big board, just over two billion on the NASDAQ.

A big move today by Bank of America. It stopped sales of foreclosed homes nationwide for the next few weeks. The move comes amid growing concern about the validity of foreclosure documents. B of A had already stopped sales in 23 states where foreclosures must be OKd by a judge. Lawmakers on Capitol Hill weigh in on the foreclosure mess at a hearing scheduled for November 16. Two ranking Democrats want other lenders to follow Bank of America`s lead. Meantime, California lawmakers finally approved a budget, ending a record budget impasse and closing a $19 billion gap. Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger brokered this budget deal, which includes no new taxes or fees. And New Jersey`s governor will re-think his decision to cancel a rail tunnel between his state and Manhattan. Yesterday, Governor Chris Christie scrapped the nation`s biggest public transit project, saying the $14 billion price tag was too high. Still ahead, the neck-and-neck race for Nevada`s third congressional district. It`s one of the tightest election contests in the country and it`s all about economic survival. We`ll explain.

GHARIB: More analysis now on today`s jobs report that we told you about. Joining us from Washington, Mohamed el-Erian, CEO and co-chief investment officer at Pimco -- the world`s largest bond fund company. Hi, Mohamed, nice to see you again.

MOHAMED EL-ERIAN, CEO & CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, PIMCO: Hi, Susie. Thanks for having me on.

GHARIB: So what`s your take on this employment report? Did it tell you anything new about the state of the U.S. economy?

EL-ERIAN: There were some bright spots, but they were very limited. Overall it`s a disappointing report and it concerns an (ph) unemployment will remain the main economic, political and social issue going forward.

GHARIB: As we reported a moment ago, the markets rallied on speculation that the Federal Reserve is going to take some action to pump money into the economy. But we`ve had so many people come on our program saying that they don`t think that action will do much to pump up the economy. Where do you stand on that?

EL-ERIAN: You know, the market is torn right now. The unemployment numbers tell you that we have a very sluggish economy. We`re not creating enough jobs and state and local governments are shedding a lot of jobs. So the markets should not like that. However, the market says, ah, but because of this, the Fed is going to have to do more. The Fed is going to have to use its printing press to come and buy securities and therefore, that is going to be good for us. The way we look at it, Susie, is there is going to be two effects: one is technical and the markets have been pricing in the entry again of the Fed as a buyer of security. But the one we are most concerned about is the economics. We do not believe that this policy action will be sufficient to get this economy growing again, to get the unemployment rate well below where it is now.

GHARIB: Well, the other thing that we`re hearing and I think the American public is also hoping that these mid-term elections are going to make a difference. They`re hoping that a new Congress will be good for the economy. What`s your take on that?

EL-ERIAN: I hope so. We desperately need, Susie, a common objective and a common analysis of this country`s economic situation. Otherwise we are going to continue to face very sluggish growth and unacceptably high unemployment. Remember one in six Americans today is either unemployed or under employed which means those who are employed, those who have jobs become more cautious and spend less because they see how many people are unemployed.

GHARIB: Exactly. And we know that this is not a quick fix. Everybody says that. So if Congress can`t do much and the Fed might not be effective in all of this, so how do we improve the job market and the housing market where we continue to see massive foreclosures? Is it just a matter of a waiting game?

EL-ERIAN: Susie, what you say is important. It is about jobs. It is about housing. It is about structural change. This economy is going through a fundamental change and it`s very important to bring in the different agencies of government, with the Federal Reserve, in a room and have a common objective, have a common analysis and then have the political support for a comprehensive solution.

GHARIB: Now, you`re talking about here in the U.S. I know that you`re in Washington today at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund where there are hundreds of world leaders and finance ministers. If you had to compress it to one thought, what is it that everybody is talking about there when it comes to the economy?

EL-ERIAN: People are nervous. They don`t like the fact that the super power is facing these head winds. They also don`t like all of this brinksmanship and positioning over currencies and all these threats that have come out over the last through days. There is a sense in anxiety in the air. There`s a sense of tension. And the hope is that discussions over the weekend can lower this tension because it is not good for the global economy.

GHARIB: All right. We`ll leave it there. Thank you so much for coming on the program. It is always a pleasure to hear your thoughts.

EL-ERIAN: Thank you, Susie.

GHARIB: My guest tonight Mohamed el-Erian, CEO and co-chief investment officer at Pimco.

HUDSON: The major indices resumed their march higher this week with the Dow Industrials back over 11,000. So let`s get you updated in tonight`s "Market Focus." In five of the past six weeks, we`ve see stocks climb higher. The gains more modest this week. Take a look. We begin with the Dow Industrials (DJI) adding 1.6 percent, up three of the past five sessions. The NASDAQ (IXIC) up 1.3 percent compared to a week ago. Several big tech bellwethers do have earnings reports next week. We`ll mention one in a moment. The S&P 500 (GSPC) added 1.7 percent thanks to two days of gains this week.

While stocks resumed their climb this week, today the big moves in the grain markets. Corn (3CZ0), soybeans and wheat all rallied as much as they`re allowed to in one day. That`s called limit up. Here`s the past six months for corn. This high tonight is a two-year high, close to a two-year high. The government cut its harvest forecast today. Back in August, the U.S. Ag Department had predicted a record haul, no longer though. Bad weather gets the blame. Adding to the anxieties, corn leftover from last year`s harvest is down too. Scott Shelladay with XFA Futures says it`s not just a drop in U.S. crops that has the market spooked.

SCOTT SHELLADY, MANAGER, XFA FUTURES: The problems that we`ve had in China, the problems that we`ve had in Russia, Canada and Australia. If you overlay that on top of what we got today, we have a food issue in the world not just a corn issue. We`ve got less rice. We`ve got less oats. We`ve got less wheat.

HUDSON: Companies doing business in American farm fields did catch a bid on this grain rally. Deere (DE) and Caterpillar (CAT) each rallied to new 52-week highs on good volume. Fertilizer makers CF Industries (CF) and Agrium (AGU), these are also new 52-week highs. In fact CF Industries was the single biggest percentage gainer of the S&P 500 today, up almost 11.5 percent. The food price rally helped companies that help grow it. It hurt companies that have to buy it. Tyson (TSN) plummeted almost 8 percent on three times its usual volume. Tonight this is an eight-month low for this stock. Tyson is one of the world`s biggest meat processors buying loads of grain for feed. Smithfield (SFD) is another big meat processor. Its shares sank almost seven percent on big volume. Meat prices have been rising helping these companies, but higher food costs clearly are worrying the market today.

Retailer JC Penney (JCP) added to its rally we reported on last night as an activist hedge fund has been buying that and others. The stock added another three 3 percent on strong volume today. Hedge fund Pershing Square now controls almost 17 percent of the stock. This same fund disclosed an 11 percent stake in Fortune Brands (FO). That company best known for its Jim Beam whiskey and Titleist golf products. Fortune FO, the stock jumping more than 7 percent.

The ripple effect around Micron Technologies (MU) helped some chip makers. Micron added almost 7 percent on the trade today even after missing estimates in its most recent quarter. Revenues and margins though were up. It also has a new licensing deal with Samsung. Fellow memory chip maker Sandisk (SNDK) up 6 percent. Intel (INTC) makes a different kind of semiconductor. Its results are due out next week, just a fractional gain. A couple of new stocks come to market this week, including yet another Chinese IPO in the United States. Ellington Financial (EFC) first, it focuses on mortgage-related assets. It closed below its IPO price of $22.50. Chinese solar products maker Daqo (DQ) came public at $9.50 per share this week and clearly it moved higher. That is tonight`s "Market Focus."

The political party that controls Congress can affect your job and your retirement savings. It also affects businesses and our economy. The outcome of next month`s elections rides on candidates slugging it out in communities across the country. In tonight`s midterm 2010, it`s the economy election coverage, Darren Gersh looks at one district and how the economy is shaping the campaigns of the two people competing to represent it.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Nevada`s third congressional district is the most populous in the nation: one million people spread across a ring of suburbs, many just a few years old. And there is bipartisan agreement on the economic pain here. Representative Dina Titus, a Democrat, won her seat in 2008.

REP DINA TITUS, (D) NEVADA: The main thing I hear is jobs. We got to create jobs.

GERSH: And this is the Republican challenger Joe Heck. He`s seen the unemployment rate here -- the highest in the nation at over 14 percent -- hit his family. One daughter, a new college graduate, is having trouble finding work. Another daughter was laid off six months ago.

JOE HECK, (R) CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: She`s actually on unemployment trying to find another job.

GERSH: To say this election is about the economy doesn`t quite capture what is going on here. It`s more basic than that. For many people, it`s about survival which is why Titus emphasizes the basics when she talks to voters.

TITUS: I`m committed to helping them with the VA, with their Social Security, with their Medicare, with their foreclosure problem. And that`s what they need right now. It`s not the big theories or the big ideologies. It`s keeping body and soul together.

GERSH: And far from running from her vote for the Obama stimulus plan, she says it`s critical to Nevada`s future and saved jobs.

TITUS: A lot of people say the failed stimulus, the failed stimulus. Well, it saved 1800 jobs at the airport new terminal. I stood outside that at shift change one morning about 4:00 in the morning, shook a lot of hands and those were working hands and those are people who`d say, thank you. We needed to keep working.

GERSH: Joe Heck is also a doctor and his economic treatment plan begins with controlling spending.

HECK: And I think that goes back to looking at, do we need to go back to a certain year and cap spending at that level, control non-defense, discretionary spending.

GERSH: And he would remove what he calls the uncertainty over regulation and taxes.

HECK: We`ve got to make sure that we can instill confidence into those that are trying to create jobs by saying look, for a certain period of time, the `01-`03 tax cuts are going to remain in effect so you don`t have to worry about hiring somebody today only to worry about your taxes going up in January and then maybe having to let that person go in March.

GERSH: Their plans would move the country in opposite directions. But polls show this race is one of the tightest in the nation in Vegas terms, even money. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Las Vegas.

GHARIB: And here`s what we`re watching for you for next week. Our Friday "Market Monitor" guest is Stephen Wood. He`s chief market strategist at Russell Investments. We`ll also see quarterly results from some big tech companies including Intel, Google and AMD. And then on Monday, with oil prices hovering around $80, we`ll look at what even higher crude prices could do to a very slow economic recovery.

One of the world`s biggest drug companies is getting smaller. Sanofi Aventis today announced plans to cut a quarter of the jobs in its U.S. pharmaceutical business. That works out to about 1,700 people, mostly sales reps and administrative staff. Sanofi is slashing staff and costs to better face growing challenges to its products. Three of its four top selling drugs either have or are about to have, generic competitors.

HUDSON: Blackberry maker Research in Motion and the United Arab Emirates have reached a truce before a ban of the mobile devices was to take effect there. The Emirates was planning to shut Blackberry`s email, messaging and web services on Monday, shut them down due to security issues. That would have meant big problems for half a million local users and thousands of passengers who use Dubai`s airport every day. RIMM and the UAE offered few details on how things were worked out. However it appears the reprieve is permanent.

Safety has become the strategy for stock investors. So says tonight`s "Market Monitor." He`s Randall Eley, president of the Edgar Lomax Company, an investment advisory firm based in Springfield, Virginia. He joins us tonight from our Washington bureau. Randall, it`s nice to see you. Welcome back to NBR.

RANDALL ELEY, PRESIDENT, THE EDGAR LOMAX COMPANY: It is good to see you also, Tom.

HUDSON: So we have seen the economy growing slightly. We have seen private payrolls that are up over the last several months. So why play it so safe?

ELEY: Because of one factor, which at first is a good factor for the value of stocks and that`s long-term interest rates. When I was last with you about six months ago, the 10-year Treasury for example was yielding about 3.8 percent. We`re down to 2.4 percent today. So on the one hand, it makes us feel better about the current prices of stocks. But on the other hand, we know the Federal Reserve will not be able to keep interest rates this low forever. So the short rate being zero.

HUDSON: Right. So with that in mind, be a one-handed investor over the next 12 to 18 months. Cautious or even pessimistic when it comes to the overall stock market?

ELEY: Cautious in the intermediate term. I would even say feeling a bit warm toward the market in the short-term, three to six months, but pessimistic over the longer term.

HUDSON: It was April Fool`s day, no coincidence however, April 1st last time you were in that chair. A couple of stocks you liked back then were Pfizer and the Traveler`s Company. Clearly big firms here, kind of a split performance. You still like these two?

ELEY: I like both of them.

HUDSON: You also brought along AT&T and Merck. AT&T up 8 percent, Merck down 2 percent and you`re putting new money to work in Merck, MRK. Why do you still like this drug maker here?

ELEY: Here is a company which should do well, whatever the economic environment. And you get a very high dividend yield, 4.1 percent. So you`re almost twice the 10-year Treasury and this company ought to be a cash machine.

HUDSON: Any concern about Brandon Pharmaceuticals in the pipeline?

ELEY: No. Not at all. The company is so cash rich and earning so much, their research capability should be good.

HUDSON: Lots of folks like dividends these days and you`re looking for them elsewhere in the oil market, big oil here with Chevron, CVX, you like that. The stock here has been on a nice rally lately as oil pro prices have rebounded. Also like ExxonMobil, XOM, the world`s largest company which its stock price has not been responding as its others. Why these two?

ELEY: Not yet. These are clearly the leaders or certainly among the leaders. And the fact of life is they should continue to be profitable, strong balance sheets. Also, these companies do not need government assistance to the extent we run into any future credit crisis.

HUDSON: However, what if you see the economy weakening substantially and perhaps oil prices moving lower?

ELEY: There is no doubt the earnings would fall, but that is very different from raising questions about the ability to earn money as would be the case elsewhere.

HUDSON: You`re also looking at And Johnson & Johnson, not just a pharmaceutical company, but medical products across the board. The stock had fallen on hard times this summertime, but has seen a nice rebound here in the month of September and October. What`s to come?

ELEY: That`s right. With Johnson & Johnson, I think we`re getting a unique opportunity to buy a good earning situation because of the recent concerns. This company has a great history of getting through crisis. And I feel comfortable they will get through this one, too.

HUDSON: It is global and it`s dividend-seeking in the short-term. You mentioned about three months, maybe, for a holding period?

ELEY: Actually, I think all of these companies at three years is probably a good holding.

HUDSON: And you have positions for your clients?

ELEY: Yes. Well, for our clients, and I also own them.

HUDSON: All right, great. Some interesting picks here. We`ll catch up in another half year or so. Tonight`s "Market Monitor" this evening is Randall Eley, president of the Edgar Lomax Company.

GHARIB: And finally, companies are hiring, just not enough to make a dent in the unemployment rate. One person who found work in the past couple of months is Marci Sigel. She got a job in Miami as a nurse consultant. In a continuing series that we`re calling "You`re Hired" Sigel tells us about her journey on and off the unemployment line.

MARCI SIGEL, LEGAL NURSE CONSULTANT: My name is Marci Sigel and I was unemployed from November until August. I was at a private school that was an exclusive environment for dyslexic kids and we would all work together how to help these kids. If there was a teaching need, I would teach a science class and then I turned into administration. Over time, with the economy, they laid me off. Every day is a full-time job to look for a job. You have to sit there and spend hours writing your cover letters, writing your resume over again, sending them out, looking at different sites all day long.

After a while, when I realized I wasn`t able to go back to a hospital because I didn`t have two years recent clinical, when I kept getting turned down in that area, I knew that I had skills that I would have to diversify with. It just popped up. And then all of a sudden a few popped up in this industry and I just sent out the resume. I knew I could do it and I made that clear. I can do this work. About three months later I got a call. And she said, I`m very sorry and I thought she was going to say we`ve hired someone else. She said, we`d like to have you come in and talk about the job. I was like, you`re kidding me. Being employed is like a holiday all the time. There is no pressure. I can have a weekend. I can have an evening. I don`t have to go see if there is a job that has been posted. I don`t have to worry about how to not show face to the kids that I`m terrified. Yeah.

HUDSON: Pretty amazing story, Susie, 150,000 Americans have gotten jobs since August. She is one of them and hopefully in the months ahead we can bring more positive stories like that.

GHARIB: I was going to say the same thing. There are 15 million Americans who could learn a lot from Marci.

HUDSON: Stay positive, stay optimistic. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Friday evening, October 8th. Thanks for joining us. Have a great weekend. I`m Tom Hudson. Have a wonderful weekend too Susie.

GHARIB: Same to you, Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Have a great weekend everyone and we hope to see all of you again on Monday.
