BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The only piece of economic news that folks still looking for work want to hear is "you`re hired!"

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: But while thousands of Americans were hired, many more were fired, as the economy lost jobs for a fourth straight month in September.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: All told, nearly 15 million people in the country are out of work. We`ll look at how that`s playing out in the economy and the upcoming election. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, October 8.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone, 95,000 American workers lost jobs in September. And you know Tom, when you look at the numbers, there was some hiring by U.S. businesses, but just not enough to offset those huge cuts in government jobs.

HUDSON: No there wasn`t Susie, the Labor Department in fact said the unemployment rate did hold steady at 9.6 percent. But add in people who`ve stopped looking or who cannot find full-time work and the so-called underemployment rate is much higher: 17.1 percent.

GHARIB: That`s right and those dreary numbers could be the trigger for Federal Reserve policymakers to pump more money into the financial system, hoping to spur economic activity and hiring. Scott Gurvey reports.

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The employment report for September looks a lot like the report for August -- more government layoffs than new hires in the private sector. There are also signs cautious employers are making due with part-time and temporary workers, adding to the number of so-called underemployed. And with consumers still cutting spending to pay down debt, economist Chris Low sees the sluggish pattern continuing.

CHRISTOPHER LOW, CHIEF ECONOMIST, FTN FINANCIAL: The obvious bad news is that we`ve got an unacceptably high level of unemployment in the U.S. And we will continue to have an unacceptably high level of unemployment. The good news is that at least the economy is growing.

GURVEY: Growing yes, but job growth remains slow. So slow in fact it is not keeping up with population growth. The president`s top economist today admitted his disappointment with the data.

AUSTAN GOOLSBEE, WHITE HOUSE ECONOMIC ADVISER: It`s clearly the right trajectory, but it`s got to be much higher because this is the deepest hole since 1929.

GURVEY: Even with short-term interest rates near zero, JPMorgan`s Bruce Kasman says today`s employment report should prompt the central bank to take additional steps to stimulate growth by injecting more money into the economy.

BRUCE KASMAN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, JP MORGAN CHASE: This is a report which feeds that concern on the part of the Fed that they`re not hitting their mandate. And I think they made it clear that unless they feel that something has changed, they`re going to move towards asset purchases.

GURVEY: The Fed could announce plans to buy additional assets as early as next month. It meets in three weeks to review policy. Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Here are the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. That weak jobs market did not stop stocks from moving higher. At the closing bell, the Dow had gained 58 points, closing above 11,000 for the first time since May. The NASDAQ added 18, the S&P 500 up seven. Volume grew slightly from yesterday`s pace but still under one billion shares on the big board, just over two billion on the NASDAQ.

A big move today by Bank of America. It stopped sales of foreclosed homes nationwide for the next few weeks. The move comes amid growing concern about the validity of foreclosure documents. B of A had already stopped sales in 23 states where foreclosures must be OKd by a judge. Lawmakers on Capitol Hill weigh in on the foreclosure mess at a hearing scheduled for November 16. Two ranking Democrats want other lenders to follow Bank of America`s lead.

Meantime, California lawmakers finally approved a budget, ending a record budget impasse and closing a $19 billion gap. Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger brokered this budget deal, which includes no new taxes or fees. And New Jersey`s governor will re-think his decision to cancel a rail tunnel between his state and Manhattan. Yesterday, Governor Chris Christie scrapped the nation`s biggest public transit project, saying the $14 billion price tag was too high.

Still ahead, the neck-and-neck race for Nevada`s third congressional district. It`s one of the tightest election contests in the country and it`s all about economic survival. We`ll explain.

GHARIB: More analysis now on today`s jobs report that we told you about. Joining us from Washington, Mohamed el-Erian, CEO and co-chief investment officer at Pimco -- the world`s largest bond fund company. Hi, Mohamed, nice to see you again.

MOHAMED EL-ERIAN, CEO & CO-CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, PIMCO: Hi, Susie. Thanks for having me on.

GHARIB: So what`s your take on this employment report? Did it tell you anything new about the state of the U.S. economy?

EL-ERIAN: There were some bright spots, but they were very limited. Overall it`s a disappointing report and it concerns an (ph) unemployment will remain the main economic, political and social issue going forward.

GHARIB: As we reported a moment ago, the markets rallied on speculation that the Federal Reserve is going to take some action to pump money into the economy. But we`ve had so many people come on our program saying that they don`t think that action will do much to pump up the economy. Where do you stand on that?

EL-ERIAN: You know, the market is torn right now. The unemployment numbers tell you that we have a very sluggish economy. We`re not creating enough jobs and state and local governments are shedding a lot of jobs. So the markets should not like that. However, the market says, ah, but because of this, the Fed is going to have to do more. The Fed is going to have to use its printing press to come and buy securities and therefore, that is going to be good for us. The way we look at it, Susie, is there is going to be two effects: one is technical and the markets have been pricing in the entry again of the Fed as a buyer of security. But the one we are most concerned about is the economics. We do not believe that this policy action will be sufficient to get this economy growing again, to get the unemployment rate well below where it is now.

GHARIB: Well, the other thing that we`re hearing and I think the American public is also hoping that these mid-term elections are going to make a difference. They`re hoping that a new Congress will be good for the economy. What`s your take on that?

EL-ERIAN: I hope so. We desperately need, Susie, a common objective and a common analysis of this country`s economic situation. Otherwise we are going to continue to face very sluggish growth and unacceptably high unemployment. Remember one in six Americans today is either unemployed or under employed which means those who are employed, those who have jobs become more cautious and spend less because they see how many people are unemployed.

GHARIB: Exactly. And we know that this is not a quick fix. Everybody says that. So if Congress can`t do much and the Fed might not be effective in all of this, so how do we improve the job market and the housing market where we continue to see massive foreclosures? Is it just a matter of a waiting game?

EL-ERIAN: Susie, what you say is important. It is about jobs. It is about housing. It is about structural change. This economy is going through a fundamental change and it`s very important to bring in the different agencies of government, with the Federal Reserve, in a room and have a common objective, have a common analysis and then have the political support for a comprehensive solution.

GHARIB: Now, you`re talking about here in the U.S. I know that you`re in Washington today at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund where there are hundreds of world leaders and finance ministers. If you had to compress it to one thought, what is it that everybody is talking about there when it comes to the economy?

EL-ERIAN: People are nervous. They don`t like the fact that the super power is facing these head winds. They also don`t like all of this brinksmanship and positioning over currencies and all these threats that have come out over the last through days. There is a sense in anxiety in the air. There`s a sense of tension. And the hope is that discussions over the weekend can lower this tension because it is not good for the global economy.

GHARIB: All right. We`ll leave it there. Thank you so much for coming on the program. It is always a pleasure to hear your thoughts.

EL-ERIAN: Thank you, Susie.

GHARIB: My guest tonight Mohamed el-Erian, CEO and co-chief investment officer at Pimco.

HUDSON: The major indices resumed their march higher this week with the Dow Industrials back over 11,000. So let`s get you updated in tonight`s "Market Focus." In five of the past six weeks, we`ve see stocks climb higher. The gains more modest this week. Take a look. We begin with the Dow Industrials (DJI) adding 1.6 percent, up three of the past five sessions. The NASDAQ (IXIC) up 1.3 percent compared to a week ago. Several big tech bellwethers do have earnings reports next week. We`ll mention one in a moment. The S&P 500 (GSPC) added 1.7 percent thanks to two days of gains this week.

While stocks resumed their climb this week, today the big moves in the grain markets. Corn (3CZ0), soybeans and wheat all rallied as much as they`re allowed to in one day. That`s called limit up. Here`s the past six months for corn. This high tonight is a two-year high, close to a two-year high. The government cut its harvest forecast today. Back in August, the U.S. Ag Department had predicted a record haul, no longer though. Bad weather gets the blame. Adding to the anxieties, corn leftover from last year`s harvest is down too. Scott Shelladay with XFA Futures says it`s not just a drop in U.S. crops that has the market spooked.

SCOTT SHELLADY, MANAGER, XFA FUTURES: The problems that we`ve had in China, the problems that we`ve had in Russia, Canada and Australia. If you overlay that on top of what we got today, we have a food issue in the world not just a corn issue. We`ve got less rice. We`ve got less oats. We`ve got less wheat.

HUDSON: Companies doing business in American farm fields did catch a bid on this grain rally. Deere (DE) and Caterpillar (CAT) each rallied to new 52-week highs on good volume. Fertilizer makers CF Industries (CF) and Agrium (AGU), these are also new 52-week highs. In fact CF Industries was the single biggest percentage gainer of the S&P 500 today, up almost 11.5 percent. The food price rally helped companies that help grow it. It hurt companies that have to buy it. Tyson (TSN) plummeted almost 8 percent on three times its usual volume. Tonight this is an eight-month low for this stock. Tyson is one of the world`s biggest meat processors buying loads of grain for feed. Smithfield (SFD) is another big meat processor. Its shares sank almost seven percent on big volume. Meat prices have been rising helping these companies, but higher food costs clearly are worrying the market today.

Retailer JC Penney (JCP) added to its rally we reported on last night as an activist hedge fund has been buying that and others. The stock added another three 3 percent on strong volume today. Hedge fund Pershing Square now controls almost 17 percent of the stock. This same fund disclosed an 11 percent stake in Fortune Brands (FO). That company best known for its Jim Beam whiskey and Titleist golf products. Fortune FO, the stock jumping more than 7 percent.

The ripple effect around Micron Technologies (MU) helped some chip makers. Micron added almost 7 percent on the trade today even after missing estimates in its most recent quarter. Revenues and margins though were up. It also has a new licensing deal with Samsung. Fellow memory chip maker Sandisk (SNDK) up 6 percent. Intel (INTC) makes a different kind of semiconductor. Its results are due out next week, just a fractional gain.

A couple of new stocks come to market this week, including yet another Chinese IPO in the United States. Ellington Financial (EFC) first, it focuses on mortgage-related assets. It closed below its IPO price of $22.50. Chinese solar products maker Daqo (DQ) came public at $9.50 per share this week and clearly it moved higher. That is tonight`s "Market Focus."

The political party that controls Congress can affect your job and your retirement savings. It also affects businesses and our economy. The outcome of next month`s elections rides on candidates slugging it out in communities across the country. In tonight`s midterm 2010, it`s the economy election coverage, Darren Gersh looks at one district and how the economy is shaping the campaigns of the two people competing to represent it.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Nevada`s third congressional district is the most populous in the nation: one million people spread across a ring of suburbs, many just a few years old. And there is bipartisan agreement on the economic pain here. Representative Dina Titus, a Democrat, won her seat in 2008.

REP DINA TITUS, (D) NEVADA: The main thing I hear is jobs. We got to create jobs.

GERSH: And this is the Republican challenger Joe Heck. He`s seen the unemployment rate here -- the highest in the nation at over 14 percent -- hit his family. One daughter, a new college graduate, is having trouble finding work. Another daughter was laid off six months ago.

JOE HECK, (R) CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: She`s actually on unemployment trying to find another job.

GERSH: To say this election is about the economy doesn`t quite capture what is going on here. It`s more basic than that. For many people, it`s about survival which is why Titus emphasizes the basics when she talks to voters.

TITUS: I`m committed to helping them with the VA, with their Social Security, with their Medicare, with their foreclosure problem. And that`s what they need right now. It`s not the big theories or the big ideologies. It`s keeping body and soul together.

GERSH: And far from running from her vote for the Obama stimulus plan, she says it`s critical to Nevada`s future and saved jobs.

TITUS: A lot of people say the failed stimulus, the failed stimulus. Well, it saved 1800 jobs at the airport new terminal. I stood outside that at shift change one morning about 4:00 in the morning, shook a lot of hands and those were working hands and those are people who`d say, thank you. We needed to keep working.

GERSH: Joe Heck is also a doctor and his economic treatment plan begins with controlling spending.

HECK: And I think that goes back to looking at, do we need to go back to a certain year and cap spending at that level, control non-defense, discretionary spending.

GERSH: And he would remove what he calls the uncertainty over regulation and taxes.

HECK: We`ve got to make sure that we can instill confidence into those that are trying to create jobs by saying look, for a certain period of time, the `01-`03 tax cuts are going to remain in effect so you don`t have to worry about hiring somebody today only to worry about your taxes going up in January and then maybe having to let that person go in March.

GERSH: Their plans would move the country in opposite directions. But polls show this race is one of the tightest in the nation in Vegas terms, even money. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Las Vegas.

GHARIB: And here`s what we`re watching for you for next week. Our Friday "Market Monitor" guest is Stephen Wood. He`s chief market strategist at Russell Investments. We`ll also see quarterly results from some big tech companies including Intel, Google and AMD. And then on Monday, with oil prices hovering around $80, we`ll look at what even higher crude prices could do to a very slow economic recovery.

One of the world`s biggest drug companies is getting smaller. Sanofi Aventis today announced plans to cut a quarter of the jobs in its U.S. pharmaceutical business. That works out to about 1,700 people, mostly sales reps and administrative staff. Sanofi is slashing staff and costs to better face growing challenges to its products. Three of its four top selling drugs either have or are about to have, generic competitors.

HUDSON: Blackberry maker Research in Motion and the United Arab Emirates have reached a truce before a ban of the mobile devices was to take effect there. The Emirates was planning to shut Blackberry`s email, messaging and web services on Monday, shut them down due to security issues. That would have meant big problems for half a million local users and thousands of passengers who use Dubai`s airport every day. RIMM and the UAE offered few details on how things were worked out. However it appears the reprieve is permanent.

Safety has become the strategy for stock investors. So says tonight`s "Market Monitor." He`s Randall Eley, president of the Edgar Lomax Company, an investment advisory firm based in Springfield, Virginia. He joins us tonight from our Washington bureau. Randall, it`s nice to see you. Welcome back to NBR.

RANDALL ELEY, PRESIDENT, THE EDGAR LOMAX COMPANY: It is good to see you also, Tom.

HUDSON: So we have seen the economy growing slightly. We have seen private payrolls that are up over the last several months. So why play it so safe?

ELEY: Because of one factor, which at first is a good factor for the value of stocks and that`s long-term interest rates. When I was last with you about six months ago, the 10-year Treasury for example was yielding about 3.8 percent. We`re down to 2.4 percent today. So on the one hand, it makes us feel better about the current prices of stocks. But on the other hand, we know the Federal Reserve will not be able to keep interest rates this low forever. So the short rate being zero.

HUDSON: Right. So with that in mind, be a one-handed investor over the next 12 to 18 months. Cautious or even pessimistic when it comes to the overall stock market?

ELEY: Cautious in the intermediate term. I would even say feeling a bit warm toward the market in the short-term, three to six months, but pessimistic over the longer term.

HUDSON: It was April Fool`s day, no coincidence however, April 1st last time you were in that chair. A couple of stocks you liked back then were Pfizer and the Traveler`s Company. Clearly big firms here, kind of a split performance. You still like these two?

ELEY: I like both of them.

HUDSON: You also brought along AT&T and Merck. AT&T up 8 percent, Merck down 2 percent and you`re putting new money to work in Merck, MRK. Why do you still like this drug maker here?

ELEY: Here is a company which should do well, whatever the economic environment. And you get a very high dividend yield, 4.1 percent. So you`re almost twice the 10-year Treasury and this company ought to be a cash machine.

HUDSON: Any concern about Brandon Pharmaceuticals in the pipeline?

ELEY: No. Not at all. The company is so cash rich and earning so much, their research capability should be good.

HUDSON: Lots of folks like dividends these days and you`re looking for them elsewhere in the oil market, big oil here with Chevron, CVX, you like that. The stock here has been on a nice rally lately as oil pro prices have rebounded. Also like ExxonMobil, XOM, the world`s largest company which its stock price has not been responding as its others. Why these two?

ELEY: Not yet. These are clearly the leaders or certainly among the leaders. And the fact of life is they should continue to be profitable, strong balance sheets. Also, these companies do not need government assistance to the extent we run into any future credit crisis.

HUDSON: However, what if you see the economy weakening substantially and perhaps oil prices moving lower?

ELEY: There is no doubt the earnings would fall, but that is very different from raising questions about the ability to earn money as would be the case elsewhere.

HUDSON: You`re also looking at And Johnson & Johnson, not just a pharmaceutical company, but medical products across the board. The stock had fallen on hard times this summertime, but has seen a nice rebound here in the month of September and October. What`s to come?

ELEY: That`s right. With Johnson & Johnson, I think we`re getting a unique opportunity to buy a good earning situation because of the recent concerns. This company has a great history of getting through crisis. And I feel comfortable they will get through this one, too.

HUDSON: It is global and it`s dividend-seeking in the short-term. You mentioned about three months, maybe, for a holding period?

ELEY: Actually, I think all of these companies at three years is probably a good holding.

HUDSON: And you have positions for your clients?

ELEY: Yes. Well, for our clients, and I also own them.

HUDSON: All right, great. Some interesting picks here. We`ll catch up in another half year or so. Tonight`s "Market Monitor" this evening is Randall Eley, president of the Edgar Lomax Company.

GHARIB: And finally, companies are hiring, just not enough to make a dent in the unemployment rate. One person who found work in the past couple of months is Marci Sigel. She got a job in Miami as a nurse consultant. In a continuing series that we`re calling "You`re Hired" Sigel tells us about her journey on and off the unemployment line.

MARCI SIGEL, LEGAL NURSE CONSULTANT: My name is Marci Sigel and I was unemployed from November until August. I was at a private school that was an exclusive environment for dyslexic kids and we would all work together how to help these kids. If there was a teaching need, I would teach a science class and then I turned into administration. Over time, with the economy, they laid me off. Every day is a full-time job to look for a job. You have to sit there and spend hours writing your cover letters, writing your resume over again, sending them out, looking at different sites all day long.

After a while, when I realized I wasn`t able to go back to a hospital because I didn`t have two years recent clinical, when I kept getting turned down in that area, I knew that I had skills that I would have to diversify with. It just popped up. And then all of a sudden a few popped up in this industry and I just sent out the resume. I knew I could do it and I made that clear. I can do this work. About three months later I got a call. And she said, I`m very sorry and I thought she was going to say we`ve hired someone else. She said, we`d like to have you come in and talk about the job. I was like, you`re kidding me. Being employed is like a holiday all the time. There is no pressure. I can have a weekend. I can have an evening. I don`t have to go see if there is a job that has been posted. I don`t have to worry about how to not show face to the kids that I`m terrified. Yeah.

HUDSON: Pretty amazing story, Susie, 150,000 Americans have gotten jobs since August. She is one of them and hopefully in the months ahead we can bring more positive stories like that.

GHARIB: I was going to say the same thing. There are 15 million Americans who could learn a lot from Marci.

HUDSON: Stay positive, stay optimistic. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Friday evening, October 8th. Thanks for joining us. Have a great weekend. I`m Tom Hudson. Have a wonderful weekend too Susie.

GHARIB: Same to you, Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Have a great weekend everyone and we hope to see all of you again on Monday.

END

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: President Obama names his choice to lead the new government watchdog agency overseeing credit cards, mortgages, and other consumer lending.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From a new bank sheriff to buying bank shares. We`ll hear from one analyst who says now is the time to invest certain financial firms, and from another who says stay away. It`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 18th.

Good evening, everyone.

We`re less than a week away from President Obama`s deadline for raising the government`s debt ceiling. And, Tom, today the president said he and Republican lawmakers were, quote, "making progress" after a series of weekend meetings.

HUDSON: Yes, Susie, with the clock clearly continues to tick, and here are the latest developments tonight as we know them. The leader of the U.S. Senate says that chamber will meet every day until Congress sends the president legislation making sure Uncle Sam does not default on its obligations.

The U.S. House, meantime, is set to pass a budget "cut, cap, and balance" bill tomorrow. That includes a proposed budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution, but credit rating agency Moody`s (NYSE: MCO) says the U.S. would be better off if the debt ceiling was eliminated entirely.

GHARIB: Now the debt showdown wasn`t the only financial topic in the nation`s capital today. The president nominated Richard Cordray to be the nation`s top consumer loan advocate.

Darren Gersh has details.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The president vowed to fight back against what he called an army of lobbyists trying to weaken the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The agency was created to fight lending abuses that the president says were a leading cause of the financial crisis.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We are not just going to shrug our shoulders and hope it doesn`t happen again. We`re not going to go back to the status quo, where consumers couldn`t count on getting protections that they deserve. We`re not going to go back to a time when our whole economy was vulnerable to a massive financial crisis.

GERSH: To make sure that doesn`t happen, the president nominated Richard Cordray to be the CFPB`s first director. As Ohioattorney general, Cordray aggressively attacked fraudulent foreclosures.

Ernie Patrikis, an expert in banking regulation, says Cordray is a tough adversary.

ERNIE PATRIKIS, PARTNER, WHITE & CASE: He is not going to be a very easy fellow for some companies to get along with. He has a strong track record of going after people and he has done it in mortgage servicing. He did it against the rating agencies. So if he can ultimately control the agency, he`ll really move it.

GERSH: That`s if he gets confirmed by the Senate, and that will be a tough battle. Republicans are demanding more oversight of the CFPB`s proposed $550 million budget and a new leadership structure, replacing a single director with a five-member board.

That`s also the position of many banks, says the Financial Services Roundtable`s Scott Talbott.

SCOTT TALBOTT, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, FINANCIAL SERVICES ROUNDTABLE: We are for creating a five-person panel. It doesn`t dilute the total power of the CFPB, it simply spreads it out. So that if an idea is a good one, then let`s have a panel agree to it. That provides the checks and the balances necessary.

GERSH: One thing seems clear, without a strong leader in place, the CFPB is off to an uncertain start.

PATRIKIS: They will be doing a lot of thinking, a lot of preparatory work for what they want to do, organizing, drafting, but nothing will be effective.

GERSH: Consumer groups endorsed Cordray, but they were clearly disappointed the president sidestepped selecting Elizabeth Warren. The CFPB was her idea, and President Obama put her in charge of setting up the office, but she was considered too confrontational to have any chance of winning support from Senate Republicans.

Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: If Richard Cordray is confirmed, part of his job will be checking the books of big banks. And we`re going to get a better idea of how those books are doing in coming days when many report quarterly earnings. By the end of this week, 40 percent of financial firms in the S&P 500 will have reported their latest numbers.

As a group, the results are expected to be downright awful. Erika Miller reports.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Banks are the heartbeat of the economy, so their health is often used as a barometer of the recovery, and the stock market.

Unfortunately for investors, bank analyst Jim Sinegal sees plenty of uncertainties ahead.

JIM SINEGAL, BANK ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: In addition to macroeconomic uncertainties, you know, with unemployment high, GDP growth slow, you know, will the banks be able to add new loans? That`s number one. Number two is the regulatory uncertainty. We are still not sure exactly where capital levels are going to fall out, and how that`s going to affect profitability.

MILLER: As for profitability, diversified financials are expected to be the worst performer this earnings season, down 94 percent. This is the group that includes Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), Citi, and JPMorgan.

But there`s a catch. Take out Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), and earnings for the group are expected to rise 23 percent, better than the 8 percent gain for the overall market. Against that backdrop, analyst Jim Sinegal says now is a good time to buy select financial stocks: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo (NYSE: WFC), and U.S. Bancorp (NYSE: USB).

SINEGAL: We think if you stick to high quality names at current prices, current earnings, and with most of their capital problems behind them, you know, we think they are one of the best sectors in terms of investment opportunities.

MILLER: But Burt White of LPL Financial warns it`s too risky to buy any bank stocks now.

BURT WHITE, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, LPL FINANCIAL: We think that there are way too many questions and just not enough answers, between housing and foreclosures and the euro crisis and regulatory reform. Plus, just some of the simple negatives like a flat yield curve and zero interest rates, so they can`t earn money on money market reserves.

MILLER: Those concerns have weighed on stocks in the sector. The BKX Index of bank stocks has fallen nearly 20 percent from its high back in February. And if you are thinking of buying financial stocks for their dividends, think again. In their heyday in 2007, the group yielded 3.3 percent. Now they pay out just 1.8 percent, the lowest of any industry group in the S&P 500.

Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Still ahead tonight, the Murdoch mess. Rupert Murdoch`s News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is under scrutiny for questionable journalism on both sides of the Atlantic, but we`ll talk with an analyst who still likes the stock.

GHARIB: Government debt worries put investors in a selling mood today. At the close, the Dow lost 94 points, the NASDAQ fell nearly 25, the S&P 500 off almost 11. Now as for volume, 871 million shares were traded here at the Big Board and just shy of 1.8 billion at the NASDAQ.

Meanwhile, all that glitters is gold. The yellow metal closed above $1,600 for the first time ever. Gold for August delivery settled at $1,602 an ounce, up $12. That`s a record in dollar terms, but below the peak reached in the 1980s, after accounting for inflation.

Big layoffs announced late today at Cisco Systems (NASDAQ: CSCO). It will lay off 6,500 workers, or about 9 percent of its full-time workforce. Analysts predicted thousands of job cuts after Cisco announced plans to reorganize back in May. The company had been losing ground in the network equipment business. Cisco says the move will cut annual expenses by about $1 billion.

HUDSON: Big Blue saw a lot of green in the second quarter. The technology company continued its recent trend of reporting better-than- expected profits. Earnings were $0.06 better than estimates. Software, services, and hardware revenue each grew by double digits, leading IBM to raise its earnings guidance for the year. Tom Smith covers Big Blue, IBM as an analyst at Standard & Poor`s, and joins us tonight from New York.

Tom, strong quarter, any concerns for IBM?

THOMAS SMITH, ANALYST, STANDARD & POOR`S: Well, I think it was a pretty bright quarter all around. And despite some weakness in Japan as a regional territory, Japan was weak in the aftermath of the earthquake.

HUDSON: Now we saw some of the double-digit revenue increases across the board, the backlog of service contracts is up as well. Big growth in software systems and services, which is the big money-maker. The outlook looks pretty bright, so what should shareholders be paying attention to closely.

SMITH: Well, the outlook is pretty bright. Going back to your prior question, you could tone down your enthusiasm a little bit because some of the top line reporting of revenues based on currency tailwind, nevertheless, 5 percent same currency base as revenue growth for the company overall is pretty good.

So it is looking ahead I think we have to see whether the strength in hardware can continue because they had new fresh batch of machines last September. And those are now about a year dated. And they will pull -- they pulled a lot of orders for three quarters now and that will continue, and software and services get added on to that. Can that continue for another year or so? That is one question in mind.

HUDSON: At least initially it seems like the shareholders were pretty encouraged that it can. The share price looks to pop to possibly a new high after hours, certainly it did. If that continues through tomorrow it will be close to $180 per share. What is your outlook for the stock?

SMITH: That`s right. Well, our outlook has been a strong buy going into the report, and remains a strong buy afterwards. And I was able to raise my earnings estimate and also push my 12-month target price from $196 to $205. So I`m even more optimistic, and yet the share price is improving on this. You hope that it can carry through.

One knock on IBM, sometimes it`s so big it can`t increase revenues. But they had a pretty good quarter on revenues.

HUDSON: It`s a big revenue already and seeing it grow by double digits across some of the business units. What does this mean, though? Extrapolate IBM`s performance for Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ). What does it mean for HP?

SMITH: Well, I think for HP and maybe for Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) too, a big data center conglomerate, if you will, is that there is interest in enterprises and governments and non-profits. Governments were a little bit weaker as a buying source. But as opposed to discretionary consumer hardware, the enterprise business for data centers is still pretty strong.

So that caters to quite a bit of what HP does and a lot of what Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) does. Those two, of course, are exposed to PCs, which are much more -- which have a business component and a discretionary component. That discretionary component makes those two look a little slower in that sense in terms of revenue or more volatile in their results.

HUDSON: OK. And we`ll.

SMITH: You know, part of IBM`s.

HUDSON: Well, we`ll see those in the weeks ahead, sorry for cutting you off here, time is short. A quick look at IBM after the close, there.

SMITH: Thank you.

HUDSON: Tom, we appreciate it. Tom Smith, he`s with Standard & Poor`s.

Well, ahead of those IBM -- news, stocks were weak to the government debt worries continuing, in Europe and the United States. So let`s go ahead and roll out with tonight`s "Market Focus."

It was an 11-point drop for the S&P 500, and takes the index down to the lowest level we`ve seen in a month. So let`s go ahead and take a look at the last 90 sessions. Here we are. We`re going to zoom in now with the March low remaining intact.

Here it is, on the far side of the screen. The index, though, was unable to crest above the highs that we saw during the April months, during the bounce-back that we had back in June. And we`re -- here we are at the lowest part in the past month. One area to watch clearly is the lows that we had back in June.

Technology, meantime, compare it to the past 90 sessions of the NASDAQ 100 Exchange-Traded Fund, it was down 0.5 percent today, but, look, it`s not nearly as low compared to a month ago, where it was. The tech sector has held up better in the past recent weeks compared to the broad market, thanks to this broad move higher late last month. It was the best sector today in the weak market.

The market focus clearly on IBM tomorrow after the earnings, but also on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), which reports earnings after the close tomorrow. Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) among the strongest technology stocks, a bit of a technology burst ourselves here on screen. This does take Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) shares up to a new 52-week high. It`s a 2.4 percent increase. Volume was stronger with the action pulling Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) to its highest price it has ever seen.

Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) reportedly is close to a new deal to sell its iPhone in China. We`ll have more on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) and its growth prospects on tomorrow night`s program.

How about B. of A., meantime? Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) jumping to a new high, Bank of America (NYSE: BAC) stock continues sinking down to new two- year lows. B. of A. shares down another 2.8 percent, the biggest loser among the Dow Industrial Components, and the financial sector clearly weighing on the market today.

Not just big banks, it was insurance stocks as well facing some of the worst selling that we saw in the broad market. Late Friday, S&P warned the credit ratings of insurers holding U.S. government debt would be in jeopardy if there is no debt deal in Washington.

Genworth falling more than 7.5 percent, a new 52-week low tonight. We`ve got Allstate (NYSE: ALL) shedding 5 percent, its lowest price since last August, and Hartford falling almost 4 percent, that is its lowest price of this year.

Between the potential push higher on mortgage rates, if there is no debt deal and the struggling job market, a look at the homebuilder confidence here, continuing to see some weakness here, off by another 1.5 percent. The Homebuilder Exchange-Traded Fund falling and now threatening some of the lows just from last month.

Also coming back to earth significantly, Delta Air Lines stock. Look at this continued push lower here, off another 4 percent. Earnings are expected tomorrow. And the stock has been trending lower really since late last year thanks to the soft patch of economic news and oil prices remaining over $90 per barrel.

Some analysts worry with no debt deal, airlines could see higher interest costs for their borrowing. Clearly some selling continuing ahead of its earnings call.

Chinese solar panel maker LDK, meantime, has faded to its lowest stock price in a year, off another 3 percent today. It is the latest Chinese firm to face questions about governance. In a report from Fitch Ratings, raised issue with the concentrated stock ownership structure as well as wild swings in profit margins, leading to the selling pressure we saw today.

Finally, it`s not often that celebrity gossip finds its way into the stock market, but retailer Kohl`s (NYSE: KSS) has plans to launch a clothing line by Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony. The company says it will continue to do that. It will start in September, despite the two announcing their divorce late last week. The stock price coming off its most recent high, off about 1 percent.

And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is in for another week of scrutiny as that phone-hacking scandal escalates. Late today, Standard & Poor`s ratings service put the media giant on credit watch with "negative implications," saying there are increased risks related to the broadening legal issues at News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS).

Now the action comes a day before CEO Rupert Murdoch and his son, James, testify before the British Parliament tomorrow morning. But our guest tonight says News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). stock is still his top pick. Joining us now, Jason Bazinet. He is media analyst at Citigroup (NYSE: C).

Hi, Jason, nice to you have with us.

JASON BAZINET, MEDIA ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Thank you so much.

GHARIB: Let`s start right off with that stock. It has been down sharply since this scandal broke. And you said in a Citi report that News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is, quote, "too compelling to ignore." Tell us why you are so bullish on the stock?

BAZINET: Well, there are a couple of reasons the stock is down so much. One is several weeks ago people expected News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). to consolidate all of BSkyB, and now that is not happening. That is disappointing to investors.

And second you have got this broadening scandal. But when we look at the numbers News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is trading about 10 times forward earnings. And importantly, they have about $12 billion of cash on the balance sheet. If you make that adjustment and remove the cash from their market capitalization, it`s trading closer to 6.5 times earnings. That`s too compelling to ignore.

GHARIB: What about some of the other issues that are on the worry list for investors? And we listed some of them on the screen here. Let`s take a look. One of the worries is, what if News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is forced to sell its British newspaper holdings? What if U.K. regulators force the company to sell its stakes that it already owns in BSkyB satellite? News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). could also lose its TV licenses if U.S. regulators say that News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is no longer fit to own American television properties.

There is a question about leadership change at the top. If Rupert Murdoch steps down or is kicked out as CEO. And what -- you know, will any of the senior execs be indicted or go to jail? So what impact do these issues have? What are the financial implications?

BAZINET: Well, if I can remember that list, let me try and go through them. The disposition of the newspaper assets in the U.K. is really inconsequential. News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). does 4.5 million nominally of operating income a year. Those assets do about 70 million. So we`re talking about less than 2 percent of the operating income. And to the Street they`re a distraction. So if those end up getting sold, it doesn`t really matter.

The second risk you mentioned, I believe, was the potential disposition of the 39 percent stake they have in BSkyB.

GHARIB: BSkyB, right.

BAZINET: Yes. You know, the Street likes that asset, but at the end of the day if they end up selling that asset, something is going to have to happen to that 12 billion of cash that was sitting on the balance sheet that was going to be used to buy in the rest of BSkyB. So not only will News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). holders get cash for the sale of the 39 percent stake, but that other 12 billion will come back to equity holders. And that is why I focused on that, you know, mid single-digit P/E ex the cash.

The TV station sale, I think, was the third risk you mentioned. You know, the Street likes the TV station business. They have got retransmission fees coming. The reality of, I think, this risk is actually quite low. There was a case that took place in the 1960s. RKO got into some trouble with the government. They didn`t end up disposing of all of their assets, even though the FCC told them to, until 1990. I mean, it really was decades in the making.

So I don`t think that is a real near-term risk. But, again, even if it is, you are going to see more cash come into News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). The cash balance will rise by another $5 billion or so. So I don`t think it is a major risk.

GHARIB: All right. So a lot of good money aspects to it. But what about if Rupert Murdoch steps down as CEO, is that a positive or a negative for the company?

BAZINET: Well, John Malone, who is another CEO of another media company, was once asked about Rupert Murdoch`s mortality and succession planning. And he somewhat famously quipped: "half of News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). shareholders are afraid Rupert Murdoch will live and the other half are afraid he will die."

What he meant by that was people think Mr. Murdoch is an intelligent man, but there have been times in the past when he has, at least in the eyes of shareholders, misallocated capital. So changing the guard, again, I think is sort of a mixed bag. It doesn`t necessarily mean it`s negative for News.

GHARIB: All right. Very interesting information. We`ll see what happens tomorrow at those hearings in the U.K. Parliament. Thank you so much, Jason.

BAZINET: Very good. Thank you.

GHARIB: And we`ve been speaking with Jason Bazinet, he`s media analyst at Citigroup (NYSE: C).

HUDSON: Here is what we are watching for tomorrow. We`ve got another check on the housing sector due in, the June numbers on housing starts and building permits. Plenty of earnings as well, a couple from all-American brands Coca-Cola (NYSE: KO) and Harley-Davidson (NYSE: HOG).

And a couple of big tech giants reporting too. We`ll see how the iPad is adding to Apple`s bottom line and whether Yahoo (NASDAQ: YHOO)! is gaining ground in the world of Internet search advertising.

GHARIB: Borders bookstore plans to write its last chapter this week after a weekend deadline passed without a bidder to keep it in business. Late today, Borders said it will ask a judge to approve its liquidation on Thursday. It will begin on Friday and wrap up by September.

Borders employs nearly 11,000 people. The company blames its demise on changes in the book industry and the popularity of the e-reader.

HUDSON: Speaking about downsizing your car for something with better gas mileage, you may save a little money by waiting a little longer. According to Kelley Blue Book, the average price of a new compact car cost a record $20,500 last month, but it is expected to fall to about $19,300 by the end of the year. They see a similar trend with used cars too, dropping from over $11,000 down to under $10,000.

The debate over the debt ceiling can also be seen as the latest blame game. There is a lot of finger-pointing going, but still no deal. Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and former chief economist to Vice President Joe Biden.

JARED BERNSTEIN, SENIOR FELLOW, CENTER ON BUDGET AND POLICY PRIORITIES : The last time I offered a commentary here, I began by observing that the current debate over economic policy is generating a lot more heat than light.

Since then, it has gotten much hotter and a lot darker. If Congress fails to raise the debt ceiling by August 2nd, just a few days from now, we could end up taking an economic hit as devastating as it is avoidable. That`s right, this wound will be self-inflicted. How did it come to this? The answer is politics, and it`s an ugly, destabilizing politics of a type we haven`t seen in this country for many years.

Ask yourself, are House Republicans refusing to countenance any budget deal that includes tax revenues from closing a break for buyers of private jets because they think it`s bad economics? Or is it because almost every one of them signed the Grover Norquist pledge that they would never raise taxes under any circumstances?

In a sense, it`s a trivial example. Closing that loophole would have virtually no effect at all on our long-term budget deficit. But in another sense, it`s the crux of the matter. Fierce partisanship is one thing, and it`s clearly part of the American political landscape.

We have profound differences and a political system that allows those differences to be both heard and embodied in our policies. But at the end of the day, our history shows that partisans compromise in the interest of preserving the common good. Those who refuse to do so have no place in this debate.

They are not legislators, working with their opponents to hammer out the best deal for both their constituents and the nation. They`re pledge- takers who are threatening to abandon the common good for narrow self- interest. And that must not stand.

I`m Jared Bernstein.

HUDSON: Obviously there`s a lot here to be said and Jared won`t have the last word on the debt debate. In the coming days and weeks, we`ll continue to bring you thoughts and views from all sides.

GHARIB: And finally tonight, hold on to your cell phones if you plan to visit Miami, New York, or Los Angeles. According to a recent study by mobile security company Lookout, those are the three top cities for cell phone loss or theft. The remainder of the list spans coast to coast. It includes Phoenix, Sacramento, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Philadelphia, and Tampa.

Basically everywhere, Tom. And pools, taxis, and airplanes are the top three worst places to lose your cell phone. And that`s why I always have mine right next to me so I don`t lose it, can`t live without it.

HUDSON: Top of my list, toddlers, a tough place to lose a cell phone as well, toddlers.

GHARIB: That`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 18th. I`m Susie Gharib. Have a great evening, everyone.

You too, Tom.

HUDSON: You, as well, Susie.

I`m Tom Hudson. Good night, thanks for joining us this evening. We`ll see you right back here tomorrow.

urn:contentItem:43X4-28X0-008R-X312-00000-00Nightly Business Report2001-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT (NBR 6:30 pm ET)Carly Fiorini, Michael Capellas, David DaboraBUSINESS090401cb.118Nightly Business ReportPaul Kangas, Susie Gharib

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
 
PAUL KANGAS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: In computers, two plus four equals one. The number two and number four computer makers, Compaq (CPQ)and Hewlett Packard (HP), are merging to become the world's number one PC seller. Good evening, I'm Paul Kangas in Miami.
 
SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: I'm Susie Gharib, in New York City. I talked with the CEOs of both firms to get their take on the deal. My interview with Carly Fiorina and Michael Capellas coming up.

And good economic news gave Wall Street a big boost, but the rally fizzled. By the closing bell, the Dow gained 47 points; and the NASDAQ lost 34.
 
GHARIB: Good evening, everyone. A mega merger in the computer industry: Hewlett Packard is buying Compaq Computer for $25 billion, creating the world's biggest maker of personal computers. The reaction on Wall Street was skeptical. Both stocks fell sharply on the news. We have two reports this evening, a look at details of the deal, and the regulatory issues. We begin with Scott Gurvey on Wall Street.
 
SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The companies say this is a great deal, but Wall Street is not convinced. Hewlett-Packard plus Compaq, using year 2000 figures, would mean $91.2 billion in sales, $4.3 billion in net income and 159,800 employees. It would be the number one worldwide maker of personal computers, and it would come within a hairs- breadth of IBM (IBM) in revenue. So why did HP shares fall a whopping 19 percent in today's trading, while Compaq shares lost 10 percent on the news?
 
SHEBLY SEYRAFI, ENTERPRISE ANALYST, A.G. EDWARDS: When you have companies like Compaq and Hewlett, which have problems already in each company, just because you get them together doesn't mean you're going to a solve a lot of these problems.
 
GURVEY: The problems include a historic sales slump. Wall Street is asking if it makes sense to create a company number one in sales for a "comoditized" product?
 
CARLY FIORINA, CEO, HEWLETT-PACKARD: I think this deal perhaps makes particularly sense - particularly good sense in tough times for technology, because what those tough times are illustrating clearly is that there is an opportunity to get more cost effective and efficient.
 
GURVEY: Getting cost effective will mean a 10 percent cut in jobs, and even then analysts wonder if a combined Hewlett Packard can match the industry's low cost producer.
 
STEVEN FORTUNA, PC ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: There's going to be distraction issues around this acquisition and integration effort that could benefit Dell in the short medium term, because they're going to be keeping to their knitting whereas these guys are more about integrating their very complex business areas.
 
GURVEY: Integrating two giants into a colossus is always difficult. Compaq's CEO Says it can be done.
 
MICHAEL CAPELLAS, CEO, COMPAQ: The economics are clear, the strategic fit is clear, will the chemistry and the culture work? And when you could actually watch it is when you can sort of say, "yes, this is actually going to work."
 
GURVEY: Analysts say more deals in the sector are likely, although they will be due more to necessity than to opportunity.
 
MEAN GRAHAM-HACKETT, COMPUTER ANALYST, STANDARD & POOR'S: I think that it's a deal that needed to be done to take out excess capacity in the PC and server industry. But I don't think the combined entity is a much stronger player than they would have been on their own six months ago.
 
GURVEY: The companies hope to close the deal in the first half of next year. Scott Gurvey, "NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT," New York.
 
DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: This is Darren Gersh in Washington. Weeks ago, Hewlett-Packard and Compaq set up a special committee to study the anti- trust issues raised by this high-tech marriage. And after careful review, HP CEO Carly Fiorina says she's confident there will be no surprises like the European Commission's decision to block the GE (GE)-Honeywell (HON) merger. To begin with, this is a different deal in a very different industry.
 
CARLY FIORINI, CEO, HEWLETT PACKARD: This is an industry with millions of customers, not a couple. It is an industry with very low barriers to entry, particularly the PC and low end of the server business. It's an industry with intense competition.
 
GERSH: If approved, HP's deal to buy Compaq will create the industry's leading consumer brand, with a 19 percent share of worldwide computer sales-Dell (DELL) is second with 14 percent, IBM Next at 7 percent. For servers the combined HP would command would command an even larger sharet, 31 percent, versus 25 percent for IBM and 15 percent for Sun Microsystems (SUNW). Numbers like that will surely raise red flags with antitrust regulators in the US And Europe, but former Justice Department official, Will Tom, does not think his former colleagues will be mesmerized by market share. Even in the server market, Tom says there is fierce competition.
 
WILL TOM, ANTITRUST ATTORNEY, MORGAN, LEWIS & BOCKIUS: The operating systems on which they run are out there and so there aren't a lot of barriers that would keep either existing competitors from expanding, or new competitors from penetrating that space.
 
GERSH: Compaq and Hewlett Packard dominate PC sales at retail stores, but the companies argue competition from the Internet will keep prices down. Rapidly changing technology may also reassure regulators that competition will not be harmed.
 
CHRISTOPHER KELLY, ANTITRUST LAWYER, KAYE SCHOLER LLP: It is very, very difficult to know what the industry is going to be like, let alone who is going to be in it two years from now.
 
GERSH: But antitrust experts say the technology involved in this merger is complex, and may extend the time it takes regulators to review the deal. Darren Gersh, "NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT," Washington.
 
KANGAS: Stocks on Wall Street opened modestly lower due to some carryover selling from last week's 4.5 percent drop in the Dow and 5.8 percent tumble in the NASDAQ index. At the outset of trading, the Dow fell 50 points and the NASDAQ 15 points before the market steadied and then firmed up as that massive Hewlett/Packard-Compaq Computer combination seemed to stir some bullish enthusiasm. By 10:00 AM, The Dow posted a 15-point gain and NASDAQ cut its loss to four points. Then came the release of the National Purchasing Management's August manufacturing Activity Index which showed marked improvement in production and new orders, suggesting a number of industries are starting to recover. Judging by the spirited stock rally which followed, that was the news Wall Street wanted to hear. By 12:30 PM, The Industrial average was sporting a 212 point, or 2.1 percent, gain at the 10,160 level and the NASDAQ index was up 24 points or 1.3 percent. The rally topped out in the afternoon partly due to a less than impressive advance decline ratio and trading. Hardly helping were sizeable losses in both Hewlett Packard and Compaq stocks. The Dow industrial average saw its closing gain slashed to only 47.74 putting it a 9997.49. The NASDAQ index closed with a loss of 34.65 or 1.9 percent. Now stands at 1770.78.
 
Big board - well, here we go to the Dow Transports Index up 22.24.
 
The Utility Index up 1.73, but not as good as they were during the day.
 
The Closing Tick just barely bullish at +177.
 
Standard & Poor's 500 down .64.
 
And the S&P 100 up .64..
 
The MidCap 400 down 1.52.
 
And a loss of 1.20 in the CRB Bridge Futures Price Index a gain of nearly 13/4 in the New York Stock Exchange
 
Composite Index
 
Value Line down 1.28.
 
The Russell2000 Small Cap off 160.
 
And the Wilshire 5000 lost just over 9 points.
 
Bond prices posted sharp losses today mostly because that unexpectedly strong Purchasing Manager's report brightened hopes for a comeback in the economy while dimming the prospects for more interest rate cuts. Also this market was very vulnerable to profit taking after last week's strong advance which sent some yields to the lowest levels in about two years.
 
At the close tax free and corporate issues were down 3/4 to one full point.
 
And most Treasuries were down even more than that, not the 5-year notes but down 20/32 nevertheless.
 
A one point loss in the 10-year notes
 
And the Bellwether 30-year bond down 1 22/32.
 
And finally the Lehman Brothers Long-Term Treasury Bond Index down 27 1/10 point. Big loss there.
 
I'll be back shortly to show you where the action was on Wall Street today. Susie.
 
GHARIB: Thanks, Paul.
 
GHARIB: Back now to our top story, that $25 billion merger between Hewlett- Packard and Compaq. Earlier today, I talked to the CEOs of both companies. I began by asking Carly Fiorina of Hewlett-Packard why she did the deal.
 
CARLY FIORINA, CEO, HEWLETT-PACKARD: We're doing this deal because the technology landscape is changing fundamentally and has been for a couple of years now. Customers are demanding different things of their I.T. partners, and I mean consumers as well as businesses. And if you look at the power of these two companies together-and we've looked at it very carefully-it's clear that we can deliver a much improved value proposition to customers and we're creating, we think, a game changing move here.
 
GHARIB: Mr. Capellas, what is Compaq getting out of the deal? It's obviously not a merger of equals. The new company is going to be called Hewlett-Packard and you're going to be the number two person in charge.
 
MICHAEL CAPELLAS, CEO, COMPAQ: If you look at the combination of first the products and the markets we serve, there is an unbelievable national synergy. We have high end computation. We have great Web servers. There's a great storage play that comes together. There is a UNIX play. There's software that brings it together. The products are complementary.
 
In terms of number two, I'm absolutely comfortable with making this contribution. I am absolutely comfortable with the relationship. I absolutely intend to stay on and do what I can and-
 
FIORINA: And I'm delighted to have him as a partner, absolutely delighted.
 
CAPELLAS: This is a-yes, this is honestly not an issue. As long as we serve employees and serve customers, I'm in good shape.
 
GHARIB: Is it fair to say that Compaq couldn't make it alone?
 
CAPELLAS: I would argue that we had put an awful lot of the tough work behind us. We've gone through a very fast and effective cost reduction program. We worked very quickly to get our distribution model in good shape. And so, and, in fact, what you're seeing is because we're both making progress towards where we want to go, that made this possible to do. So I don't think we would be here at all if we weren't actually sort of headed down a common path.
 
FIORINA: I also think, Susie, if I may, each of these companies individually were strong companies.
 
CAPELLAS: Absolutely.
 
FIORINA: Good balance sheets, lots of scope and scale, wonderful employees. This is about a game changer.
 
CAPELLAS: Absolutely.
 
FIORINA: We are changing the game and we are playing to win, and that's why we've done this.
 
GHARIB: Well, execution. One of the big questions is how are you going to put together two massive companies, two companies that are facing strategic and tactical challenges and in an economic climate that's also very challenging? And yet you're so confident.
 
FIORINA: Well, I think we are confident we can do this and we are also sober about what it takes to do it. And by the way, I think the fact that we're sober makes us confident. There's no question there's a lot of work to do here. But the first thing you've got to know is we have planned it out pretty carefully. In fact, we had done detailed business plans and detailed integration plans before we ever called the first banker. And the reason we did that is because we wanted to be sure are we aligned in terms of the value drivers of this combination? We've thought about it, we've planned it, we have the key people in place, we have the key decisions already made. And so we think we are in a position when we get regulatory approval to execute with that discipline and speed and decisiveness. And we recognize we're going to have to prove that to people.
 
GHARIB: Mr. Capellas, you know how hard it is to put together two big tech companies. I mean some people would say that the Compaq/Digital Equipment merger was not all that successful. What are you confident about this deal?
 
CAPELLAS: What you have to look at is when you see the compelling opportunities and the vision to really become a value leading company in the industry, you have a compelling vision to get there. This is not about what the two are doing individually. It's about collectively the growth opportunities you have. And as you look forward to the industry, this industry will grow. Growth will come back and when it does, this is a powerful, compelling vision. The second one is, I think you've got some lessons learned and I think you have to apply those lessons learned, which is be decisive, stay absolutely consistent to your road map and move forward.
 
GHARIB: Wall Street is saying that this deal is fraught with risk. What do you think is the biggest risk, Ms. Fiorina?
 
FIORINA: Well, I think clearly execution is a risk. Now, we think we have mitigated that risk by planning for it carefully and, indeed, I think Michael deservedly gets credit for having completed the acquisition of Digital in an effective way. And so we are learning the lessons Michael learned and applying them.
 
GHARIB: The Wall Street reaction has been very skeptical, both of your stocks suffering on the news. What is Wall Street missing here?
 
CAPELLAS: Well, I think the first place is this is a really big deal and it has, you know, huge, huge implications for the industry. And so I think, as Carly absolutely said, is in a tough market people are going to take a little time to look at the news, to digest it and to understand it overall.
 
GHARIB: Investors are already looking at Hewlett Packard itself with some creditability issues. How are you going to sell this deal to shareholders?
 
FIORINA: Well, we're going to sell it by being clear around why we did it, clear around what the value is both in terms of the bottom line and the top line, and clear, as well, in terms of the execution and then we're going to go do it.
 
GHARIB: Thank you both very much. Good luck to you.
 
FIORINA: Thanks.
 
GHARIB: Miss Fiorina, Michael Capellas, thank you very much.
 
CAPELLAS: Thank you so much.
 
FIORINA: Thanks.
 
KANGAS: What a rally-and then what a sell-off. It was bad in both directions, depending on how you stand in the market. But the Dow up only 47 3/4 points after being up well over 200. The advance/decline ratio none too impressive, about 8 to 7 in favor of advancers. 153 new yearly highs, though. Only 76 new lows.
 
Compaq (CPQ) topped the active list on 57.2 million shares. It traded as low as $10.75 and finally closed at $11.08. That stock swap with Hewlett- Packard (HWP) is worth about $12 as of today and that's, of course, after Hewlett's stock dropped $4.34.
 
Then Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), the big point gainer in the Dow, up $3.44, the company claiming its new Cortistent reduces to zero the chances of arteries reclogging. That's known as restenosis.
 
GE (GE) down $0.15.
 
Providian Financial (PVN) had a bad day, down $8.70. The company sees third quarter earnings coming in at $0.82 to $0.84, the Street expecting $0.89. The company also says 2002 earnings will be lower than expected. Banc of America and First Boston among
 
just a few brokerages to downgrade the stock.
 
Lucent (LU) down $0.30.
 
AOL Time Warner (AOL) moved up $0.15.
 
Nokia (NOK) a $0.74 loss.
 
And then the NASDAQ Cubes (QQ) down $1.16.
 
Citigroup, tenth in volume, was up $0.41.
 
Royal Ahold (AHO), this is the huge Dutch grocery chain owner, down $1.59 on news the company is going to buy Alient Exchange. That's a leading U.S. food service. The price, $2.2 billion.
 
IBM's (IBM) reaction to the Hewlett-Compaq merger, up $1.49.
 
Lexmark International (LXK), the printer maker, though, down $4.80. Standard & Poor's downgraded the stock from "accumulate" to just "hold" on concern that the Hewlett-Packard-Compaq merger will eliminate Compaq as a major Lexmark customer.
 
MBNA (XRB) down $2. That's in sympathy with the big drop in Providian (PVN). They're both credit card issuers.
 
Sante Fe International (SDC) fell $2.32. The company will buy for stock Global Marine (GLM).
 
And Global Marine's stock moved up $0.60 to $15 a share.
 
Finally, Wal-Mart (WMT) up $0.40. After the close, the company said an accounting change will add $223 million to the bottom line in the fiscal year 2003.
 
Anderson Exploration (AXN) had a good day, up $8.34. The company will be acquired by Devon Energy (DVN) for $25.80 a share in cash.
 
EDO Corp. (EDO), the defense manufacturer, up $1.80. The company V.P. told us policy is not to comment, but he did say he knew of no corporate developments or issues, no statements issued by the company.
 
Swift Energy (SFV) a $2.09 gain. That's in reaction to a positive report issued today from the First Albany Brokerage.
 
And Mykrolis Corp. (MYK) down $3.60. Fourth quarter forecasts from the company, lower than expected third quarter revenues of $36 million to $40 million and a loss of $0.38 to $0.45 a share.
 
SCI Systems (SCI) down $3.02. The company is being acquired for stock by Sanmina (SANM) and Sanmina, on prediction of lower than expected earnings, fell over $2 a share.
 
National Australia Bank (NAB) down $10.24. The company is going to write down the value of its U.S. mortgage unit by $1.75 million. Wall Street was expecting the company to divest itself of the unit.
 
Nasdaq trading, a loss of 34 2/3 points. It was up almost that much during the midday session. 1.5 billion shares traded, about 14 stocks up for every 21 down.
 
Microsoft (MSFT) topped the active list, down $0.95.
 
Then Intel (INTC) off $1.11. Lehman Brothers cut second half earnings estimates on Intel and the company Thursday will hold a conference to talk about its business outlook.
 
QUALCOMM (QCOM) down $4.55.
 
Dell Computer (DELL) moved up $0.93.
 
Cisco Systems (CSC) a loss of $0.56, fifth in volume.
 
NVIDIA (NVDA) down $5.89.
 
Applied Materials (AMAT) fell $1.16.
 
Oracle (ORCL) off $0.13.
 
Amgen (AMGN) down $0.16.
 
And then tenth in volume, Sun Microsystems (SUNW) fell $0.50.
 
Terayon Communications (TERN) up $2.13, a huge percentage gain. W.R. Hambrecht upgraded it from "neutral" to "buy." Lehman
 
upgraded it from "market perform" to "buy."
 
Crayfish Company Limited (CRFH) up $2.70. A Japanese firm launched a tender offer to boost its stake in the company from 40 percent to 67 percent.
 
And Novoste Corp. (NOVT) down $8.23 on concern the new Johnson & Johnson stent will hurt this company's business. Merrill
 
Lynch downgraded the stock from "near term buy" to "neutral."
 
The American Exchange Index (XAX) off 3 1/2 points.
 
Frequency Electronics (FEI) down $2.82. After the close last Thursday, the company said it lost a $4 million contract.
 
And Devon Energy (DVN) going to have to come up with a lot of cash to buy, as you heard, Anderson Exploration (AXN).
 
Finally, the Index Shares, a real mixture.
 
But the only gainer, the DIAMONDS (DIA) were up .09.
 
That's the Wall Street Wrap Up. Susie?
 
GHARIB: Thanks, Paul.
 
GHARIB: Faster is better for Motorola (MOT). The communications equipment maker has developed a semiconductor that runs 35 times faster than today's models. The new technology combines silicon for durability with crystals for high speed. But getting it to the market won't be speedy. Motorola says don't expect to see products with the new chip for at least two years.
 
KANGAS: Tomorrow, a look at the future of radio. Here's a hint, think digital.
 
GHARIB: Sales continue to downshift at the nation's big three auto makers. General Motors (GM) posted a drop in sales of just over 7 1/2 percent. Its biggest loss came in sales of passenger cars. They were down 20 percent. But GM Is sticking with third quarter production estimates of more than a million vehicles. Ford (F) sales dropped a less than expected 8 1/2 percent. Analysts were looking for sales to fall as much as 20 percent. Ford, like G.M., saw its greatest weakness in car sales, down 16 percent. But truck sales were almost break even with its F150 pickup truck posting its best monthly sales ever.
 
And sales at Daimler Chrysler (DAJ) fell 24 percent last month, much worse than expectations of a decline of 15 to 20 percent. But last year's August sales numbers were the company's best ever, and they were helped by huge incentives on discontinued models.
 
GHARIB: Employees of Boeing (BA) are unpacking boxes and finding the supply rooms today at their new corporate headquarters in Chicago. The airplane maker opened for business this morning. The official ceremonies will come tomorrow. Boeing moved to Chicago after 85 years in Seattle, making the switch to a downtown skyscraper in what the company says was record time.
 
KANGAS: In the current market, just finding a mutual fund with a positive return is a triumph. So would you believe that tonight we'll be talking about a fund that has a strong double digit return for the year to date? That fund is Boston Partners Small Cap Value Fund II, and while it's been down in recent weeks, it's still up almost 40 percent since January and up 54 percent over the last full year. Since its inception three years ago, the portfolio manager of Boston Partners Small Cap Value Fund II has been David Dabora, and he joins us now from San Francisco. David, welcome to NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT.
 
DAVID DABORA, BOSTON PARTNERS SMALL CAP VALUE FUND II: Thank you, Paul.
 
KANGAS: First, how have you managed to run up a record like that in a market like this?
 
DABORA: Well, we've had good stock selection, which has been a direct result of our value oriented investment philosophy and process at Boston Partners.
 
KANGAS: What are some of criteria that you use?
 
DABORA: We're looking for undervalued stock, stocks selling at a discount to their intrinsic value, companies with sound business fundamentals and a catalyst to unlock that value that we see in those stocks.
 
KANGAS: Are you still finding some bargains among the small cap sector?
 
DABORA: Yes, we are. We, a couple of the larger holdings in the portfolio, Navigate Consulting , a consulting company based out of Chicago, business is getting better, sales at 11 times earnings, very attractive.
 
KANGAS: Give us some of the trading symbols there of these stocks you like, and the largest holdings.
 
DABORA: Yes, Navigate Consulting ticker is (NCI). We also like Apria Health Care Group. It's in the home service, the home health care service area. The ticker is (AHG). And we like a small retailer, Pier One Imports, ticker (PIR).
 
KANGAS: Very good. You know, you have now almost a quarter of a billion dollars in assets in the fund. And I believe the fund is still open to new investors. But do you have any plans to close it any time soon?
 
DABORA: The fund is still open. We would anticipate closing it about year end at approximately $500 million under management.
 
KANGAS: Finally, David, what about the tech stocks? I mean we saw a nice rally today which faded badly. Are there are still some bargains there? Are you considering them?
 
DABORA: Yes. We've had some exposure in the tech area. About 10 percent of the portfolio is in the tech area. A name that we own in the portfolio is Network Associates (NETA) and we plan on finding further bargains as the market avails itself.
 
KANGAS: OK. Give us a few more that you like in the tech area. There are so many that have been hit hard. We've got about 20 seconds left.
 
DABORA: Yes. PC-Tel, a soft modem manufacturer, ticker (PCTI), we like. American Management Systems, an I.T. company, ticker (AMSY). We like that one, as well.
 
KANGAS: All right, David, thanks very much for being with us.
 
DABORA: Thank you.
 
KANGAS: And continued good luck.
 
DABORA: Thank you.
 
KANGAS: My guest David Dabora of Boston Partners Small Cap Value Fund II.
 
GHARIB: And recapping today's market action, the Dow gains 47 points, the NASDAQ loses 34.
 
And please be sure to join us at our World Wide Web site, nbr.com. And that's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Tuesday, September 4. I'm Susie Gharib. Good night, everyone. And good night to you, Paul.
 
KANGAS: Good night, Susie. I'm Paul Kangas wishing all of you the best of good buys.
