TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: President Obama names his choice to lead the new government watchdog agency overseeing credit cards, mortgages, and other consumer lending.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From a new bank sheriff to buying bank shares. We'll hear from one analyst who says now is the time to invest certain financial firms, and from another who says stay away. It's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 18th.

Good evening, everyone.

We're less than a week away from President Obama's deadline for raising the government's debt ceiling. And, Tom, today the president said he and Republican lawmakers were, quote, "making progress" after a series of weekend meetings.

HUDSON: Yes, Susie, with the clock clearly continues to tick, and here are the latest developments tonight as we know them. The leader of the U.S. Senate says that chamber will meet every day until Congress sends the president legislation making sure Uncle Sam does not default on its obligations.

The U.S. House, meantime, is set to pass a budget "cut, cap, and balance" bill tomorrow. That includes a proposed budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution, but credit rating agency Moody's (NYSE: MCO) says the U.S. would be better off if the debt ceiling was eliminated entirely.

GHARIB: Now the debt showdown wasn't the only financial topic in the nation's capital today. The president nominated Richard Cordray to be the nation's top consumer loan advocate.

Darren Gersh has details.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The president vowed to fight back against what he called an army of lobbyists trying to weaken the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The agency was created to fight lending abuses that the president says were a leading cause of the financial crisis.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We are not just going to shrug our shoulders and hope it doesn't happen again. We're not going to go back to the status quo, where consumers couldn't count on getting protections that they deserve. We're not going to go back to a time when our whole economy was vulnerable to a massive financial crisis.

GERSH: To make sure that doesn't happen, the president nominated Richard Cordray to be the CFPB's first director. As Ohioattorney general, Cordray aggressively attacked fraudulent foreclosures.

Ernie Patrikis, an expert in banking regulation, says Cordray is a tough adversary.

ERNIE PATRIKIS, PARTNER, WHITE & CASE: He is not going to be a very easy fellow for some companies to get along with. He has a strong track record of going after people and he has done it in mortgage servicing. He did it against the rating agencies. So if he can ultimately control the agency, he'll really move it.

GERSH: That's if he gets confirmed by the Senate, and that will be a tough battle. Republicans are demanding more oversight of the CFPB's proposed $550 million budget and a new leadership structure, replacing a single director with a five-member board.

That's also the position of many banks, says the Financial Services Roundtable's Scott Talbott.

SCOTT TALBOTT, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, FINANCIAL SERVICES ROUNDTABLE: We are for creating a five-person panel. It doesn't dilute the total power of the CFPB, it simply spreads it out. So that if an idea is a good one, then let's have a panel agree to it. That provides the checks and the balances necessary.

GERSH: One thing seems clear, without a strong leader in place, the CFPB is off to an uncertain start.

PATRIKIS: They will be doing a lot of thinking, a lot of preparatory work for what they want to do, organizing, drafting, but nothing will be effective.

GERSH: Consumer groups endorsed Cordray, but they were clearly disappointed the president sidestepped selecting Elizabeth Warren. The CFPB was her idea, and President Obama put her in charge of setting up the office, but she was considered too confrontational to have any chance of winning support from Senate Republicans.

Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: If Richard Cordray is confirmed, part of his job will be checking the books of big banks. And we're going to get a better idea of how those books are doing in coming days when many report quarterly earnings. By the end of this week, 40 percent of financial firms in the S&P 500 will have reported their latest numbers.

As a group, the results are expected to be downright awful. Erika Miller reports.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Banks are the heartbeat of the economy, so their health is often used as a barometer of the recovery, and the stock market.

Unfortunately for investors, bank analyst Jim Sinegal sees plenty of uncertainties ahead.

JIM SINEGAL, BANK ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: In addition to macroeconomic uncertainties, you know, with unemployment high, GDP growth slow, you know, will the banks be able to add new loans? That's number one. Number two is the regulatory uncertainty. We are still not sure exactly where capital levels are going to fall out, and how that's going to affect profitability.

MILLER: As for profitability, diversified financials are expected to be the worst performer this earnings season, down 94 percent. This is the group that includes Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), Citi, and JPMorgan.

But there's a catch. Take out Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), and earnings for the group are expected to rise 23 percent, better than the 8 percent gain for the overall market. Against that backdrop, analyst Jim Sinegal says now is a good time to buy select financial stocks: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo (NYSE: WFC), and U.S. Bancorp (NYSE: USB).

SINEGAL: We think if you stick to high quality names at current prices, current earnings, and with most of their capital problems behind them, you know, we think they are one of the best sectors in terms of investment opportunities.

MILLER: But Burt White of LPL Financial warns it's too risky to buy any bank stocks now.

BURT WHITE, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, LPL FINANCIAL: We think that there are way too many questions and just not enough answers, between housing and foreclosures and the euro crisis and regulatory reform. Plus, just some of the simple negatives like a flat yield curve and zero interest rates, so they can't earn money on money market reserves.

MILLER: Those concerns have weighed on stocks in the sector. The BKX Index of bank stocks has fallen nearly 20 percent from its high back in February. And if you are thinking of buying financial stocks for their dividends, think again. In their heyday in 2007, the group yielded 3.3 percent. Now they pay out just 1.8 percent, the lowest of any industry group in the S&P 500.

Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Still ahead tonight, the Murdoch mess. Rupert Murdoch's News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is under scrutiny for questionable journalism on both sides of the Atlantic, but we'll talk with an analyst who still likes the stock.

GHARIB: Government debt worries put investors in a selling mood today. At the close, the Dow lost 94 points, the NASDAQ fell nearly 25, the S&P 500 off almost 11. Now as for volume, 871 million shares were traded here at the Big Board and just shy of 1.8 billion at the NASDAQ.

Meanwhile, all that glitters is gold. The yellow metal closed above $1,600 for the first time ever. Gold for August delivery settled at $1,602 an ounce, up $12. That's a record in dollar terms, but below the peak reached in the 1980s, after accounting for inflation.

Big layoffs announced late today at Cisco Systems (NASDAQ: CSCO). It will lay off 6,500 workers, or about 9 percent of its full-time workforce. Analysts predicted thousands of job cuts after Cisco announced plans to reorganize back in May. The company had been losing ground in the network equipment business. Cisco says the move will cut annual expenses by about $1 billion.

HUDSON: Big Blue saw a lot of green in the second quarter. The technology company continued its recent trend of reporting better-than- expected profits. Earnings were $0.06 better than estimates. Software, services, and hardware revenue each grew by double digits, leading IBM to raise its earnings guidance for the year. Tom Smith covers Big Blue, IBM as an analyst at Standard & Poor's, and joins us tonight from New York.

Tom, strong quarter, any concerns for IBM?

THOMAS SMITH, ANALYST, STANDARD & POOR'S: Well, I think it was a pretty bright quarter all around. And despite some weakness in Japan as a regional territory, Japan was weak in the aftermath of the earthquake.

HUDSON: Now we saw some of the double-digit revenue increases across the board, the backlog of service contracts is up as well. Big growth in software systems and services, which is the big money-maker. The outlook looks pretty bright, so what should shareholders be paying attention to closely.

SMITH: Well, the outlook is pretty bright. Going back to your prior question, you could tone down your enthusiasm a little bit because some of the top line reporting of revenues based on currency tailwind, nevertheless, 5 percent same currency base as revenue growth for the company overall is pretty good.

So it is looking ahead I think we have to see whether the strength in hardware can continue because they had new fresh batch of machines last September. And those are now about a year dated. And they will pull -- they pulled a lot of orders for three quarters now and that will continue, and software and services get added on to that. Can that continue for another year or so? That is one question in mind.

HUDSON: At least initially it seems like the shareholders were pretty encouraged that it can. The share price looks to pop to possibly a new high after hours, certainly it did. If that continues through tomorrow it will be close to $180 per share. What is your outlook for the stock?

SMITH: That's right. Well, our outlook has been a strong buy going into the report, and remains a strong buy afterwards. And I was able to raise my earnings estimate and also push my 12-month target price from $196 to $205. So I'm even more optimistic, and yet the share price is improving on this. You hope that it can carry through.

One knock on IBM, sometimes it's so big it can't increase revenues. But they had a pretty good quarter on revenues.

HUDSON: It's a big revenue already and seeing it grow by double digits across some of the business units. What does this mean, though? Extrapolate IBM's performance for Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ). What does it mean for HP?

SMITH: Well, I think for HP and maybe for Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) too, a big data center conglomerate, if you will, is that there is interest in enterprises and governments and non-profits. Governments were a little bit weaker as a buying source. But as opposed to discretionary consumer hardware, the enterprise business for data centers is still pretty strong.

So that caters to quite a bit of what HP does and a lot of what Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) does. Those two, of course, are exposed to PCs, which are much more -- which have a business component and a discretionary component. That discretionary component makes those two look a little slower in that sense in terms of revenue or more volatile in their results.

HUDSON: OK. And we'll.

SMITH: You know, part of IBM's.

HUDSON: Well, we'll see those in the weeks ahead, sorry for cutting you off here, time is short. A quick look at IBM after the close, there.

SMITH: Thank you.

HUDSON: Tom, we appreciate it. Tom Smith, he's with Standard & Poor's.

Well, ahead of those IBM -- news, stocks were weak to the government debt worries continuing, in Europe and the United States. So let's go ahead and roll out with tonight's "Market Focus."

It was an 11-point drop for the S&P 500, and takes the index down to the lowest level we've seen in a month. So let's go ahead and take a look at the last 90 sessions. Here we are. We're going to zoom in now with the March low remaining intact.

Here it is, on the far side of the screen. The index, though, was unable to crest above the highs that we saw during the April months, during the bounce-back that we had back in June. And we're -- here we are at the lowest part in the past month. One area to watch clearly is the lows that we had back in June.

Technology, meantime, compare it to the past 90 sessions of the NASDAQ 100 Exchange-Traded Fund, it was down 0.5 percent today, but, look, it's not nearly as low compared to a month ago, where it was. The tech sector has held up better in the past recent weeks compared to the broad market, thanks to this broad move higher late last month. It was the best sector today in the weak market.

The market focus clearly on IBM tomorrow after the earnings, but also on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), which reports earnings after the close tomorrow. Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) among the strongest technology stocks, a bit of a technology burst ourselves here on screen. This does take Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) shares up to a new 52-week high. It's a 2.4 percent increase. Volume was stronger with the action pulling Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) to its highest price it has ever seen.

Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) reportedly is close to a new deal to sell its iPhone in China. We'll have more on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) and its growth prospects on tomorrow night's program.

How about B. of A., meantime? Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) jumping to a new high, Bank of America (NYSE: BAC) stock continues sinking down to new two- year lows. B. of A. shares down another 2.8 percent, the biggest loser among the Dow Industrial Components, and the financial sector clearly weighing on the market today.

Not just big banks, it was insurance stocks as well facing some of the worst selling that we saw in the broad market. Late Friday, S&P warned the credit ratings of insurers holding U.S. government debt would be in jeopardy if there is no debt deal in Washington.

Genworth falling more than 7.5 percent, a new 52-week low tonight. We've got Allstate (NYSE: ALL) shedding 5 percent, its lowest price since last August, and Hartford falling almost 4 percent, that is its lowest price of this year.

Between the potential push higher on mortgage rates, if there is no debt deal and the struggling job market, a look at the homebuilder confidence here, continuing to see some weakness here, off by another 1.5 percent. The Homebuilder Exchange-Traded Fund falling and now threatening some of the lows just from last month.

Also coming back to earth significantly, Delta Air Lines stock. Look at this continued push lower here, off another 4 percent. Earnings are expected tomorrow. And the stock has been trending lower really since late last year thanks to the soft patch of economic news and oil prices remaining over $90 per barrel.

Some analysts worry with no debt deal, airlines could see higher interest costs for their borrowing. Clearly some selling continuing ahead of its earnings call.

Chinese solar panel maker LDK, meantime, has faded to its lowest stock price in a year, off another 3 percent today. It is the latest Chinese firm to face questions about governance. In a report from Fitch Ratings, raised issue with the concentrated stock ownership structure as well as wild swings in profit margins, leading to the selling pressure we saw today.

Finally, it's not often that celebrity gossip finds its way into the stock market, but retailer Kohl's (NYSE: KSS) has plans to launch a clothing line by Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony. The company says it will continue to do that. It will start in September, despite the two announcing their divorce late last week. The stock price coming off its most recent high, off about 1 percent.

And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

GHARIB: News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is in for another week of scrutiny as that phone-hacking scandal escalates. Late today, Standard & Poor's ratings service put the media giant on credit watch with "negative implications," saying there are increased risks related to the broadening legal issues at News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS).

Now the action comes a day before CEO Rupert Murdoch and his son, James, testify before the British Parliament tomorrow morning. But our guest tonight says News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). stock is still his top pick. Joining us now, Jason Bazinet. He is media analyst at Citigroup (NYSE: C).

Hi, Jason, nice to you have with us.

JASON BAZINET, MEDIA ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Thank you so much.

GHARIB: Let's start right off with that stock. It has been down sharply since this scandal broke. And you said in a Citi report that News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is, quote, "too compelling to ignore." Tell us why you are so bullish on the stock?

BAZINET: Well, there are a couple of reasons the stock is down so much. One is several weeks ago people expected News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). to consolidate all of BSkyB, and now that is not happening. That is disappointing to investors.

And second you have got this broadening scandal. But when we look at the numbers News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is trading about 10 times forward earnings. And importantly, they have about $12 billion of cash on the balance sheet. If you make that adjustment and remove the cash from their market capitalization, it's trading closer to 6.5 times earnings. That's too compelling to ignore.

GHARIB: What about some of the other issues that are on the worry list for investors? And we listed some of them on the screen here. Let's take a look. One of the worries is, what if News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is forced to sell its British newspaper holdings? What if U.K. regulators force the company to sell its stakes that it already owns in BSkyB satellite? News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). could also lose its TV licenses if U.S. regulators say that News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is no longer fit to own American television properties.

There is a question about leadership change at the top. If Rupert Murdoch steps down or is kicked out as CEO. And what -- you know, will any of the senior execs be indicted or go to jail? So what impact do these issues have? What are the financial implications?

BAZINET: Well, if I can remember that list, let me try and go through them. The disposition of the newspaper assets in the U.K. is really inconsequential. News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). does 4.5 million nominally of operating income a year. Those assets do about 70 million. So we're talking about less than 2 percent of the operating income. And to the Street they're a distraction. So if those end up getting sold, it doesn't really matter.

The second risk you mentioned, I believe, was the potential disposition of the 39 percent stake they have in BSkyB.

GHARIB: BSkyB, right.

BAZINET: Yes. You know, the Street likes that asset, but at the end of the day if they end up selling that asset, something is going to have to happen to that 12 billion of cash that was sitting on the balance sheet that was going to be used to buy in the rest of BSkyB. So not only will News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). holders get cash for the sale of the 39 percent stake, but that other 12 billion will come back to equity holders. And that is why I focused on that, you know, mid single-digit P/E ex the cash.

The TV station sale, I think, was the third risk you mentioned. You know, the Street likes the TV station business. They have got retransmission fees coming. The reality of, I think, this risk is actually quite low. There was a case that took place in the 1960s. RKO got into some trouble with the government. They didn't end up disposing of all of their assets, even though the FCC told them to, until 1990. I mean, it really was decades in the making.

So I don't think that is a real near-term risk. But, again, even if it is, you are going to see more cash come into News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). The cash balance will rise by another $5 billion or so. So I don't think it is a major risk.

GHARIB: All right. So a lot of good money aspects to it. But what about if Rupert Murdoch steps down as CEO, is that a positive or a negative for the company?

BAZINET: Well, John Malone, who is another CEO of another media company, was once asked about Rupert Murdoch's mortality and succession planning. And he somewhat famously quipped: "half of News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). shareholders are afraid Rupert Murdoch will live and the other half are afraid he will die."

What he meant by that was people think Mr. Murdoch is an intelligent man, but there have been times in the past when he has, at least in the eyes of shareholders, misallocated capital. So changing the guard, again, I think is sort of a mixed bag. It doesn't necessarily mean it's negative for News.

GHARIB: All right. Very interesting information. We'll see what happens tomorrow at those hearings in the U.K. Parliament. Thank you so much, Jason.

BAZINET: Very good. Thank you.

GHARIB: And we've been speaking with Jason Bazinet, he's media analyst at Citigroup (NYSE: C).

HUDSON: Here is what we are watching for tomorrow. We've got another check on the housing sector due in, the June numbers on housing starts and building permits. Plenty of earnings as well, a couple from all-American brands Coca-Cola (NYSE: KO) and Harley-Davidson (NYSE: HOG).

And a couple of big tech giants reporting too. We'll see how the iPad is adding to Apple's bottom line and whether Yahoo (NASDAQ: YHOO)! is gaining ground in the world of Internet search advertising.

GHARIB: Borders bookstore plans to write its last chapter this week after a weekend deadline passed without a bidder to keep it in business. Late today, Borders said it will ask a judge to approve its liquidation on Thursday. It will begin on Friday and wrap up by September.

Borders employs nearly 11,000 people. The company blames its demise on changes in the book industry and the popularity of the e-reader.

HUDSON: Speaking about downsizing your car for something with better gas mileage, you may save a little money by waiting a little longer. According to Kelley Blue Book, the average price of a new compact car cost a record $20,500 last month, but it is expected to fall to about $19,300 by the end of the year. They see a similar trend with used cars too, dropping from over $11,000 down to under $10,000.

The debate over the debt ceiling can also be seen as the latest blame game. There is a lot of finger-pointing going, but still no deal. Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and former chief economist to Vice President Joe Biden.

JARED BERNSTEIN, SENIOR FELLOW, CENTER ON BUDGET AND POLICY PRIORITIES : The last time I offered a commentary here, I began by observing that the current debate over economic policy is generating a lot more heat than light.

Since then, it has gotten much hotter and a lot darker. If Congress fails to raise the debt ceiling by August 2nd, just a few days from now, we could end up taking an economic hit as devastating as it is avoidable. That's right, this wound will be self-inflicted. How did it come to this? The answer is politics, and it's an ugly, destabilizing politics of a type we haven't seen in this country for many years.

Ask yourself, are House Republicans refusing to countenance any budget deal that includes tax revenues from closing a break for buyers of private jets because they think it's bad economics? Or is it because almost every one of them signed the Grover Norquist pledge that they would never raise taxes under any circumstances?

In a sense, it's a trivial example. Closing that loophole would have virtually no effect at all on our long-term budget deficit. But in another sense, it's the crux of the matter. Fierce partisanship is one thing, and it's clearly part of the American political landscape.

We have profound differences and a political system that allows those differences to be both heard and embodied in our policies. But at the end of the day, our history shows that partisans compromise in the interest of preserving the common good. Those who refuse to do so have no place in this debate.

They are not legislators, working with their opponents to hammer out the best deal for both their constituents and the nation. They're pledge- takers who are threatening to abandon the common good for narrow self- interest. And that must not stand.

I'm Jared Bernstein.

HUDSON: Obviously there's a lot here to be said and Jared won't have the last word on the debt debate. In the coming days and weeks, we'll continue to bring you thoughts and views from all sides.

GHARIB: And finally tonight, hold on to your cell phones if you plan to visit Miami, New York, or Los Angeles. According to a recent study by mobile security company Lookout, those are the three top cities for cell phone loss or theft. The remainder of the list spans coast to coast. It includes Phoenix, Sacramento, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Philadelphia, and Tampa.

Basically everywhere, Tom. And pools, taxis, and airplanes are the top three worst places to lose your cell phone. And that's why I always have mine right next to me so I don't lose it, can't live without it.

HUDSON: Top of my list, toddlers, a tough place to lose a cell phone as well, toddlers.

GHARIB: That's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 18th. I'm Susie Gharib. Have a great evening, everyone.

You too, Tom.

HUDSON: You, as well, Susie.

I'm Tom Hudson. Good night, thanks for joining us this evening. We'll see you right back here tomorrow.

END

urn:contentItem:5JDH-S3G1-DY0W-44JV-00000-00Nightly Business Report2011-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportLanhamFULL TEXT

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: President Obama names his choice to lead the new government watchdog agency overseeing credit cards, mortgages, and other consumer lending.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: From a new bank sheriff to buying bank shares. We'll hear from one analyst who says now is the time to invest certain financial firms, and from another who says stay away. It's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 18th.

Good evening, everyone.

We're less than a week away from President Obama's deadline for raising the government's debt ceiling. And, Tom, today the president said he and Republican lawmakers were, quote, "making progress" after a series of weekend meetings.

HUDSON: Yes, Susie, with the clock clearly continues to tick, and here are the latest developments tonight as we know them. The leader of the U.S. Senate says that chamber will meet every day until Congress sends the president legislation making sure Uncle Sam does not default on its obligations.

The U.S. House, meantime, is set to pass a budget "cut, cap, and balance" bill tomorrow. That includes a proposed budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution, but credit rating agency Moody's (NYSE: MCO) says the U.S. would be better off if the debt ceiling was eliminated entirely.

GHARIB: Now the debt showdown wasn't the only financial topic in the nation's capital today. The president nominated Richard Cordray to be the nation's top consumer loan advocate.

Darren Gersh has details.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The president vowed to fight back against what he called an army of lobbyists trying to weaken the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The agency was created to fight lending abuses that the president says were a leading cause of the financial crisis.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We are not just going to shrug our shoulders and hope it doesn't happen again. We're not going to go back to the status quo, where consumers couldn't count on getting protections that they deserve. We're not going to go back to a time when our whole economy was vulnerable to a massive financial crisis.

GERSH: To make sure that doesn't happen, the president nominated Richard Cordray to be the CFPB's first director. As Ohio attorney general, Cordray aggressively attacked fraudulent foreclosures.

Ernie Patrikis, an expert in banking regulation, says Cordray is a tough adversary.

ERNIE PATRIKIS, PARTNER, WHITE & CASE: He is not going to be a very easy fellow for some companies to get along with. He has a strong track record of going after people and he has done it in mortgage servicing. He did it against the rating agencies. So if he can ultimately control the agency, he'll really move it.

GERSH: That's if he gets confirmed by the Senate, and that will be a tough battle. Republicans are demanding more oversight of the CFPB's proposed $550 million budget and a new leadership structure, replacing a single director with a five-member board.

That's also the position of many banks, says the Financial Services Roundtable's Scott Talbott.

SCOTT TALBOTT, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, FINANCIAL SERVICES ROUNDTABLE: We are for creating a five-person panel. It doesn't dilute the total power of the CFPB, it simply spreads it out. So that if an idea is a good one, then let's have a panel agree to it. That provides the checks and the balances necessary.

GERSH: One thing seems clear, without a strong leader in place, the CFPB is off to an uncertain start.

PATRIKIS: They will be doing a lot of thinking, a lot of preparatory work for what they want to do, organizing, drafting, but nothing will be effective.

GERSH: Consumer groups endorsed Cordray, but they were clearly disappointed the president sidestepped selecting Elizabeth Warren. The CFPB was her idea, and President Obama put her in charge of setting up the office, but she was considered too confrontational to have any chance of winning support from Senate Republicans.

Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: If Richard Cordray is confirmed, part of his job will be checking the books of big banks. And we're going to get a better idea of how those books are doing in coming days when many report quarterly earnings. By the end of this week, 40 percent of financial firms in the S&P 500 will have reported their latest numbers.

As a group, the results are expected to be downright awful. Erika Miller reports.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Banks are the heartbeat of the economy, so their health is often used as a barometer of the recovery, and the stock market.

Unfortunately for investors, bank analyst Jim Sinegal sees plenty of uncertainties ahead.

JIM SINEGAL, BANK ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: In addition to macroeconomic uncertainties, you know, with unemployment high, GDP growth slow, you know, will the banks be able to add new loans? That's number one. Number two is the regulatory uncertainty. We are still not sure exactly where capital levels are going to fall out, and how that's going to affect profitability.

MILLER: As for profitability, diversified financials are expected to be the worst performer this earnings season, down 94 percent. This is the group that includes Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), Citi, and JPMorgan.

But there's a catch. Take out Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), and earnings for the group are expected to rise 23 percent, better than the 8 percent gain for the overall market. Against that backdrop, analyst Jim Sinegal says now is a good time to buy select financial stocks: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo (NYSE: WFC), and U.S. Bancorp (NYSE: USB).

SINEGAL: We think if you stick to high quality names at current prices, current earnings, and with most of their capital problems behind them, you know, we think they are one of the best sectors in terms of investment opportunities.

MILLER: But Burt White of LPL Financial warns it's too risky to buy any bank stocks now.

BURT WHITE, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, LPL FINANCIAL: We think that there are way too many questions and just not enough answers, between housing and foreclosures and the euro crisis and regulatory reform. Plus, just some of the simple negatives like a flat yield curve and zero interest rates, so they can't earn money on money market reserves.

MILLER: Those concerns have weighed on stocks in the sector. The BKX Index of bank stocks has fallen nearly 20 percent from its high back in February. And if you are thinking of buying financial stocks for their dividends, think again. In their heyday in 2007, the group yielded 3.3 percent. Now they pay out just 1.8 percent, the lowest of any industry group in the S&P 500.

Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Still ahead tonight, the Murdoch mess. Rupert Murdoch's News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is under scrutiny for questionable journalism on both sides of the Atlantic, but we'll talk with an analyst who still likes the stock.

GHARIB: Government debt worries put investors in a selling mood today. At the close, the Dow lost 94 points, the NASDAQ fell nearly 25, the S&P 500 off almost 11. Now as for volume, 871 million shares were traded here at the Big Board and just shy of 1.8 billion at the NASDAQ.

Meanwhile, all that glitters is gold. The yellow metal closed above $1,600 for the first time ever. Gold for August delivery settled at $1,602 an ounce, up $12. That's a record in dollar terms, but below the peak reached in the 1980s, after accounting for inflation.

Big layoffs announced late today at Cisco Systems (NASDAQ: CSCO). It will lay off 6,500 workers, or about 9 percent of its full-time workforce. Analysts predicted thousands of job cuts after Cisco announced plans to reorganize back in May. The company had been losing ground in the network equipment business. Cisco says the move will cut annual expenses by about $1 billion.

HUDSON: Big Blue saw a lot of green in the second quarter. The technology company continued its recent trend of reporting better-than- expected profits. Earnings were $0.06 better than estimates. Software, services, and hardware revenue each grew by double digits, leading IBM to raise its earnings guidance for the year. Tom Smith covers Big Blue, IBM as an analyst at Standard & Poor's, and joins us tonight from New York.

Tom, strong quarter, any concerns for IBM?

THOMAS SMITH, ANALYST, STANDARD & POOR'S: Well, I think it was a pretty bright quarter all around. And despite some weakness in Japan as a regional territory, Japan was weak in the aftermath of the earthquake.

HUDSON: Now we saw some of the double-digit revenue increases across the board, the backlog of service contracts is up as well. Big growth in software systems and services, which is the big money-maker. The outlook looks pretty bright, so what should shareholders be paying attention to closely.

SMITH: Well, the outlook is pretty bright. Going back to your prior question, you could tone down your enthusiasm a little bit because some of the top line reporting of revenues based on currency tailwind, nevertheless, 5 percent same currency base as revenue growth for the company overall is pretty good.

So it is looking ahead I think we have to see whether the strength in hardware can continue because they had new fresh batch of machines last September. And those are now about a year dated. And they will pull -- they pulled a lot of orders for three quarters now and that will continue, and software and services get added on to that. Can that continue for another year or so? That is one question in mind.

HUDSON: At least initially it seems like the shareholders were pretty encouraged that it can. The share price looks to pop to possibly a new high after hours, certainly it did. If that continues through tomorrow it will be close to $180 per share. What is your outlook for the stock?

SMITH: That's right. Well, our outlook has been a strong buy going into the report, and remains a strong buy afterwards. And I was able to raise my earnings estimate and also push my 12-month target price from $196 to $205. So I'm even more optimistic, and yet the share price is improving on this. You hope that it can carry through.

One knock on IBM, sometimes it's so big it can't increase revenues. But they had a pretty good quarter on revenues.

HUDSON: It's a big revenue already and seeing it grow by double digits across some of the business units. What does this mean, though? Extrapolate IBM's performance for Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ). What does it mean for HP?

SMITH: Well, I think for HP and maybe for Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) too, a big data center conglomerate, if you will, is that there is interest in enterprises and governments and non-profits. Governments were a little bit weaker as a buying source. But as opposed to discretionary consumer hardware, the enterprise business for data centers is still pretty strong.

So that caters to quite a bit of what HP does and a lot of what Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) does. Those two, of course, are exposed to PCs, which are much more -- which have a business component and a discretionary component. That discretionary component makes those two look a little slower in that sense in terms of revenue or more volatile in their results.

HUDSON: OK. And we'll.

SMITH: You know, part of IBM's.

HUDSON: Well, we'll see those in the weeks ahead, sorry for cutting you off here, time is short. A quick look at IBM after the close, there.

SMITH: Thank you.

HUDSON: Tom, we appreciate it. Tom Smith, he's with Standard & Poor's.

Well, ahead of those IBM -- news, stocks were weak to the government debt worries continuing, in Europe and the United States. So let's go ahead and roll out with tonight's "Market Focus."

It was an 11-point drop for the S&P 500, and takes the index down to the lowest level we've seen in a month. So let's go ahead and take a look at the last 90 sessions. Here we are. We're going to zoom in now with the March low remaining intact.

Here it is, on the far side of the screen. The index, though, was unable to crest above the highs that we saw during the April months, during the bounce-back that we had back in June. And we're -- here we are at the lowest part in the past month. One area to watch clearly is the lows that we had back in June.

Technology, meantime, compare it to the past 90 sessions of the NASDAQ 100 Exchange-Traded Fund, it was down 0.5 percent today, but, look, it's not nearly as low compared to a month ago, where it was. The tech sector has held up better in the past recent weeks compared to the broad market, thanks to this broad move higher late last month. It was the best sector today in the weak market.

The market focus clearly on IBM tomorrow after the earnings, but also on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), which reports earnings after the close tomorrow. Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) among the strongest technology stocks, a bit of a technology burst ourselves here on screen. This does take Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) shares up to a new 52-week high. It's a 2.4 percent increase. Volume was stronger with the action pulling Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) to its highest price it has ever seen.

Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) reportedly is close to a new deal to sell its iPhone in China. We'll have more on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) and its growth prospects on tomorrow night's program.

How about B. of A., meantime? Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) jumping to a new high, Bank of America (NYSE: BAC) stock continues sinking down to new two- year lows. B. of A. shares down another 2.8 percent, the biggest loser among the Dow Industrial Components, and the financial sector clearly weighing on the market today.

Not just big banks, it was insurance stocks as well facing some of the worst selling that we saw in the broad market. Late Friday, S&P warned the credit ratings of insurers holding U.S. government debt would be in jeopardy if there is no debt deal in Washington.

Genworth falling more than 7.5 percent, a new 52-week low tonight. We've got Allstate (NYSE: ALL) shedding 5 percent, its lowest price since last August, and Hartford falling almost 4 percent, that is its lowest price of this year.

Between the potential push higher on mortgage rates, if there is no debt deal and the struggling job market, a look at the homebuilder confidence here, continuing to see some weakness here, off by another 1.5 percent. The Homebuilder Exchange-Traded Fund falling and now threatening some of the lows just from last month.

Also coming back to earth significantly, Delta Air Lines stock. Look at this continued push lower here, off another 4 percent. Earnings are expected tomorrow. And the stock has been trending lower really since late last year thanks to the soft patch of economic news and oil prices remaining over $90 per barrel.

Some analysts worry with no debt deal, airlines could see higher interest costs for their borrowing. Clearly some selling continuing ahead of its earnings call.

Chinese solar panel maker LDK, meantime, has faded to its lowest stock price in a year, off another 3 percent today. It is the latest Chinese firm to face questions about governance. In a report from Fitch Ratings, raised issue with the concentrated stock ownership structure as well as wild swings in profit margins, leading to the selling pressure we saw today.

Finally, it's not often that celebrity gossip finds its way into the stock market, but retailer Kohl's (NYSE: KSS) has plans to launch a clothing line by Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony. The company says it will continue to do that. It will start in September, despite the two announcing their divorce late last week. The stock price coming off its most recent high, off about 1 percent.

And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

GHARIB: News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is in for another week of scrutiny as that phone-hacking scandal escalates. Late today, Standard & Poor's ratings service put the media giant on credit watch with "negative implications," saying there are increased risks related to the broadening legal issues at News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS).

Now the action comes a day before CEO Rupert Murdoch and his son, James, testify before the British Parliament tomorrow morning. But our guest tonight says News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). stock is still his top pick. Joining us now, Jason Bazinet. He is media analyst at Citigroup (NYSE: C).

Hi, Jason, nice to you have with us.

JASON BAZINET, MEDIA ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Thank you so much.

GHARIB: Let's start right off with that stock. It has been down sharply since this scandal broke. And you said in a Citi report that News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is, quote, "too compelling to ignore." Tell us why you are so bullish on the stock?

BAZINET: Well, there are a couple of reasons the stock is down so much. One is several weeks ago people expected News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). to consolidate all of BSkyB, and now that is not happening. That is disappointing to investors.

And second you have got this broadening scandal. But when we look at the numbers News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is trading about 10 times forward earnings. And importantly, they have about $12 billion of cash on the balance sheet. If you make that adjustment and remove the cash from their market capitalization, it's trading closer to 6.5 times earnings. That's too compelling to ignore.

GHARIB: What about some of the other issues that are on the worry list for investors? And we listed some of them on the screen here. Let's take a look. One of the worries is, what if News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is forced to sell its British newspaper holdings? What if U.K. regulators force the company to sell its stakes that it already owns in BSkyB satellite? News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). could also lose its TV licenses if U.S. regulators say that News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). is no longer fit to own American television properties.

There is a question about leadership change at the top. If Rupert Murdoch steps down or is kicked out as CEO. And what -- you know, will any of the senior execs be indicted or go to jail? So what impact do these issues have? What are the financial implications?

BAZINET: Well, if I can remember that list, let me try and go through them. The disposition of the newspaper assets in the U.K. is really inconsequential. News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). does 4.5 million nominally of operating income a year. Those assets do about 70 million. So we're talking about less than 2 percent of the operating income. And to the Street they're a distraction. So if those end up getting sold, it doesn't really matter.

The second risk you mentioned, I believe, was the potential disposition of the 39 percent stake they have in BSkyB.

GHARIB: BSkyB, right.

BAZINET: Yes. You know, the Street likes that asset, but at the end of the day if they end up selling that asset, something is going to have to happen to that 12 billion of cash that was sitting on the balance sheet that was going to be used to buy in the rest of BSkyB. So not only will News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). holders get cash for the sale of the 39 percent stake, but that other 12 billion will come back to equity holders. And that is why I focused on that, you know, mid single-digit P/E ex the cash.

The TV station sale, I think, was the third risk you mentioned. You know, the Street likes the TV station business. They have got retransmission fees coming. The reality of, I think, this risk is actually quite low. There was a case that took place in the 1960s. RKO got into some trouble with the government. They didn't end up disposing of all of their assets, even though the FCC told them to, until 1990. I mean, it really was decades in the making.

So I don't think that is a real near-term risk. But, again, even if it is, you are going to see more cash come into News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). The cash balance will rise by another $5 billion or so. So I don't think it is a major risk.

GHARIB: All right. So a lot of good money aspects to it. But what about if Rupert Murdoch steps down as CEO, is that a positive or a negative for the company?

BAZINET: Well, John Malone, who is another CEO of another media company, was once asked about Rupert Murdoch's mortality and succession planning. And he somewhat famously quipped: "half of News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). shareholders are afraid Rupert Murdoch will live and the other half are afraid he will die."

What he meant by that was people think Mr. Murdoch is an intelligent man, but there have been times in the past when he has, at least in the eyes of shareholders, misallocated capital. So changing the guard, again, I think is sort of a mixed bag. It doesn't necessarily mean it's negative for News.

GHARIB: All right. Very interesting information. We'll see what happens tomorrow at those hearings in the U.K. Parliament. Thank you so much, Jason.

BAZINET: Very good. Thank you.

GHARIB: And we've been speaking with Jason Bazinet, he's media analyst at Citigroup (NYSE: C).

HUDSON: Here is what we are watching for tomorrow. We've got another check on the housing sector due in, the June numbers on housing starts and building permits. Plenty of earnings as well, a couple from all-American brands Coca-Cola (NYSE: KO) and Harley-Davidson (NYSE: HOG).

And a couple of big tech giants reporting too. We'll see how the iPad is adding to Apple's bottom line and whether Yahoo (NASDAQ: YHOO)! is gaining ground in the world of Internet search advertising.

GHARIB: Borders bookstore plans to write its last chapter this week after a weekend deadline passed without a bidder to keep it in business. Late today, Borders said it will ask a judge to approve its liquidation on Thursday. It will begin on Friday and wrap up by September.

Borders employs nearly 11,000 people. The company blames its demise on changes in the book industry and the popularity of the e-reader.

HUDSON: Speaking about downsizing your car for something with better gas mileage, you may save a little money by waiting a little longer. According to Kelley Blue Book, the average price of a new compact car cost a record $20,500 last month, but it is expected to fall to about $19,300 by the end of the year. They see a similar trend with used cars too, dropping from over $11,000 down to under $10,000.

The debate over the debt ceiling can also be seen as the latest blame game. There is a lot of finger-pointing going, but still no deal. Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and former chief economist to Vice President Joe Biden.

JARED BERNSTEIN, SENIOR FELLOW, CENTER ON BUDGET AND POLICY PRIORITIES : The last time I offered a commentary here, I began by observing that the current debate over economic policy is generating a lot more heat than light.

Since then, it has gotten much hotter and a lot darker. If Congress fails to raise the debt ceiling by August 2nd, just a few days from now, we could end up taking an economic hit as devastating as it is avoidable. That's right, this wound will be self-inflicted. How did it come to this? The answer is politics, and it's an ugly, destabilizing politics of a type we haven't seen in this country for many years.

Ask yourself, are House Republicans refusing to countenance any budget deal that includes tax revenues from closing a break for buyers of private jets because they think it's bad economics? Or is it because almost every one of them signed the Grover Norquist pledge that they would never raise taxes under any circumstances?

In a sense, it's a trivial example. Closing that loophole would have virtually no effect at all on our long-term budget deficit. But in another sense, it's the crux of the matter. Fierce partisanship is one thing, and it's clearly part of the American political landscape.

We have profound differences and a political system that allows those differences to be both heard and embodied in our policies. But at the end of the day, our history shows that partisans compromise in the interest of preserving the common good. Those who refuse to do so have no place in this debate.

They are not legislators, working with their opponents to hammer out the best deal for both their constituents and the nation. They're pledge- takers who are threatening to abandon the common good for narrow self- interest. And that must not stand.

I'm Jared Bernstein.

HUDSON: Obviously there's a lot here to be said and Jared won't have the last word on the debt debate. In the coming days and weeks, we'll continue to bring you thoughts and views from all sides.

GHARIB: And finally tonight, hold on to your cell phones if you plan to visit Miami, New York, or Los Angeles. According to a recent study by mobile security company Lookout, those are the three top cities for cell phone loss or theft. The remainder of the list spans coast to coast. It includes Phoenix, Sacramento, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Philadelphia, and Tampa.

Basically everywhere, Tom. And pools, taxis, and airplanes are the top three worst places to lose your cell phone. And that's why I always have mine right next to me so I don't lose it, can't live without it.

HUDSON: Top of my list, toddlers, a tough place to lose a cell phone as well, toddlers.

GHARIB: That's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, July 18th. I'm Susie Gharib. Have a great evening, everyone.

You too, Tom.

HUDSON: You, as well, Susie.

I'm Tom Hudson. Good night, thanks for joining us this evening. We'll see you right back here tomorrow.

END

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER, CEO, NYSE EURONEXT: I think people are going to have to feel more comfortable that their job is more stable, the roof over their head is stable, they can take care of their family.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: The head of the New York Stock Exchange, Duncan Niederauer says investor confidence will come once we have consumer confidence.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: And at the New York Stock Exchange, a show of investor confidence for today at least. The blue chips rack up a triple digit gain, powered higher by the nation`s factories kicking into higher gear. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, January 4.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone. Wall Street kicked off 2010 with a rally. The Dow surged over 155 points, the NASDAQ rose 39 and the S&P 500 jumped nearly 18.

HUDSON: Susie, it was a heck of a run the first trading day, good economic news triggered the buying. Investors encouraged by an upbeat report from the Institute of Supply Management showing those factory orders ramping up, jobs ramping up and prices finally starting to head up as well.

GHARIB: And comforting comments from Fed chief Bernanke yesterday also helped, implying there`s no hurry to raise interest rates, at least for now. UBS strategist Mike Ryan expects stocks to continue to move higher from here.

MIKE RYAN, STRATEGIST, UBS WEALTH MANAGEMENT: The market I think is moving in anticipation of several events. They`re moving in anticipation of what they believe will be a moderate but sustainable economic recovery. They`re moving in anticipation of an earnings recovery that should have earnings returning towards trend -- not immediately, but slowly returning towards trend and also an environment that remains fairly benign from an inflation standpoint.

GHARIB: The head of the New York Stock Exchange told me he`s also optimistic about the stock market in 2010. I talked to Duncan Niederauer right after the opening bell rang here at the big board and I asked him for his market forecast.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER, CEO, NYSE EURONEXT: I think we`re in such a better place than we were a year ago that it`s hard not to be optimistic. So I`m very constructive about where the market should go from here. We look at our IPO pipeline, it`s pretty solid. I think you`ve got corporate earnings continuing to grow and I think you`ve got a lot of the uncertainty that was really prevailing at this time last year, is out of the way. So I`m pretty optimistic for `010.

GHARIB: But Duncan I have been talking to a lot of market strategists and even traders right here on the floor. And they`re talking about a correction for 2010.

NIEDERAUER: I happen to not agree. It`s easy to predict the correction because we`re up, the Dow`s up 60 percent since March, S&P is up more than that, NASDAQ is up 80 percent since March. The indices are all up a lot so I think it`s right to expect a correction. The market feels fairly valued to me. It doesn`t feel overvalued. I think people are going to be much more focused on the economy because I think corporate earnings are going to deliver the goods this year.

GHARIB: I`m sure you get asked this a lot by individual investors. Is it safe for me to put my money in the stock market? Everybody is still afraid about putting their money in stocks these days. What is going to take to restore investor confidence?

NIEDERAUER: I think it`s about how they feel as a consumer first. So I`m going to be watching the consumer confidence metrics and how the economic recovery is going in `010. Because I think that is what people are now going to focus their attention on. So I think people are going to have to feel more comfortable that their job is more stable, the roof over their head is stable, they can take care of their family and then I think it is a necessary -- that is a necessary step to take before we are going to have people feel better and come back to the equity markets on the retail side.

GHARIB: Let`s talk a little bit about financial regulatory reform. The American public is looking to Congress to pass new rules that hopefully will prevent the financial system from breaking down in the future. What do you like the most? What don`t you like?

NIEDERAUER: I think a lot of what you are going to see from the SEC is directionally correct. It is going to be a lot around market structure. I don`t know if it is necessarily going to be in the category of preventing a crisis. I think the best thing that has been talked about is on the OTC derivative space, more central clearing, more transparency. The thing I`m most worried about on the regulatory side is this talk of a transaction tax which I think would have very, very negative implications for volumes and for the cost of trading for retail investors.

GHARIB: And this transaction tax would be on trades of stocks and options and futures. Is that a tax really just going to be passed on to investors?

NIEDERAUER: That`s my view. I`m actually writing a piece right now that I`m going to be distributing in the next couple of weeks. And among the points I make is one of the points you just made Susie, which is it`s absolutely a pass-through tax. This idea, the way it`s been packaged, to sell it to Main Street that it is a tax on Wall Street. It is not a tax on Wall Street. It is a tax on Main Street. It will flow down to the retail investor. It will flow down to the mutual fund holder. It is not going to be paid for by Wall Street.

GHARIB: Duncan, how do you rate President Obama`s performance in terms of his position on things like banks, financial reform, executive compensation?

NIEDERAUER: I would sum it up this way. We`ve been very pleased with the words that he and the Treasury secretary have spoken. We have given them kudos for the measures they appear to be ready to take. I think now in `010 the proof is in the pudding. Are they actually going to carry out what they say they are going to do and follow through?

GHARIB: What do you think the president needs to do in 2010 that will restore confidence in American businesses and the markets?

NIEDERAUER: What the president needs to do is what he started to do a few weeks ago which is call the banks in together and say crisis averted. You guys are well on the road to recovery. Your profitability shows that. Please start lending to small and medium-sized institutions and from our vantage point, the credit market is still predominantly closed to small and medium-sized enterprises and we think it`s critical that he apply pressure in the right places to get that credit flowing freely again.

GHARIB: You mentioned earlier about IPOs. There is a lot of buzz about a flurry of IPOs and the NYSE and the NASDAQ are lobbying hard to get those listings. How much of it will come your way?

NIEDERAUER: We operate in a very competitive environment for the listings. We win more than our fair share. We have and I`m very confident will continue to do so. The pipeline we`ve got coming in the next few months dramatically tilted our way. So we`re pretty excited about it.

GHARIB: This first trading week of the year, we`re talking to the leaders of the nation`s big exchanges. On Wednesday Craig Donohue, CEO of the CME Group in Chicago and then on Thursday, Robert Greifeld, CEO of the NASDAQ OMX. Tom.

HUDSON: Susie, some of the other big stories tonight. Putting away the hammers and the nails at building sites in November. We`ve seen a drop-off in both home building and commercial projects leading to a 0.6 percent drop in construction spending. This is the seventh straight month on the downside.

Swiss drug maker Novartis is eyeing complete control of eye care company Alcon. Today, Novartis announcing plans to take over Alcon, paying Nestle nearly $39 billion for the 77 percent stake in Alcon that Nestle owns.

Some good and some bad in what Bank of America`s new CEO Brian Moynihan sees for the future. Forecasters at the bank predict the U.S. economy will grow more than 3 percent this year. But that slow pace also means the unemployment rate will stay high.

And watch out, above! How about this, the world`s tallest skyscraper now open in Dubai. At 2,717 feet, the Burj Khalifa is named for the leader of the neighboring Abu Dhabi which just pitched in $10 billion to bail Dubai out of its financial crisis.

GHARIB: An evolution of thinking for the Fed chairman. That`s how political economist Tom Gallagher today characterized this weekend`s remarks we told you about from Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke. Bernanke said low interest rates were not to blame for the housing crisis; a lack of regulation was. Stephanie Dhue spoke with Gallagher about the message the Fed chairman delivered.

STEPHANIE DHUE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Bernanke said that sometimes the Fed should use interest rate policy to address bubbles. Do you see the Fed making a move to address emerging markets or commodities?

TOM GALLAGHER, POLITICAL ECONOMIST, ISI: That is a change on Bernanke`s part. He was very much a part of the Greenspan-led consensus on how monetary policy wants to approach bubbles, which is to say that monetary policy shouldn`t adjust for bubbles at all until it was time to pick up the pieces. Now I think the central banking community is moving toward a view that the central bank should be worried about the development of asset bubbles, primarily know that regulation is the preferred approach. But there are some circumstances in which monetary policy can play a role. So that does reflect a bit of an evolution, his thinking along with the rest of the central banking community during the course of this bubble, this boom-bust cycle. So I think that has been a shift on his part.

DHUE: Bernanke says that low interest rates weren`t the reason for the housing bubble. Do you see that as a defense of the Greenspan Fed or a defense of the current Fed?

GALLAGHER: Given that he was there during most of that time period, it was really a defense of the Fed and his own role in it, I think. And I think that he`s on pretty good grounds in arguing that the monetary policy was not being reason for the housing bubble. He defended the Fed`s record by pointing to a defensible calculation on where the Fed funds rate should be. It wasn`t very far from that and he was responding to a lot of criticism that the Fed had unusually low interest rates for a long period of time and that`s what Fed the housing bubble. Instead he presented some calculations that suggested that it was the development of alternative mortgages that produced very low initial monthly payments and that that system is what lead to the housing bubble as both the borrower and lender believed that home prices would continue to rise and they would never have to pay the higher mortgage payments that would be due later on.

DHUE: Now Bernanke`s faced a lot of criticism as he has gone before the Senate to keep his job. Do you think he`ll be an effective advocate for reform?

GALLAGHER: Well, I don`t think the views of the Fed chairman are an especially important part of the outcome of this debate. There is a lot of interest groups that are affected by this and they are fighting very hard on this. And I think it`s hard for any Fed chairman to really have a material impact on the outcome of that debate.

DHUE: And bottom line for investors looking at Bernanke talking about asset bubbles and interest rates, any change here?

GALLAGHER: No, I thought especially if you take Bernanke`s and Cohen`s speeches together, there wasn`t a lot of guidance on where interest rates are headed in the near-term. But I think that you have to assume, you have to read those speeches as suggesting that not anything is -- that nothing is going to happen any time soon.

DHUE: And not any time soon, not first quarter, not second quarter.

GALLAGHER: I think that the Fed is likely to raise interest rates in the third quarter. And I think given how far away that is, that`s still six months away at the earliest, it`s hard to be very specific on that. I think that probably the important action for the financial markets, even more than the rate hike will be when they change the language, the guidance they are giving the markets on interest rates. Right now they are promising to keep interest rates more or less at zero for an extended period of time. When that extended period phrase gets dropped, it is probably when markets start to react and risk assets will probably perform more poorly. When that happens and I suspect that is a second quarter event, and again, so not anything any time soon.

DHUE: Tom Gallagher, thanks so much for joining us.

GALLAGHER: Thank you.

HUDSON: Still ahead on the program, can Google do for mobile phones what it`s done for web searches and advertising? The tech titan gets ready to lift the curtain on its own smart phone.

GHARIB: Tom as you heard me complain, it`s so very cold here in New York so I`m not surprised that that`s the theme that you`re going to be looking at in your market focus tonight.

HUDSON: Absolutely. That cold snap that`s really gripping much of the country Susie pushing around energy, even orange juice prices. Plus we`re going to talk about betting on China and some new highs today for the first of the year for some big tech names in our market focus.

But that Arctic cold air gripping much of the country is sending energy prices up to prices not seen since October. Energy also getting a boost certainly from today`s better than expected manufacturing numbers we told you about earlier.

So let`s take a look at some of the numbers. Crude oil jumping to over $80 a barrel. In addition to the cold weather, a weaker dollar may have helped out, also a break out over $83 for oil would take it to post- recession highs. Nat gas also catching fire with this cold snap and with the freezing temps reaching down into Florida, even orange juice futures jumping, but ended with only about half of the gains seen earlier in the day. Watch those OJ prices by the way, as futures have doubled in the past year.

Speaking of the surprise rise in manufacturing activity fueling some hope maybe that the job picture finally may be seeing some improvement. The December jobs reports are due out on Friday of course and the job gains are expected to be seen again in temporary workers, as has been the case over the past four months. Now the temp hiring stocks are already moving, maybe in anticipation.

Stocks like Manpower (MAN), Robert Half International, Kelly Services (KELVA) seeing a nice bid today. Spherion (SPN) also moving higher by better than 8 1/2 percent. All these stocks hitting multi-week highs ahead of those Friday`s jobs data.

Early on here already just one day in 2010 looking a lot like 2009, with last year`s leaders helping push the market indices higher. Information technology the single best performing sector throughout all of 2009 and the big guys continue to hit some prices not seen in really about a couple of years. Take a look at some of these longer term charts, two years long here on Cisco (CSCO) breaking out to the upside on this first trading day of the year, running after $25 a share, a price not seen since the summer of 2008. Volume also stronger than normal on today`s move higher.

How about Microsoft (MSFT), another two-year chart here, continues to find buyers over $30 a share. Today`s buying takes Microsoft to a level shareholders haven`t enjoyed in two years. The rally in these stocks is helpful for many growth mutual fund investors as these stocks tend to be very popular with those kinds of mutual funds.

Intel (INTC) also getting in the act, jumping to its highest price since October. Brokerage firm Baird upgrading it, calling Intel a quote value and defensive idea and continuing to echo the idea that businesses will be buying new computers in 2010.

The action in these three stocks comes really just a few days before the beginning of the big consumer electronics show, which spotlights tech trends in the making.

Speaking of which, watch Apple (AAPL) stock as the "Wall Street Journal" tonight quoting sources saying the company will unveil a long- awaited tablet computer at that convention. It could measure 10 to 11 inches and ship out in March around $1,000. Apple stock over $214 a share, $214, is at all-time highs.

With the market breaking out to these post-recession highs, some market leading sectors have seen mixed performance.

Thanks to that Intel (INTC) move, semiconductor exchange traded fund leading the way for technology above the range in December.

The economically sensitive transportation ETF however remains below new highs perhaps kept in check a little bit by oil.

Financial stocks also turning up but remain well below their October highs.

Betting on gaming in the new year, how about this, a couple of gambling stocks see big buying volume today. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) jumping more than 9 percent on twice average daily volume. UBS thinking the stock should see $20 a share in the next year. It also raised its rating on Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and that stock responded, up on bigger than usual volume. The price target here $76.

The analyst likes both casinos based not on what happens in Las Vegas but what could happen in Macau, China. While Vegas revenues are predicted to be flat, UBS thinks gaming in Macau is tracking better than expected.

And that`s our market focus tonight.

GHARIB: Could Google have iPhone envy? That`s a question the tech blogs are asking tonight as we wait for an announcement tomorrow from the Internet giant. Google is expected to unwrap its own entry into the smart phone market. But as usual, exactly what the company is up to is less than clear. Scott Gurvey reports.

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The Google phone is one of the worst kept secrets in an industry that doesn`t keep secrets very well. Since the web site Engadget got its hands on what Google is calling the Nexus one, editor-in-chief Joshua Topolsky says the response has been extraordinary.

JOSHUA TOPOLSKY, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, ENGADGET.COM (BY TELEPHONE): The reaction about this phone has been kind of insane. It`s been phenomenal. And since we put up our hands-on post, there`s been an enormous amount of traffic with people coming to the site to see those pictures and to hear what we had to say about the phone.

GURVEY: The big question Google will face at tomorrow`s unveiling is, why? Google`s Android operating system already appears on scores of phones including the Motorola Droid recently introduced by Verizon Wireless. The Nexus phone does not appear to make any major improvements on the Droid. And Gene Munster, technology analyst at Piper Jaffray, says Google`s unknown motives are alarming the industry.

GENE MUNSTER, TECHNOLOGY ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: If they put out a phone that shows all the good things that Android can do I think their partners well be happy to see that. If they come out and actually try to grab market share and aggressively price this, I think it`s going to create quite a high level of friction between all the players in the market.

GURVEY: Rumors about Google`s marketing plans have industry blogs on fire. Price points range from $500 to free. T-Mobile may offer the phone packaged with a two-year contract for $200. Sales of conventional mobile phones have been dropping since the economy tanked. But Apple`s iPhone has remained a strong seller throughout the downturn. And Michael Gikas of "Consumer Reports," says interest in smart phones is jumping as the economy recovers.

MICHAEL GIKAS, SENIOR EDITOR, CONSUMER REPORTS: Sales of smart phones keep going up and the number one reason is people want these extra features. And they`re going to pay more for them too. Not just for the phones but they`re going to be paying higher monthly premiums for data plans and text messaging and all sorts of other things.

GURVEY: The Google phone is said to run only on GSM networks. GSM is frequently found in countries overseas but in the United States, this means the Nexus one will only run on the T-Mobile system. Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

GHARIB: Here`s what we`re watching for tomorrow. We`ll get a look at the health of the housing sector when the National Association of Realtors release the pending home sales for November. Factory orders for November will be released as well. Also we`ll see how U.S. auto makers fared in December and hear from some car dealers for their take on what will drive the auto industry this year.

While we won`t know about General Motors` U.S. sales until tomorrow, its sales in China are revving up. The auto maker says last year it sold a record 1.8 vehicles there. That`s up 67 percent. The top selling brands in China were Buick and Chevrolet. And helping things: a government program to defray the cost of buying fuel efficient cars and trucks. Some of those programs are now being phased out, but GM thinks its sales in China are still on track to keep growing down the road.

HUDSON: Until we make a profit, I won`t take a paycheck. Now, that`s what the new head of Continental Airlines told employees today, Jeff Smisek took the top job Friday after Larry Kellner left to join a private equity firm. Smisek says the tone for business is set at the top, so if everyone wants better pay and benefits, the business needs to make money. That`s not happening now. Continental Air is deep in the red. The carrier lost $367 million in the first nine months of last year.

GHARIB: Tonight`s commentator thinks we`ll see a better economic reality in 2010. He`s Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody`seconomy.com.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY`SECONOMY.COM: For the first time in a very long time, I`m able to say that I`m optimistic about the economy`s prospects. 2010 won`t be a great year. That would be inappropriate given that unemployment will likely remain in the double- digits through much of the year, but it will feel pretty good after what we have been through. Job growth is set to resume in the next few months and will be strong enough to meaningfully bring down unemployment by year`s end. This optimism is based on the belief that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates anytime soon and that the Obama administration and Congress will provide more temporary help to unemployed workers and hard- pressed state and local governments.

A stronger global economy and softer U.S. dollar will also fuel a revival in export growth. Selling what we produce to the rest of the world will be the principal source of long term growth and this growth driver will kick in this year. While the economy will make its way back this year, it won`t come roaring back. Businesses are no longer panicked, but they remain cautious and will be slow to hire and to invest. A lack of credit is weighing heavily on those small businesses so vital to the job machine. The ongoing foreclosure crisis also threatens to push house prices even lower. The wrongs that led to the financial crisis and great recession are being slowly righted. With a bit more help from policy makers, the current recovery will evolve into a self sustaining economic expansion in 2010. This is Mark Zandi.

HUDSON: So it`s a new year and as you can seen in this broadcast, we have some new features here at NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, so let me show you around our new home base. It`s called a virtual set and chances are you`ve seen them before. This one was created by our graphic artists and is controlled by a system of computers. If you were here in the studio with me, you`d see I`m actually standing on a big green backdrop. The set and other elements are added in our control room. Now moving to this type of electronic set up lets us give you critical analysis of news stories, stock market information and data, in new ways. It helps us make information visual, more interesting and easy to see at a glance. And it also helps you connect with our content in a clear and concise way. So while there may be fewer stock quotes, there will be more analysis.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Beautiful.

HUDSON: Hope you find it beautiful as well and Susie clearly the presentation has changed, some faces have changed but some things will never change here at NBR.

GHARIB: You look really good against that green background, yeah, you are right. The good stuff and the important stuff is still here, same mission that we have had for the past 30 years. We want to educate and empower you, our viewers, so that you can make better financial decisions. So keep watching.

HUDSON: And it`s great to start out on a day with the Dow hitting new 15 month highs, how about that.

GHARIB: We`ll call it the Tom Hudson effect.

HUDSON: Yeah, right, OK, you`ll be about the only one that calls it that, maybe you and my mom.

That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Monday, January 4. I`m Tom Hudson. Good night to everybody and good night to you too Susie.

GHARIB: And good night to you Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Good night, everyone and we hope to see all of you again tomorrow night.

END
