urn:contentItem:5KR6-6HX1-JBHT-D53K-00000-00Nightly Business Report2010-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportWalthamFULL TEXT

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: The mid-term election is just 11 days away and Wall Street strategists are keeping a close eye on the races.

ALEC YOUNG, MARKET STRATEGIST, STANDARD & POOR`S: We think if the Republicans win the House and if they make some headway in the Senate, they`ll have the leverage to extend the Bush tax cuts for everybody.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: S&P`s Alec Young says that could mean strong economic growth for the first half of 2011. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, October 22.

GHARIB: Good evening, everyone. The clock is ticking for the mid- term elections. Americans on Main Street are eager for their voices to be heard. And you know Tom, investors on Wall Street are waiting for a post- election market rally and history shows they might just get one.

HUDSON: It certainly does Susie, mid-term elections classic for case studies on the stock market. In the third year of a first-term presidency, which would be next year, stocks have rallied every time since 1939. The "Stock Traders Almanac," which tracks these things says in years where there`s a Democrat in the White House, stocks have rallied more than 21 percent.

GHARIB: This time Tom, the run up might have come early. S&P strategist Alec Young notes the Dow has surged more than a thousand points since September.

YOUNG: There is building anticipation that the Republicans will take the House. So certainly I think that`s probably factored into the market and viewed as a positive given tremendous tax and regulatory uncertainty that is currently hanging over a sluggish domestic recovery.

GHARIB: Now two of the most closely watched Senate races in the country are in Illinois and Florida. Both are races without any incumbents. And with both states struggling with double-digit unemployment, those races are all about the economy. As we continue our coverage, "Mid- Term 2010-- It`s the Economy," we bring you two reports tonight. We begin with Diane Eastabrook in Illinois, where the focus is on regaining thousands of lost manufacturing jobs.

DIANE EASTABROOK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Shuttered factories have become part of the landscape in rust belt states like Illinois. In the last two years, the recession has claimed more than 100,000 manufacturing jobs here. Job search boot camps are attracting twice as many displaced workers as they did a year ago. Some like Craig Radcliffe want more help from Washington.

CRAIG RADCLIFFE, DISPLACED WORKER: I would think that maybe at this time that you would want to open up to more ideas and not really worry about how many people think you should do this or that.

EASTABROOK: In Illinois, jobs and the economy are central issues in the campaign for the U.S. Senate where Republican Congressman Mark Kirk is running against Democratic state Treasurer Alexi Giannoulias. Some Illinois manufacturers call this election the most important one in decades.

BERT MILLER, PRESIDENT, PHOENIX CLOSURES: The policies that we`ve seen implemented in Washington in the last two years are killing American business.

EASTABROOK: Bert Miller is the president of Phoenix Closures -- a 120-year-old firm that makes plastic container caps. Miller wants less government regulation and tax cuts extended for everyone, including the wealthy, something Kirk favors, but Giannoulias opposes.

MILLER: If you start raising those taxes, you are going to find that there is less money to invest in capital equipment and things like that.

EASTABROOK: While the economy and jobs loom large in Illinois this election year, so too does scandal. Both candidates for the U.S. Senate are battling controversy that political scientists say could overshadow other issues. For Giannoulias it`s the failure of his family`s Chicago bank which allegedly made loans to the mob a decade ago. For Kirk, it`s the embellishment of his naval record. Northwestern University political science Professor Victoria Defrancesco Soto thinks these issues could influence voters more than the economy.

VICTORIA DEFRANCESCO SOTO, PROFESSOR, NORTHWESTERN UNIV.: The economy has been going downhill in Illinois for a long time. We`re the rust belt, so people were consciously aware of what was going on unlike a Nevada. So, they`re in the midst of an economic downturn, but they don`t want to add insult to injury by having somebody who is a liar or who has links to the mob.

EASTABROOK: Despite their reasons, Soto thinks the way Illinoisans cast their votes in this election could send a strong message to the president. Since it`s his old Senate seat, the outcome could be viewed as a referendum on his policies. Diane Eastabrook, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Naperville, Illinois.

JEFF YASTINE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: This is Jeff Yastine. Foreclosure signs and political signs. The two go together in Florida, where housing defaults are the fifth highest in the nation. That, combined with a 12 percent unemployment rate and an economy just limping along is driving the sentiment of voters like Tracy Flett. He owns a south- Florida based roofing company which has had its share of layoffs. He`s also one of the thousands of people who went to the polls for early voting this week.

TRACY FLETT, EARLY VOTER: I`m looking for someone who cares about balance, someone who cares about the middle class; I`m looking for someone who`s looks at the right things for big corporations, but also the right things for the small business owner. And I`m looking for people who care.

YASTINE: The right things for business are key factors in the three- way race for Florida`s open Senate seat. Republican Marco Rubio has been hammering away with a low-tax message that`s made him the front-runner. Republican-governor turned-independent Charlie Crist and Congressman Kendrick Meek running a distant second and third. Rubio has benefited from major support and endorsements from national business groups, like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the National Federation of Independent Business. The Senate race hasn`t seen any endorsements from the Florida Chamber of Commerce. But its president and CEO Mark Wilson says the group`s members, more than anything, are looking for policy predictability in Washington.

MARK WILSON, FLORIDA CHAMBER OF COMMERCE: The private sector, when they know that we`re not going to change our taxes around, when they`re not going to force benefits on small businesses that they can`t afford, when they feel that it`s safe to invest again and they feel that they can invest in employees and in technology and productivity improvement, then we`re going to see job growth in this state and in this country, that we`ve not seen in over a decade.

YASTINE: Professor Charles Zelden of Nova Southeastern University, says in a state like Florida ardent pro-business messages, like low taxes, are an especially winning formula. But it come with a catch.

CHARLES ZELDEN, PROF., LEGAL STUDIES, NOVA SOUTHEASTERN UNIV.: The problem is what do you do to compensate for less income coming in? What do you cut? The problem is we don`t want services to be cut. We want a stimulus that keeps our teachers working, that keeps our cops working, keeps our firefighters working. But we also don`t want to pay more taxes. You can`t do both.

YASTINE: As this trio of Senate candidates hits the homestretch, Florida residents will soon make their priorities known. Jeff Yastine, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Miami.

HUDSON: Here are the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. It was a mixed end to the week on Wall Street. The Dow Industrials fell 14 points, the NASDAQ added 19, the S&P 500 up nearly three. Trading volume fell on both the big board and the NASDAQ to the lowest levels of the week.

U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is urging limits on trade imbalances for the world`s biggest economies. Speaking at a gathering of G-20 finance ministers and central bankers in South Korea, Geithner said he thinks G-20 nations need to keep their current account balance below 4 percent of gross domestic product. After weeks of protests and strikes, the French senate has approved a measure hiking that nation`s retirement age from 60 to 62. Final approval of the change is expected Monday. France`s unions say the protests will continue, despite today`s vote.

HUDSON: Still ahead on the program, sailing the seas of a weak U.S. economy. We bring you illustrator David Gillette`s latest Inkonomics.

GHARIB: Big tech companies are sitting on billions of dollars of cash, including Intel. Earlier this week, the chip giant announced plans to spend $6 billion on research and development. It`s also forking over more than $7 billion to acquire Internet security firmMcAfee. Stacy Smith is the chief financial officer at Intel. He tells NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT using cash wisely is good for Intel investors.

STACY SMITH, CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER, INTEL: I think companies have a moral obligation to do the right things for their constituencies and for us our constituencies are our owners, so we`re always looking at how do we create shareholder value. Our employees and then where we have operations we want to do the right things for the countries and the environment and that constituency as well.

GHARIB: On Monday, you can see our entire interview with Smith as he explains how Intel makes decisions about its $20 billion pile of cash.

Tom, it was a mixed day for the markets but for the week they were up. That makes three in a row. Some nervousness as you mentioned earlier about that G-20 meeting of finance ministers this coming up weekend.

HUDSON: Yes, nervousness about that communique that will come out before the market opens on Monday clearly, but the focus still remains on earnings throughout this week and likely for the next couple of weeks. Let`s get you updated here Susie in tonight`s "Market Focus." And the reason why the focus remains on earnings, this was just the first of three peak weeks for earnings and those earnings helped the major indices clock another week of gains as Susie mentioned. And here are those gains beginning with the Dow Industrials (DJI) adding 0.6 of a percent thanks to gains on Monday, Wednesday and Thursday. The NASDAQ (IXIC) meantime gained 0.4 of a percent, gained four out of the past five sessions as you can see. The S&P 500 (GSPC) 0.6 of a percent higher tonight compared to one week ago.

It was a mixed market overall today. Technology and energy shares really led the gainers. The Dow was hurt by a couple of those earnings reports. Verizon (VZ) one of them. Here are the results. They were better than estimates, but down from a year ago as you can see. Even though Verizon predicted its earnings for the rest of the year will be at the high end of its guidance, shares sold off. Let`s take a look at the stock here, falling more than 1 percent. It was the second biggest percent drop for the Dow Industrial components. It`s now at a one-month low. One concern for Verizon: far fewer new wireless subscribers last quarter than rival AT&T. The other big Dow loser American Express (AXP), dropping 3 percent. Earnings last night were better than expected but loan volume remains low and that`s fueling worries about future revenue growth.

Now oil service stocks really helped energy put in the best sector gains today. Among the leaders here, Schlumberger (SLB). Earnings easily beating estimates after excluding the impact of the acquisition of Smith International. Revenue jumped despite that deep water moratorium that was in place during most of the third quarter. The stock was able to add more than 5 percent on pretty heavy volume. This is its highest price that Schlumberger has seen since early May. Earnings were also in play in technology, helping the top three sector gainers and all three of these are software makers. Take a look. Compuware (CPWR) was up more than 12 percent on some strong earnings. This is a two-year high for shares tonight. CA (CA) jumped 5 percent to its highest price since May. Strong earnings, especially the performance in North America helped last quarter. And Citrix Systems (CTXS) bounced 4 percent. It had a stronger than expected outlook after decent results.

Investors clearly had an appetite for restaurant stocks, pizza, yeah one of them, also Mexican and cheesecake, how about that? We`ll begin with BJ`s (BJRI). It runs pizza and brewery restaurants. Strong results and positive analyst comments fueled a 17 percent run in shares today. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) boosted its same store sales outlook after strong earnings. Shares added 15 percent. Both BJ`s and Chipotle are at all-time highs tonight. Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) also getting an analyst upgrade after some strong results. Shares jumping 8 percent.

Busy week for IPOs, five of them hitting the Street, including two more Chinese-based firms. Take a look at all five here. Tal Education (XRS) started at $10 this week. It provides tutoring services in China. Shares continued jumping throughout the week. ShangPharma (SHP) does research for drug makers. It began trading at $15, closed below that price tonight. Three others -- Vera Bradley`s (VRA) IPO $16 per share, nice big run there. It makes designer handbags. Debit card company NetSpend (NTSP) had investors spending. It started at $11, closing tonight over $13. And Brio (BBRG) is the first American restaurant to go public since 2006. It started at $14 per share and clearly is higher tonight. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: As we`ve been reporting, corporate America is feeling better about earnings. Investors have been rewarded with a market rally. But there seems to be a disconnect with what most Americans are experiencing: lost jobs, lost value in their homes and on and on. With that in mind, we bring you another installment of "Inkonomics with David Gillette." David`s an Emmy-winning illustrator and essayist at Twin Cities public television. Tonight, he ponders the question: has our economic ship sailed?

DAVID GILLETTE: If you`re on a mission to understand the economy, there`s no better place to start than your own back yard. For this cartoonist, we`re talking (INAUDIBLE) Minnesota, a small community just west of Minneapolis and resting on the shores of Lake Minnetonka, a 14,528 acre fresh water playground which incidentally empties itself into Minnehaha Creek, flows through the city of Minnetonka and then drops over Minnehaha Falls. Basically it`s a land where everything starts with minne, the Dakota word for water. And when people in this part of the world want to flex their financial muscles, they spent a lot of money on the minne. It`s an economy measured in boats. But here`s the surprising part. No matter what you may have heard over the last few years about the sour economy, there are still plenty of boats on Lake Minnetonka.

On the surface this makes no sense. If you turn on any electronic device, including practically the toaster, you`re told we`re either in the middle of, emerging from or returning to a recession. For most people this implies a lack of jobs, a lack of money and you would think a lack of time for practicing the principle of displacement. But there they are -- boats. And according to the people who take them to market, the bigger they are, the faster they sell. That`s why out of all the story lines we`re knitting around the contemporary American economy, wasteful government spending, in- exceptional education, foreign competition, I`m hanging my life jacket on the resurgence of financial stratification.

You see, according to the unique glacial pock marks I call home, this country isn`t suffering from an overall shortage of wealth. It`s just that the money we do have is disproportionately concentrated in a handful of 40-foot weekend cruisers and that`s actually where I`m going to stop. You see I`m not stupid. I don`t fully understand the economic forces that allow the rich to get richer while the not rich get not richer. But I do understand human nature. And if I go on national television and make it sound like the entire economic collapse rests on the shoulders of the people who buy boats, my chances of spending a day on the lake are going to end up in the drink.

GHARIB: So Tom, do you think Ben Bernanke knows about the Minnetonka indicator? Maybe we should tell him about the water effect on the economy.

HUDSON: I tell you, as long as those boats are seaworthy, it maybe a lot easier to refloat them, certainly, that`s definitely the truth. Let`s get you updated on what we`re watching for next week. We`ve got a lot on the calendar. Our Friday "Market Monitor" James Paulsen. He`s chief strategist at Wells Capital Management. We`re also due to get an update on housing from the September reports on both new and existing home sales as well as the first report on the third quarter GDP out next Friday. Monday our shoptalk series look at Ikea and how its eco-friendly policies are giving it a competitive advantage.

The Postal Service says the increase is needed because of losses caused by a drop in mail volume. It blames it on the weak economy and a shift to email and online bill paying.

HUDSON: Federal regulators are now getting involved in the fee dispute between Cablevision and News Corp. The Federal Communications Commission today sent letters to the heads of both companies. They`ve asked to describe how they`re negotiating in good faith. About three million Cablevision subscribers in New York City and Philadelphia have been cut off from Fox programming. The blackout will enter its second week tomorrow if a deal is not reached.

MARK SKOUSEN, EDITOR, "FORECASTS & STRATEGIES": Tom, good to be with you.

SKOUSEN: I think we`re going to see inflation down the road. But we have a triple play right now or hat trick, whatever you want to call it, for investors and I`m very bullish. Because what we have is low interest rates, we have low price inflation and we have easy money by the Fed. And the Fed has deliberately decided to increase inflation to 2 to 3 percent, inflation targeting, that`s what Ben Bernanke cut his teeth on and he`s really trying to impose it.

HUDSON: But we haven`t seen any of that inflation really. Instead we`ve seen disinflation. Still positive numbers, but very, very small.

SKOUSEN: Yes and that`s because the economy is so sluggish, particularly in the United States, unemployment really high. So they`re buying time and that`s great for us as investors because prices for investors are low and it`s an opportunity to be buying and taking advantage of this very unique scenario, because inflation will be coming back. Gold is a great indicator of future inflation and look what that`s doing.

HUDSON: Yes, over $1300 an ounce. So what markets do you like if the Fed is successful and is able to reignite inflation in the months or years ahead?

SKOUSEN: As we can see, this has been very bearish for the dollar, but it`s very bullish for stocks, bonds and commodities. So I`m fully invested in all three of those areas.

HUDSON: So you still like fixed income, even though interest rates are so low.

SKOUSEN: Well, fixed income, no, not Treasury bills that only pay 2 or 3 percent. What I`m talking about is high dividend paying stocks, the kind that I`ve been recommending to your viewers.

HUDSON: Sure, even though you do like dividends, your first new pick here, you`re clearly not afraid of volatility. This is a new stock pick, Rare Element Resources. We`re going to take a look at a chart here. This owns Rare Earth Element mine in Wyoming, REE the ticker symbol. Is Rare Earth Elements as you know Mark a source of some building tensions between the U.S. and China? Are you willing to play that geo-political risk?

SKOUSEN: This is a major geo-political risk and I will warn your viewers and they can see from the chart this stock has already doubled, tripled, quadrupled in value and so it is a risky speculation. But this problem is not going away. China is trying to corner the rare earth market, which is this group of 12 to 17 elements that nobody has ever heard of before that is critical in military applications and in hybrid cars, in cell phones, in computers and you name it and they control 97 percent of this market.

HUDSON: Mark, let me ask you, what kind of price target do you have? What kind of holding period for a volatile stock like that?

SKOUSEN: Well a lot of people think, it`s a micro cap right now, a lot of people think this is a billion dollar company, so it could possibly triple in value, but it is extremely volatile and investors need to know that.

HUDSON: Ninety seconds, I want to get to everything here. A new pick SeaDrill. This is a deep water energy driller, close to a new high. Why choose this deep water driller?

SKOUSEN: Well, because they were hurt by the BP scandal and they are still recovering from it. They have a very nice dividend yield of almost 9 percent. And they`re aggressively expanding. I think it`s a very good play on the expanding energy area.

HUDSON: OK. April 23rd you were last with us. You had three picks back then, two of them, the Ishares exchange-traded fund following Hong Kong, that stock up 17 percent. American Capital, a private equity firm, up by better than almost 6 percent. These are stock returns only. Do you still like these two?

SKOUSEN: Yes, I like Hong Kong because it`s only selling at 15 times earnings, 3 percent dividend. It is the center of growth in Asia. I like American Capital because there`s insider buying recently and it`s still selling below book. That`s a great story.

HUDSON: You also like EPD, this is a natural gas play, Enterprise Products, 15 1/2 percent on its stock price, plus a nice dividend on top of that. Do you still like it?

SKOUSEN: Yes, but I think Dan Duncan, the late, great Dan Duncan died recently. He bought a bunch of stock before hand. It a great rising dividend story, but I`m going to sell that and put that money in Sea Drill.

HUDSON: Take you profits. Any disclosures tonight?

SKOUSEN: Just these are some of the stocks we`re recommending in our services, but I don`t own any myself.

HUDSON: Our "Market Monitor "this evening, Mark Skousen. He`s editor of the market letter "Forecasts and Strategies."

SKOUSEN: Thank you.

GHARIB: And Tom, before we say good night, looking ahead to next week we`ve got a lot to cover, more earnings, more election coverage, more about the markets and of course we`re going to be talking about upcoming decisions being made in Washington at the Fed.

HUDSON: Absolutely, the looming Federal Reserve meeting, which is a week from Wednesday, the day after Election Day. It`s going to be a busy couple weeks here. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on this Friday evening. Thanks for joining us. It is October 22. I`m Tom Hudson. Have a great weekend and you too, Susie.

GHARIB: Tom, hope you have a great weekend as well. I`m Susie Gharib. Thanks for watching everyone and we hope to see all of you again on Monday night.

END

ALEC YOUNG, MARKET STRATEGIST, STANDARD & POOR`S: We think if the Republicans win the House and if they make some headway in the Senate, they`ll have the leverage to extend the Bush tax cuts for everybody.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: S&P`s Alec Young says that could mean strong economic growth for the first half of 2011. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, October 22.

GHARIB: Good evening, everyone. The clock is ticking for the mid- term elections. Americans on Main Street are eager for their voices to be heard. And you know Tom, investors on Wall Street are waiting for a post- election market rally and history shows they might just get one.

HUDSON: It certainly does Susie, mid-term elections classic for case studies on the stock market. In the third year of a first-term presidency, which would be next year, stocks have rallied every time since 1939. The "Stock Traders Almanac," which tracks these things says in years where there`s a Democrat in the White House, stocks have rallied more than 21 percent.

GHARIB: This time Tom, the run up might have come early. S&P strategist Alec Young notes the Dow has surged more than a thousand points since September.

YOUNG: There is building anticipation that the Republicans will take the House. So certainly I think that`s probably factored into the market and viewed as a positive given tremendous tax and regulatory uncertainty that is currently hanging over a sluggish domestic recovery.

GHARIB: Now two of the most closely watched Senate races in the country are in Illinois and Florida. Both are races without any incumbents. And with both states struggling with double-digit unemployment, those races are all about the economy. As we continue our coverage, "Mid- Term 2010-- It`s the Economy," we bring you two reports tonight. We begin with Diane Eastabrook in Illinois, where the focus is on regaining thousands of lost manufacturing jobs.

DIANE EASTABROOK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Shuttered factories have become part of the landscape in rust belt states like Illinois. In the last two years, the recession has claimed more than 100,000 manufacturing jobs here. Job search boot camps are attracting twice as many displaced workers as they did a year ago. Some like Craig Radcliffe want more help from Washington.

CRAIG RADCLIFFE, DISPLACED WORKER: I would think that maybe at this time that you would want to open up to more ideas and not really worry about how many people think you should do this or that.

EASTABROOK: In Illinois, jobs and the economy are central issues in the campaign for the U.S. Senate where Republican Congressman Mark Kirk is running against Democratic state Treasurer Alexi Giannoulias. Some Illinois manufacturers call this election the most important one in decades.

BERT MILLER, PRESIDENT, PHOENIX CLOSURES: The policies that we`ve seen implemented in Washington in the last two years are killing American business.

EASTABROOK: Bert Miller is the president of Phoenix Closures -- a 120-year-old firm that makes plastic container caps. Miller wants less government regulation and tax cuts extended for everyone, including the wealthy, something Kirk favors, but Giannoulias opposes.

MILLER: If you start raising those taxes, you are going to find that there is less money to invest in capital equipment and things like that.

EASTABROOK: While the economy and jobs loom large in Illinois this election year, so too does scandal. Both candidates for the U.S. Senate are battling controversy that political scientists say could overshadow other issues. For Giannoulias it`s the failure of his family`s Chicago bank which allegedly made loans to the mob a decade ago. For Kirk, it`s the embellishment of his naval record. Northwestern University political science Professor Victoria Defrancesco Soto thinks these issues could influence voters more than the economy.

VICTORIA DEFRANCESCO SOTO, PROFESSOR, NORTHWESTERN UNIV.: The economy has been going downhill in Illinois for a long time. We`re the rust belt, so people were consciously aware of what was going on unlike a Nevada. So, they`re in the midst of an economic downturn, but they don`t want to add insult to injury by having somebody who is a liar or who has links to the mob.

EASTABROOK: Despite their reasons, Soto thinks the way Illinoisans cast their votes in this election could send a strong message to the president. Since it`s his old Senate seat, the outcome could be viewed as a referendum on his policies. Diane Eastabrook, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Naperville, Illinois.

YASTINE: Professor Charles Zelden of Nova Southeastern University, says in a state like Florida ardent pro-business messages, like low taxes, are an especially winning formula. But it come with a catch.

CHARLES ZELDEN, PROF., LEGAL STUDIES, NOVA SOUTHEASTERN UNIV.: The problem is what do you do to compensate for less income coming in? What do you cut? The problem is we don`t want services to be cut. We want a stimulus that keeps our teachers working, that keeps our cops working, keeps our firefighters working. But we also don`t want to pay more taxes. You can`t do both.

YASTINE: As this trio of Senate candidates hits the homestretch, Florida residents will soon make their priorities known. Jeff Yastine, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Miami.

HUDSON: Here are the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. It was a mixed end to the week on Wall Street. The Dow Industrials fell 14 points, the NASDAQ added 19, the S&P 500 up nearly three. Trading volume fell on both the big board and the NASDAQ to the lowest levels of the week.

After weeks of protests and strikes, the French senate has approved a measure hiking that nation`s retirement age from 60 to 62. Final approval of the change is expected Monday. France`s unions say the protests will continue, despite today`s vote.

HUDSON: Still ahead on the program, sailing the seas of a weak U.S. economy. We bring you illustrator David Gillette`s latest Inkonomics.

It`s also forking over more than $7 billion to acquire Internet security firmMcAfee. Stacy Smith is the chief financial officer at Intel. He tells NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT using cash wisely is good for Intel investors.

STACY SMITH, CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER, INTEL: I think companies have a moral obligation to do the right things for their constituencies and for us our constituencies are our owners, so we`re always looking at how do we create shareholder value. Our employees and then where we have operations we want to do the right things for the countries and the environment and that constituency as well.

GHARIB: On Monday, you can see our entire interview with Smith as he explains how Intel makes decisions about its $20 billion pile of cash.

Tom, it was a mixed day for the markets but for the week they were up. That makes three in a row. Some nervousness as you mentioned earlier about that G-20 meeting of finance ministers this coming up weekend.

HUDSON: Yes, nervousness about that communique that will come out before the market opens on Monday clearly, but the focus still remains on earnings throughout this week and likely for the next couple of weeks. Let`s get you updated here Susie in tonight`s "Market Focus." And the reason why the focus remains on earnings, this was just the first of three peak weeks for earnings and those earnings helped the major indices clock another week of gains as Susie mentioned. And here are those gains beginning with the Dow Industrials (DJI) adding 0.6 of a percent thanks to gains on Monday, Wednesday and Thursday. The NASDAQ (IXIC) meantime gained 0.4 of a percent, gained four out of the past five sessions as you can see. The S&P 500 (GSPC) 0.6 of a percent higher tonight compared to one week ago.

It was a mixed market overall today. Technology and energy shares really led the gainers. The Dow was hurt by a couple of those earnings reports. Verizon (VZ) one of them. Here are the results. They were better than estimates, but down from a year ago as you can see. Even though Verizon predicted its earnings for the rest of the year will be at the high end of its guidance, shares sold off. Let`s take a look at the stock here, falling more than 1 percent. It was the second biggest percent drop for the Dow Industrial components. It`s now at a one-month low. One concern for Verizon: far fewer new wireless subscribers last quarter than rival AT&T. The other big Dow loser American Express (AXP), dropping 3 percent. Earnings last night were better than expected but loan volume remains low and that`s fueling worries about future revenue growth.

Now oil service stocks really helped energy put in the best sector gains today. Among the leaders here, Schlumberger (SLB). Earnings easily beating estimates after excluding the impact of the acquisition of Smith International. Revenue jumped despite that deep water moratorium that was in place during most of the third quarter. The stock was able to add more than 5 percent on pretty heavy volume. This is its highest price that Schlumberger has seen since early May. Earnings were also in play in technology, helping the top three sector gainers and all three of these are software makers. Take a look. Compuware (CPWR) was up more than 12 percent on some strong earnings. This is a two-year high for shares tonight. CA (CA) jumped 5 percent to its highest price since May. Strong earnings, especially the performance in North America helped last quarter. And Citrix Systems (CTXS) bounced 4 percent. It had a stronger than expected outlook after decent results.

Investors clearly had an appetite for restaurant stocks, pizza, yeah one of them, also Mexican and cheesecake, how about that? We`ll begin with BJ`s (BJRI). It runs pizza and brewery restaurants. Strong results and positive analyst comments fueled a 17 percent run in shares today. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) boosted its same store sales outlook after strong earnings. Shares added 15 percent. Both BJ`s and Chipotle are at all-time highs tonight. Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) also getting an analyst upgrade after some strong results. Shares jumping 8 percent.

Busy week for IPOs, five of them hitting the Street, including two more Chinese-based firms. Take a look at all five here. Tal Education (XRS) started at $10 this week. It provides tutoring services in China. Shares continued jumping throughout the week. ShangPharma (SHP) does research for drug makers. It began trading at $15, closed below that price tonight. Three others -- Vera Bradley`s (VRA) IPO $16 per share, nice big run there. It makes designer handbags. Debit card company NetSpend (NTSP) had investors spending. It started at $11, closing tonight over $13. And Brio (BBRG) is the first American restaurant to go public since 2006. It started at $14 per share and clearly is higher tonight. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: As we`ve been reporting, corporate America is feeling better about earnings. Investors have been rewarded with a market rally. But there seems to be a disconnect with what most Americans are experiencing: lost jobs, lost value in their homes and on and on. With that in mind, we bring you another installment of "Inkonomics with David Gillette." David`s an Emmy-winning illustrator and essayist at Twin Cities public television. Tonight, he ponders the question: has our economic ship sailed?

DAVID GILLETTE: If you`re on a mission to understand the economy, there`s no better place to start than your own back yard. For this cartoonist, we`re talking (INAUDIBLE) Minnesota, a small community just west of Minneapolis and resting on the shores of Lake Minnetonka, a 14,528 acre fresh water playground which incidentally empties itself into Minnehaha Creek, flows through the city of Minnetonka and then drops over Minnehaha Falls. Basically it`s a land where everything starts with minne, the Dakota word for water. And when people in this part of the world want to flex their financial muscles, they spent a lot of money on the minne. It`s an economy measured in boats. But here`s the surprising part. No matter what you may have heard over the last few years about the sour economy, there are still plenty of boats on Lake Minnetonka.

On the surface this makes no sense. If you turn on any electronic device, including practically the toaster, you`re told we`re either in the middle of, emerging from or returning to a recession. For most people this implies a lack of jobs, a lack of money and you would think a lack of time for practicing the principle of displacement. But there they are -- boats. And according to the people who take them to market, the bigger they are, the faster they sell. That`s why out of all the story lines we`re knitting around the contemporary American economy, wasteful government spending, in- exceptional education, foreign competition, I`m hanging my life jacket on the resurgence of financial stratification.

You see, according to the unique glacial pock marks I call home, this country isn`t suffering from an overall shortage of wealth. It`s just that the money we do have is disproportionately concentrated in a handful of 40-foot weekend cruisers and that`s actually where I`m going to stop. You see I`m not stupid. I don`t fully understand the economic forces that allow the rich to get richer while the not rich get not richer. But I do understand human nature. And if I go on national television and make it sound like the entire economic collapse rests on the shoulders of the people who buy boats, my chances of spending a day on the lake are going to end up in the drink.

GHARIB: So Tom, do you think Ben Bernanke knows about the Minnetonka indicator? Maybe we should tell him about the water effect on the economy.

HUDSON: I tell you, as long as those boats are seaworthy, it maybe a lot easier to refloat them, certainly, that`s definitely the truth. Let`s get you updated on what we`re watching for next week. We`ve got a lot on the calendar. Our Friday "Market Monitor" James Paulsen. He`s chief strategist at Wells Capital Management. We`re also due to get an update on housing from the September reports on both new and existing home sales as well as the first report on the third quarter GDP out next Friday. Monday our shoptalk series look at Ikea and how its eco-friendly policies are giving it a competitive advantage.

GHARIB: The U.S. Postal Service still wants you to pay more for stamps. It plans to appeal a regulator`s decision that denied permission to raise rates to $0.46 a stamp. The Postal Service says the increase is needed because of losses caused by a drop in mail volume. It blames it on the weak economy and a shift to email and online bill paying.

HUDSON: Federal regulators are now getting involved in the fee dispute between Cablevision and News Corp. The Federal Communications Commission today sent letters to the heads of both companies. They`ve asked to describe how they`re negotiating in good faith. About three million Cablevision subscribers in New York City and Philadelphia have been cut off from Fox programming. The blackout will enter its second week tomorrow if a deal is not reached.

With the Federal Reserve poised to try to get more money into the economy, tonight`s "Market Monitor" thinks that means inflation. Mark Skousen is editor of the market letter "Forecasts and Strategies." He joins us tonight from the NASDAQ. Mark, nice to see you again, welcome back.

MARK SKOUSEN, EDITOR, "FORECASTS & STRATEGIES": Tom, good to be with you.

HUDSON: So how much inflation and when do you think we`ll actually see it?

SKOUSEN: I think we`re going to see inflation down the road. But we have a triple play right now or hat trick, whatever you want to call it, for investors and I`m very bullish. Because what we have is low interest rates, we have low price inflation and we have easy money by the Fed. And the Fed has deliberately decided to increase inflation to 2 to 3 percent, inflation targeting, that`s what Ben Bernanke cut his teeth on and he`s really trying to impose it.

HUDSON: But we haven`t seen any of that inflation really. Instead we`ve seen disinflation. Still positive numbers, but very, very small.

SKOUSEN: Yes and that`s because the economy is so sluggish, particularly in the United States, unemployment really high. So they`re buying time and that`s great for us as investors because prices for investors are low and it`s an opportunity to be buying and taking advantage of this very unique scenario, because inflation will be coming back. Gold is a great indicator of future inflation and look what that`s doing.

HUDSON: Yes, over $1300 an ounce. So what markets do you like if the Fed is successful and is able to reignite inflation in the months or years ahead?

SKOUSEN: As we can see, this has been very bearish for the dollar, but it`s very bullish for stocks, bonds and commodities. So I`m fully invested in all three of those areas.

HUDSON: So you still like fixed income, even though interest rates are so low.

SKOUSEN: Well, fixed income, no, not Treasury bills that only pay 2 or 3 percent. What I`m talking about is high dividend paying stocks, the kind that I`ve been recommending to your viewers.

HUDSON: Sure, even though you do like dividends, your first new pick here, you`re clearly not afraid of volatility. This is a new stock pick, Rare Element Resources. We`re going to take a look at a chart here. This owns Rare Earth Element mine in Wyoming, REE the ticker symbol. Is Rare Earth Elements as you know Mark a source of some building tensions between the U.S. and China? Are you willing to play that geo-political risk?

SKOUSEN: This is a major geo-political risk and I will warn your viewers and they can see from the chart this stock has already doubled, tripled, quadrupled in value and so it is a risky speculation. But this problem is not going away. China is trying to corner the rare earth market, which is this group of 12 to 17 elements that nobody has ever heard of before that is critical in military applications and in hybrid cars, in cell phones, in computers and you name it and they control 97 percent of this market.

HUDSON: Mark, let me ask you, what kind of price target do you have? What kind of holding period for a volatile stock like that?

SKOUSEN: Well a lot of people think, it`s a micro cap right now, a lot of people think this is a billion dollar company, so it could possibly triple in value, but it is extremely volatile and investors need to know that.

HUDSON: Ninety seconds, I want to get to everything here. A new pick SeaDrill. This is a deep water energy driller, close to a new high. Why choose this deep water driller?

SKOUSEN: Well, because they were hurt by the BP scandal and they are still recovering from it. They have a very nice dividend yield of almost 9 percent. And they`re aggressively expanding. I think it`s a very good play on the expanding energy area.

HUDSON: OK. April 23rd you were last with us. You had three picks back then, two of them, the Ishares exchange-traded fund following Hong Kong, that stock up 17 percent. American Capital, a private equity firm, up by better than almost 6 percent. These are stock returns only. Do you still like these two?

SKOUSEN: Yes, I like Hong Kong because it`s only selling at 15 times earnings, 3 percent dividend. It is the center of growth in Asia. I like American Capital because there`s insider buying recently and it`s still selling below book. That`s a great story.

HUDSON: You also like EPD, this is a natural gas play, Enterprise Products, 15 1/2 percent on its stock price, plus a nice dividend on top of that. Do you still like it?

SKOUSEN: Yes, but I think Dan Duncan, the late, great Dan Duncan died recently. He bought a bunch of stock before hand. It a great rising dividend story, but I`m going to sell that and put that money in Sea Drill.

HUDSON: Take you profits. Any disclosures tonight?

SKOUSEN: Just these are some of the stocks we`re recommending in our services, but I don`t own any myself.

HUDSON: Our "Market Monitor "this evening, Mark Skousen. He`s editor of the market letter "Forecasts and Strategies."

SKOUSEN: Thank you.

GHARIB: And Tom, before we say good night, looking ahead to next week we`ve got a lot to cover, more earnings, more election coverage, more about the markets and of course we`re going to be talking about upcoming decisions being made in Washington at the Fed.

HUDSON: Absolutely, the looming Federal Reserve meeting, which is a week from Wednesday, the day after Election Day. It`s going to be a busy couple weeks here. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT on this Friday evening. Thanks for joining us. It is October 22. I`m Tom Hudson. Have a great weekend and you too, Susie.

GHARIB: Tom, hope you have a great weekend as well. I`m Susie Gharib. Thanks for watching everyone and we hope to see all of you again on Monday night.

END

urn:contentItem:53SY-JP61-DYG3-149H-00000-00Nightly Business Report2011-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:33ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTJohn Kanas, Daniel Gross, Ken SolomanBUSINESS091301cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib, Darren Gersh, Suzanne Pratt, Rick Horrow

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: New proof that an economic recovery remains out of reach: a record number of Americans are living in poverty.

DOUGLAS ELMENDORF, CBO DIRECTOR: I think, really, the fundamental question for you is not how we got here, but where you want the country to go.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: It comes as Congress` super-committee gets a dose of reality at its first public hearing. It`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Tuesday, September 13.

HUDSON: Good evening and thanks for joining us tonight. Nearly one in six Americans or 46 million people, live in poverty. Susie, that startling number comes from a U.S. census report released today. It`s 2.5 million more people than in 2009.

GHARIB: Tom, it`s the fourth straight increase and the largest number of people living in poverty since record-keeping began 52 years ago. The report is also a reminder that all the efforts to jumpstart the economy are not helping the nation`s poorest people. Today`s number represents just over 15 percent of the country. That`s a nearly 1 percent jump from the year 2009. The government defines the poverty line as income of $22,000 a year for a family of four and $11,000 for an individual.

HUDSON: When viewed all together, these numbers represent the severe and widespread financial strains in America today. Steven Ullman of the University of Miami`s school of business says the data has all kinds of ramifications for the economy.

STEVEN ULLMAN, PROFESSOR, UNIV. OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: It means that people are going to have growing history associated with making basic ends meet, being able to afford rent in terms of housing for their families, being ability to afford to put food on the table and of course access to health care becomes that much more problematic.

HUDSON: The same census report shows how problematic access to health care has become. Nearly 50 million Americans do not have medical insurance. That`s more than 16 percent of the population, statistically the same as the year before. Congress passed a health care overhaul last year to deal with rising numbers of uninsured, though many of those main provisions won`t take effect until 2014. The law also is the target of several constitutional court challenges.

GHARIB: A one-two punch on the deficit as the so-called super committee held its first public hearing in Washington. First, data out today shows the Federal budget deficit reached more than $1.2 trillion last month. That number adds pressure on Washington lawmakers to reach agreement to trim government spending. The second came from the head of the Congressional Budget Office. He warned the super-committee that the Federal deficit threatens to cripple the U.S. economy over the long term if it is not dealt with soon. Darren Gersh reports.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The lawmakers charged with coming up with $1.2 trillion in deficit reduction held a public hearing today on the history and drivers of the deficit. The star witness gently suggested that was not really the issue confronting the so- called super committee.

DOUGLAS ELMENDORF, CBO DIRECTOR: I think, really, the fundamental question for you is not how we got here, but where you want the country to go.

GERSH: Douglas Elmendorf, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the deficit problem really comes down to what role the Federal government should play in the economy.

ELMENDORF: And if you want a role that has benefit programs for older Americans like the ones we`ve had in the past and operates the rest of the government like the ones we`ve had in the past, then more tax revenue is needed than under current tax rates. And the other hand, if one wants those tax rates, then one has to make very significant changes in spending programs for older Americans or other aspects.

GERSH: Members of the committee largely seemed locked in the same debates they have been having for the last nine months. Republicans pushing to cut spending...

REP. JEB HENSARLING, CO-CHAIR, JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON DEFICIT REDUCTION: A path to credible deficit reduction is a jobs program and we should not be deterred in that mission.

GERSH: Democrats to preserve spending, blaming much of the current deficits on Bush- era tax cuts.

REP. XAVIER BECERRA, (D) CALIFORNIA: We need to ask ourselves, was it the senior citizen, the student or the Wall Street banker who received the benefit of the spending binge?

GERSH: The CBO director offered a compromise way forward. His agency says the best medicine for the economy is clear.

ELMENDORF: The combination of fiscal policies likely to be most effective would be policies that cut taxes or increase spending in the near term, but over the medium and longer term, move in the opposite direction and cut spending or raise taxes.

GERSH: But there were few signs today either side was willing to compromise to get there. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: Shares inched a bit higher as investors kept an eye on the latest developments regarding Europe`s debt worries today. German Chancellor Angela Merkel rejected the notion that a Greek bankruptcy would provide a quick solution to the Eurozone debt crisis. That possibility was raised just yesterday by her deputy. Here in the states, the Dow Industrials added nearly 45 points today, the NASDAQ rose 37 and the S&P 500 gaining 10.5. Big board volume meantime continues to hold firmly above one billion shares. NASDAQ volume slipped just below two billion.

GHARIB: July 2012 is D-day for the nation`s biggest banks. That`s the deadline for giving regulators a plan on how they would break up and sell off their assets if they are in danger of failing. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or FDIC approved the rule today. Bankers are calling these plans living wills. Under the new law, the largest banks and financial firms, like Citigroup (NYSE: C), JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, would be required to outline liquidation plans so regulators could shut them down in an orderly way to avoid damage to the financial system.

So what kind of shape are the nation`s banks in? Our next guest is a long-time banker and CEO of Bank United, John Kanas. Hi John, nice to have you on the program again.

JOHN KANAS, CHAIRMAN & CEO, BANKUNITED: Hi Susie. How are you?

GHARIB: Good, thank you. Let me start off with asking you, how would you describe the health of the banking system whether we`re talking about the super big banks or the smaller banks.

KANAS: Statistically Susie, the banks are in much better shape than they were four or five years ago. All of the metrics that are normally used to measure the safety of banks have improved. Capital is higher. Reserves against non-performing loans are much higher than they were back in 2007. So in terms of the sheer strength of capital, they`re stronger than they were. Unfortunately, the issue with banks today is the question of profitability since the flagging economy is having trouble getting out of its own way. Banks are having difficulty in expanding their balance sheets and finding opportunities to make loans. And so those who worry about such things worry that bank`s profitability will be under pressure in the near future.

GHARIB: And you`re expecting a wave of bank mergers and in fact your own bank recently bought a small New York bank. Do you think all of these consolidations are good or bad for the economy?

KANAS: It just depends. Some consolidation is essential as we go into the next decade. There are 7,000 banks in the United States and most pundits have thought that we`re probably over banked for some time especially given the relatively slack performance in the economy. Where I think consolidation will cause difficulties is in the small towns of America where there may be only one or two institutions, neither of whom may survive these next few years and it the put further pressure on small business people and even further as the economy tries to recover from these doldrums.

GHARIB: And we hear from so many banks, so many small and medium size businesses, that it`s very tough to get loans from their banks. What is the problem and what`s the solution? Why do we keep hearing this refrain?

KANAS: Those comments are sporadic and they`re geographic. If you happen to run a business in a town where two or three of the banks are in serious trouble and operating under agreements by the regulators that frankly don`t allow them to make loans then you could very well be suffering the consequences of that. To be frank, the large banks and most of the regional banks that is have healthy balance sheets are desperately trying to make loans in this environment, because whether we like it or not, banks can`t make money if they can`t make loans and certainly we`re not going to be able to make any money by investing in government securities that are yielding one or two or three percent. So we desperately need to make loans in this industry and are seeking opportunities to do so.

GHARIB: I want to ask you this, John, you`ve lived through so many recessions in your working career. Is the U.S. headed for another one? From what you`ve seen in the past, how bad -- what kind of shape is the economy in? How bad is it compared to what you lived through before?

KANAS: Some would argue that it`s never really fully recovered from the last recession, and frankly, I`m not sure whether being in a recession or being where we are today, which is in a position of almost no growth is much different. The classic definition of recession two calendar quarters of negative GDP may or may not be reached. But frankly, no one in my banking circles, and no one in business circles, at least in the southeast and the north east where I`m most familiar are looking forward to any significant growth in the next two quarters. So whether we return to recession or not, I think it`s going to feel like it.

GHARIB: We have to leave it there. John thank you so much for coming on the program. We really appreciate your time.

KANAS: Thank you Susie.

GHARIB: We`ve been speaking with John Kanas, who`s the CEO of Bank United.

HUDSON: Still ahead tonight, Target (NYSE: TGT) hits the bull`s eye with bargain shoppers. We`ll show you how its new designer collection is red hot on its first day.

James Murdoch is being recalled for another grilling before Britain`s parliament after former News Corp (NASDAQ: NWS). executives raised serious doubts about his role in that country`s tabloid phone hacking scandal. Two former executives have contradicted Murdoch`s testimony that he did not know the extent of the hacking. James, along with his father you see here, Rupert, appeared before parliament earlier this summer, apologizing for the scandal. So far, the date for James Murdoch`s appearance has not been finalized.

GHARIB: A lot of uncertainty still in the market and that`s why we didn`t see much movement today, Tom.

HUDSON: Not much at all here, really trying to digest all of the news out of Europe as well as trying to discern which direction the U.S. economy is headed here Susie. So let`s go with it with tonight`s "Market Focus." While the major stocks averages moved up from the second session in a row, oil continues to really see this tug of war over lower demand possibly from the U.S. and Europe and a growing thirst from emerging economies. So let`s begin with crude oil jumping more than $2, closing above $90 a barrel here tonight. This is at the top of the range that we`ve seen since this sharp sell-off began back in July. Oil supplies did fall last week due to tropical storms in the Gulf of Mexico and tonight we have rallied up to a five-week high.

Now while oil prices have risen lately, the transportation sector continues really around the low end of the range that we`ve seen it really over the past 12 months. This year we`re looking at is the exchange-traded fund for the Dow transport index. It did see a nice rally today of about 3.5 percent. Worries about economic growth though have pushed this fund down 20 percent from the high of over $100 per share back in July.

Airline stocks ready to take flight. Delta jumping more than 8 percent after reporting its third quarter performance is ahead of forecasts. Delta also will continue to cut the number of seats it makes available this year and early next year. United Continental meantime will modestly cut its U.S. seat capacity while increasing the international capacity. The airlines clearly hope to maintain airfares by not having empty seats. And U.S. Airways says both bookings and pricing remains strong. Shares of U.S. Airways shooting up more than 16 percent, heavy volume trade for LCC today.

Airline stocks not the only mode of transportation to see higher prices. How about railroad? Kansas City Southern (NYSE: SO) (NYSE: KSU) popping almost 6 percent, nice gain as Citigroup (NYSE: C) upgraded its rating to "buy." RailAmerica (NYSE: RA) gained 5 percent. Its biggest shipping product is coal and while traffic has actually continued to drop, it`s the rate of the decline has slowed down. That helped out shares of RA today. Genesee and Wyoming meantime up 4 percent after announcing four and a half consecutive, month-over-month traffic increases, four and a half years of month-over-month traffic increases for GWR shares, up 4 percent.

Late today, we learned that General Electric (NYSE: GE) will pay back Warren Buffett next month. GE will begin buying back $3.3 billion of preferred stock from Buffett. Buffett`s Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE: BRK.A) made that investment bacl in the fall of 2008 at the height of the financial crisis. The pay-back from General Electric (NYSE: GE) comes with a 10 percent redemption premium for Buffett. Before the news, GE was the biggest gainer of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, up 2.7 percent. It was a nice move here today but look at this. It was just yesterday when it hit $15 per share and on this 12-month chart, yeah, that was a 52-week low for GE.

Big tech also helping the market move higher, Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) up 2.4 percent. It has been trying to rally here over the past several sessions tonight at its highest price in a month. Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) and Google (NASDAQ: GOOG) announced a partnership, positioning Google`s smart phone software, Android, to work closely with Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) semiconductors further pushing Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) into the mobile space. Cisco meantime saw a nice rally today, up about 1.6 percent. The CEO John Chambers hit an optimistic tone during an analyst meeting, even as the company released a more conservative growth forecast. Instead of double- digit year-over-year revenue growth which had been the norm at Cisco. Instead the company is predicting revenues to be up 5 to 7 percent over the next three years. Muted growth, nonetheless we are seeing a rally today.

Finally, grain prices taking another tumble. Despite lower harvest estimates this week, both wheat and corn dropping at least 3 percent. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Best Buy (NYSE: BBY) is having difficulty living up to its name. The company said today its quarterly profit fell 30 percent because rival retailers and weak consumer spending, especially on TVs and smart phones. Best Buy (NYSE: BBY) earned $0.47 a share, falling short of analyst estimates. The retailer also lowered its full-year outlook.

It was a much different scene at Target (NYSE: TGT) stores across the country today. The retailer rolled out its highly anticipated designer line "Missoni for Target (NYSE: TGT)." To say the items were popular may be an understatement. Suzanne Pratt reports.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: This was Target (NYSE: TGT) in Mount Vernon, New York at 7:45 this morning. Everyone there wanted one thing, a piece of sky-high fashion at low prices. Customers buzzed through the aisles making a beeline for anything with Missoni`s signature zigzag pattern.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Oh, my God, it`s a fashion steal. Are you kidding me? Who wouldn`t want these at these prices?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A regular sweater costs around $1,000.

PRATT: There were coveted rain boots, pillows and other bedding, super cute kids` clothes, and yes, that`s right, even a Missoni neck roll. And I`m still trying to figure out exactly what this is. It`s 10:00 in the morning, just two hours after this Target (NYSE: TGT) opened and already most of the women`s Missoni collection is gone. Target (NYSE: TGT) managers say they will be replenishing, but they don`t know how much or when. Target (NYSE: TGT) team leader Kyle Wilhelmy says he wasn`t surprised by the Missoni madness.

KYLE WILHELMY, EXECUTIVE TEAM LEADER, TARGET: We`ve had a lot of designers do really well here in the past. So, we anticipated it. We staffed for it and we were ready for it.

PRATT: Those who chose to shop online were disappointed. The site crashed early this morning. Target (NYSE: TGT) blamed demand for Missoni. Many retail experts say Target (NYSE: TGT) does a great job creating a frenzy ahead of its designer launches. This pop-up Missoni store in Manhattan opened last week and was sold out in hours. Analyst Jharonne Martis is impressed by Target`s know-how.

JHARONNE MARTIS, RETAIL ANALYST, THOMSON REUTERS: We`ve already seen so many items fly of the shelf that it`s definitely going to help boost September same store sales for Target (NYSE: TGT). It`s a very smart strategy, a very smart partnership. And if Target (NYSE: TGT) continues to do so, they will continue to succeed in the coming years.

PRATT: And then there are customers who simply can`t resist the chance to own even a tidbit of the iconic Missoni design.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I`ve never done this before. In fact, I`ve never been at a store at 10 after 8:00 in the morning to shop.

PRATT: Guess what? She`s coming back tomorrow morning. And, you know, so am I. Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

GHARIB: Here`s what we`re watching for you for tomorrow. We`ll see the August reports on retail sales and the producer price index. MIT economist and Professor Simon Johnson joins us to discuss the impact of Europe`s debt crisis. And Hilary Kramer is our "Street Critique" guest. Email your questions to streetcritique@nbr.com

Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) wants America to run on Windows. To spread the word, the software giant handed out 5,000 Samsung tablet computers today that run on Windows 8. That will give users a chance to experience Microsoft`s next software system that includes features tailored for touch screens and tablets. The company hopes to take a bite out of consumers switching to Apple`s iPad. Tablet makers are expected to start selling products with Windows 8 by the middle of next year.

HUDSON: H&R Block (NYSE: HRB) will not offer refund anticipation loans during next year`s tax season. The company says its client base is growing and the appeal of those high-cost loans is shrinking. H&R Block (NYSE: HRB) was unable to offer the loans this year after regulators directed its third- party lending bank to stop funding the project. Now the tax services giant will continue to let customers use their anticipated refunds though to pay for tax preparation.

GHARIB: Is the economy behaving like Tennessee Williams characters? Tonight`s commentator thinks so. Here`s Daniel Gross, columnist and economic editor at Yahoo (NASDAQ: YHOO)! Finance.

DANIEL GROSS, COLUMNIST & ECONOMICS EDITOR, YAHOO! FINANCE: Time was, governments bailed out their own troubled companies and citizens came to the aid of their own floundering governments. But today, we`re in the Blanche Dubois economy: companies, countries and sectors imperiled by dint of their own poor life choices are relying on the kindness of strangers. Greece is waiting on future bailouts from its frenemies in northern Europe. Italy, unable or unwilling to take aggressive action to cuts its deficits, is now looking to the Chinese government to plow some of its vast foreign currency reserves into Italian bonds.

In the U.S., a broken-down Chrysler was acquired and recapitalized by Fiat, an Italian company. And if you`re an American stuck with an insanely expensive real estate white elephant, your only hope seems to be selling to a foreigner. A British heiress recently purchased Aaron Spelling`s $85 million Hollywood mansion, which had lingered on the market for ages. Money is indeed scurrying around the world. I`m Daniel Gross.

HUDSON: Finally tonight, if the Greek economic drama hasn`t been enough international intrigue, look no further than this year`s U.S. open tennis tournament. Serbian Novak Djokovic cranked his winning shot on match point, defeating the defending champion Rafael Nadal of Spain last night and bringing with it a double digit increase in television ratings. Tonight`s "Beyond the Scoreboard" looks at the business of tennis. Here`s Rick Horrow.

RICK HORROW: A slow job market and bad weather are not ideal conditions for an outdoor game that can take hours to finish. Those are the challenges for the tennis industry and it showcased an American event that wrapped up this week, the U.S. Open. According to the tennis industry association, rackets, tennis ball, even string shipments all fell during the first half of the year. Players may be spending less on tennis gear, but more people are spending time watching the sport. Television ratings for the U.S. Open were up from a year ago. I spoke with Ken Soloman, the chairman and CEO of the tennis championship.

KEN SOLOMAN, CHAIRMAN & CEO, THE TENNIS CHANNEL: This is the one sport where women are as, if not more popular than the men both on court and in terms of their real playing. That doubles the potential scale of the enterprise going in.

HORROW: So talk about the business model generally. You are somewhat independent and you have to compete with the big boys everybody day. How does that work?

SOLOMAN: The season of tennis is a lot like a movie slate in that we`ve got four (INAUDIBLE) blockbusters every year called the grand slam. Those are like multi-hundred million dollar sequels. Everybody know what they are. They come back every single year. Those are our tent poles.

HORROW: So you`ve got the content model all taken care of. But the revenue model, the distribution model. Was it harder than you thought when you started?

SOLOMAN: Our distributors are also our competitors. Many are the very same people who control the pipes, like a Comcast (NASDAQ: CMCSA) (NYSE: CCS) like a Cablevision, also have their own networks. It`s a natural outcropping of business to say well look, if I`ve got golf channel, and a piece of the major league baseball network and NHL network and NBA network, those are going to get preferential treatment if I have a choice and I`m Comcast (NASDAQ: CMCSA) (NYSE: CCS). And that`s why golf channel is in 23 million homes and Versus (ph) is in 23 Comcast (NASDAQ: CMCSA) (NYSE: CCS) homes. Virtually every one of their household subscriber homes preferring (ph) with no additional charge and tennis channel is only in about 2.7 to three million homes with a $5.99 or $6.99 surcharge. That wouldn`t be happening if we were owned by them.

HORROW: You do have some synergies. Here at this tournament, ESPN, CBS (NYSE: CBS), NBC for the French. How do you make that work?

SOLOMAN: We became evangelists for the notion that integrated networks, an integrated web of networks was superior to what had previously been the model which was exclusivity. Platforms would buy rights and then say whatever I don`t put out, I don`t want anybody to have. We went to the French tennis federation and said look, ESPN is doing a great job. They`ve got about 50 hours. Looks like NBC has about 12 to 15. You`re doing 400 and they`re all good. Every one of those minutes on the red clay is great and you`re not seeing the Serena match or the Roger match or the Ken (INAUDIBLE) match or the (INAUDIBLE) match because you had to show something else. Let us do that.

And that was our first grand slam and we went back to ESPN and to CBS (NYSE: CBS) and NBC and said let us shoulder the burden of it. Let us find a way to share costs on the back end for the stuff that people don`t see and let`s promote the whole thing together. Our presentation is much more like an Olympics presentation. That`s two weeks of content morning noon and night just like here the U.S. Open. And their ratings go up, because we`re promoting to them, and our only quid pro quo was look, when you go off and you go to ESPN into Nascar or bull riding or women`s basketball, please make sure that you toss that to us so that you don`t make the tennis fan unhappy.

HUDSON: Tennis channel CEO Ken Soloman with Rick Horrow. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Tuesday evening, September 13. Thanks for joining us. Have a great night Susie.

GHARIB: Same to you, Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Have a great evening everyone and we hope to see all of you again tomorrow night.
